sections.name: Genre
sections.blurb: These awards are given to the anime from each genre that displayed all-around excellence compared to the competition. Each show is assigned to one of seven genre categories, and a winner is chosen within each category.

awards.name: Action
awards.blurb:
The sheer abundance of brilliant action shows in 2021 made the elimination process for the final nominations a rigorous, but satisfying task.  While sifting through potential nominations, it was clear that many shows excelled in aspects ranging from impressionable characters to stylish palettes,and gripping narratives. 
 
Countless days were spent watching and discussing shows during the jury process. Along the way we lost multiple good shows despite them receiving juror support such as, Black Clover, Godzilla: Singular Point, and Nomad: Megalo Box 2. While each show excelled in different areas, they were culled due to other nominations being stronger. Both *SSSS.Dynazenon's* and *Kingdom 3's* focus on characters, relationships, and narrative was well-regarded. Idaten-tachi and 86: Eighty Six had excellent direction, and the slow unraveling of their gritty worlds made each episode intriguing. There were shows whose fight scenes contained some of the most visually impressive animation of the year, such as Kimetsu no Yaiba: Mugen Ressha-hen  Fate/stay night [Heaven's Feel] III, Jujutsu Kaisen, and Gintama: The Final. 
 
The finalization process was not an easy one due to the polarizing nature of some of our nominations.  After days of heated discussion, very few of us seemed willing to  budge. This ranking is a representation of what we believe to be the best action anime released this year.

nominees.writeup:
*Kingdom's* third season is a masterclass of storytelling unfortunately held back by its average animation. Being historical fiction all the characters have roots in real life, and it does a good job making you understand why these people were important. The political machinations they use, the tactics and skills needed to overcome conflict, and the drive of each to achieve their own personal goals are enhanced by the larger-than-life presentation the anime creates, allowing them to feel like they stepped out of an epic, over a mere history book. 


Although much of this season's runtime is spent covering one conflict, that time is well spent. The slow rise of the action gives every front of the battle time to breathe, allowing every character to show off in their ensuing challenges. It captures a scale of combat normally glossed over in ancient war stories. There is still the ever-present anime tendency to have plot relevant characters do a lot of the heavy lifting, but tactics do play a large role in how the battles unfold as well. 


The production unfortunately is relatively lackluster, and is average at the best of times, despite improvements from previous seasons. Large scale horse charges use CGI animals, wide shots that show off large sections of the battlefield tend to lack detail, and because this covers one conflict there is not much change in scenery over the course of the season. 


While lacking in sakuga moments, *Kingdom 3* is hard to put down. The handling of the story through it's narrative and characters makes it a must see for anyone with an interest in ancient China or history in general.

Studio Pierrot



Directed by Ken`ichi Imaizumi and Kazuya Monma

nominees.writeup:
2022 had some big bombastic action movies, and while many left much to be desired; *Gintama: The Final* was thankfully one of the better ones. *The Final* is a well-crafted love letter to the franchise, full of call-backs, references, in-jokes, and a shocking amount of emotional weight to go with the humor and action. The big Gintoki fight scene was one of the more visually impressive and intricately choreographed battles, not just in the franchise, but in the action category overall. While this was the standout scene of the movie, sadly, this did not quite apply to the rest of the film's fairly standard animation.


Furthermore, the movie, while great for *Gintama* fans, is not exactly a film for newcomers. One must be well-versed in the franchise to fully enjoy this picture. Even then, they might find the movie's structure rather disorientating as it starts with a rapid-fire parody recap and then just throws you into the deep end. That said, for those who are fans of *Gintama*, this movie has everything one could possibly ask for and it delivered this in the most appropriate and fitting way for the franchise. 


Thus, while not perfect, this passionate farewell to *Gintama* certainly more than earned its 3rd place finish in Action.
nominees.staff:
BN Pictures



Directed by Chizuru Miyawaki

nominees.writeup:
Trigger saves anime again with their thrilling throwback and masterfully crafted love letter to the Tokusatsu genre. This of course refers to their latest Gridman Universe series of *SSSS.Dynazenon*. This phenomenal series combines the excellent character writing and story arcs of *SSSS.Gridman* with kinetic and hard-hitting action set-pieces that were both compelling to behold and entertaining to watch. Aside from dazzling the visual senses, the series' audio-based traits excelled as well, with top-notch seiyuu performances and amazing music and sound effects, setting an appropriate sense of scale for these literally larger than life sequences. 


Speaking of which, the combining mecha versus Kaiju fights were populated with elaborate choreography and impressive cinematography; and furthermore, this series had the brains to go with its beauty as the interactions between the show's various cast members among one another kept things interesting and provided stakes for the audience to be invested in. The production values, while high overall, did suffer slightly due to the unfortunate use of CGI animation. However, Trigger's excellent cinematography and boundless creativity mostly overcame this trivial hurdle. 


Furthermore, the show's callbacks to events and characters hailing from both *SSSS.Gridman* and *Gridman The Hyper Agent* were integrated well into the show and all felt organic rather than ham-fisted or nostalgia pandering. Thus, *SSSS.Dynazenon* was a thought-provoking, and exciting Mecha series, as well as one of the year's best in the Action category. Thus, it is with great honor to report that this amazing series placed first in the Action category.

Directed by Akira Amemiya

nominees.writeup:
*Heion Sedai no Idaten-tachi* tells the story of a group of ”heroes” that don't *really* have any villains to defeat. However, this setup is used to subvert all expectations that one might have when watching it. This show is surprising in many different ways.


This show never stops, be it the plot or the animation. Being very stylish and dynamic, with great color design choices and editing transitions, it's hard to feel bored and uninterested when watching all the combat scenes that happen very often, but even the slower scenes feel very fluid. The plot is no different, with a constant change of scenarios and problems; it never stops moving forward. If the story has some down time where not much happens, *Idaten* is not afraid to completely skip to the good part.


However, it's not all sunshine and rainbows. Even if *Idaten* is not afraid to make jokes, it goes places which are triggering to some people, like religion and, most commonly, rape and sex jokes. These jokes feel very out of place and don't serve much (if any) purpose to the story, and are ultimately a major turn-off.


Despite its comedic flaws and an ending that left much to be desired, *Idaten's* excellent production and subversion of storytelling lets it finish in 7th place.

Directed by Seimei Kidokoro

nominees.writeup:
Ufotable's adaptation of the Fate series is well renowned, and not without reason. With the last installment of *Heaven's Feel*, Ufotable outdid themselves once again. *Heaven's Feel III* offers a spectacle that will be remembered for years to come due to its focus put into the production, and the fact that it's the conclusion to the most popular path of the original game.


From a production viewpoint it is easy to notice care put into this movie. Action sequences feel alive and each flow feels impactful thanks to smooth animation and sharp visual effects. Additionally, the soundtrack manages to convey the current mood of the scene, be it sad or hype moments.


Most of the fame of Fate comes from characters and their struggles, and this entry is no different. While historical characters such as Rider or Saber had less focus than they deserved, this route's deep dive on modern-day cast members Shirou and Sakura is very commendable. We experience their inner-workings and what in life led to current events, offering an immersive character drama.


Overall, *Fate/Stay Night [Heaven's Feel] III* offers immersive enjoyment due to its stunning visuals and interesting main cast. As a result, it lands in second place, barely missing the higher ranking due to some missed opportunities.

Directed by Tomonori Sudou

nominees.writeup:
*Kimetsu no Yaiba: Mugen Ressha-hen* is the record-breaking follow up to 2019's smash hit TV series. The film is filled to the brim with some of the most exciting, high-quality action scenes in the category. Director Haruo Sotozaki and his team pour in all the talent and passion they have to generate as much hype into the action as they can with superb animation, choreography, and sound design. The animation isn't just superb in the action scenes, but in the emotional character acting scenes as well. 


While the animation and action were a source of praise, there was little in the story and character department. The film's plot is simplistic for its tone and doesn't differentiate itself from the rest of shounen anime. Additionally, the film does little to add depth to the already basic cast from the TV series. However, the addition of Rengoku Kyoujuro is very welcome, bringing an entertaining personality to several scenes.


Overall, *Kimetsu no Yaiba* brings enough entertainment for two hours to satisfy fans of the TV series and shounen fans alike to earn a nomination in this category.
nominees.staff:
Ufotable



Directed by Haruo Sotozaki

nominees.writeup:
*86: Eighty-Six* is a hard-hitting war story that truly stands out. Its plot is incredibly well paced, production is on point, and the voice actors really deliver. As the audience we learn new information and twists at the same time as the protagonist. That is used to create scenes that take their time to show how the MC is feeling, something very uncommon in anime.


Lena, the protagonist, is superbly well written, with praise-worthy character development throughout the season. The rest of the cast is not lacking in development either, with the character-driven approach to worldbuilding making the cast feel real. Unfortunately, there are many characters that end up being underutilized with their stories being cut short. Some deaths have little to no weight to them and that ends up feeling somewhat out of place with how impactful the others are.


The battles in this anime are a low point, regrettably. The mechas are different from the usual fair; the mechas from The Legion have awesome looking designs. But the mechas from the 86 are too similar to each other, making it a bit difficult to identify them in the middle of a battle. They are also CGI; although not badly made, it can still put some people off.


With beautiful backgrounds, excellent framing, the use of “cameras”, and shots inspired by live-action rules, scenes can flow very well when there's a lot of movement while also having time to breathe when they need to. The story is neither rushed nor sluggish, and does a great job at setting up whatever is in the future for the series.
nominees.staff:
A-1 Pictures



Directed by Toshimasa Ishii

nominees.writeup:
*Jujutsu Kaisen* is an extremely satisfying anime to watch due to its unique battle system, characters, consistently stylish and over-the-top action sequences, and amazing soundtrack. Despite this, it still feels like a collection of standardized battle shounen tropes with little originality. *Jujutsu Kaisen's* curse energy techniques feel akin to power systems seen in other long running shows such as nen in *Hunter x Hunter* or stands in *Jojo's Bizarre Adventure*. While not original, the creativity and variety of abilities, when paired with excellent pacing and seamlessly interwoven backstories, can make for a truly spectacular experience like episode 17.


*Jujutsu Kaisen's* focus on minuscule details such as the character's subtle body movements helps convey the inter-character relationships and gives the main characters a decent amount of depth. Unfortunately, the insipid supporting characters are void of development. Despite this, quite a few are impressionable, or at the very least relatable. Pacing inconsistencies were present for the introductory arcs in the first half. However, the tournament arc in the second half gave the show a chance to breathe and allowed each character a time to shine with smartly written battles oozing with flair.


The groundwork has been laid for what could potentially be one of the best battle shounens we have seen in awhile. *Jujutsu Kaisen* was one of the more highly anticipated series of 2021, and Mappa's stellar production has phenomenally enhanced almost every facet of the source material, landing it in a respectable 5th place.

awards.name: Adventure
awards.blurb:
It’s clear that isekai had a huge impact this year. *Log Horizon Entaku Houkai* is the long-awaited sequel to one of the first shows that started the isekai boom. *Tensura S2* is a sequel to one of the most popular in general. *Sekai Saikou no Ansatsusha* keeps the trend going with its own take on reincarnation stories. And of course, who could forget *Mushoku Tensei*, one of the best-looking and most popular anime of the year.  
 
It wasn’t all isekai stories though; there were several differently-styled anime as well. *Dr. Stone: Stone Wars* is another sequel a few years coming that kept what was enjoyable about the first season. For new series, *Yoru no Kuni* stands out as a short series with distinct visuals and uplifting episodes. On the other side of the coin is *To Your Eternity*, a relatively longer show that tugs at your heartstrings. *Star Wars Visions* differs from all the others as an anthology film, with wildly different staff and tones depending on the episode. It was great to see the isekai subgenre becoming more diverse, with good fantasy works coming from outside it too. *Mushoku Tensei* and *Yoru no Kuni*, the top two shows, really highlighted this in their close battle for first.

nominees.writeup:
Growing up is a universal human experience.  It is hard to express the breadth of emotions that anyone might experience during their formative years, but *Yoru no Kuni* comes close.  It follows three young girls in different stages of adolescence and pivotal moments they experience in the strange Night World under the guidance of Yoru.

Chiyu is an elementary-aged girl who grapples with death for the first time when her dog passes away. She's whisked away to the Night World where she meets the ethereal Yoru, who helps her confront her feelings.  The story continues with Tsumugi, a middle schooler dealing with jealousy, and Akatsuki, a recent college grad having just suffered another job application rejection.  They're all poignant depictions of deeply relatable events.

The Night World itself is a beautifully realized dreamscape that uses music and color to heighten emotion.  The soft glow that the stars give off contrast brilliantly with Yoru's pure black body.  The soundtrack uses violin, piano and harp purposefully to heighten the magic of the show.  Yoru's large, wing-like arms are both strange and welcoming, inviting the girls into their embrace.

Every minute of this short experience is profound. It doesn't overstay its welcome or become preachy. It accomplishes what it set out to do perfectly.  *Yoru no Kuni* is a triumph, and its second-place finish reflects that.

Studio Daisy

Directed by Ryouchimo

nominees.writeup:
*Log Horizon Entaku Houkai* is divided into 3 main arcs, each with a very different focus. The first has no action, focusing on the politics and diplomatic agreements the series is known for. The story is the best part, especially Shiroe and Rayneshia's scenes. Unfortunately, the pacing was a big problem for this arc, there were too few interesting moments to justify its length.
The second arc is even weaker, focusing on only a couple of familiar characters. Instead, the second arc introduces many new characters at once that aren't very memorable. The animation of the show in general wasn't very good, but the second arc has the worst of it with its action-oriented focus. There are many still frames, a big flaw for an action-oriented segment.
The final arc was an improvement. This arc gave the younger members of Log Horizon and Akatsuki time to shine. The action carries this section of the show. The final fight is just as climactic as a season finale should be. Minori and Akatsuki's touching scene is the icing on the cake.
*Log Horizon* has many strong moments this season, especially in the first and last arc. However, its production flaws and weaker segments hold it back compared to many of the other nominations.

Studio Deen

Directed by Shinji Ishihara

nominees.writeup:
*Sekai Saikou no Ansatsusha, Isekai Kizoku ni Tensei suru* is an Isekai show centered on Lugh the veteran assassin that dies in a plane crash after serving a criminal organization, who then reincarnates into a fantasy world. His task in his new life is simple: kill the hero that is prophesied to destroy the entire world.
Needless to say, this show presents a certain amount of flaws that hurt its overall reputation. Using Lugh as an anti-hero was initially a good idea, however, it was poorly executed since it doesn't provide any depth to its character. 
Lugh's ability to continuously surpass all the obstacles he faces without any struggles gives away any potential for character development or an unique narrative. Certain themes like pedophilia or human trafficking are used as a tool to gather a cast of superficial and cliché female characters. 
Using assassination elements such as, creating a magical sniper or using sneaking fighting styles to kill his subjects, was undoubtedly an interesting approach. However, as time passes, these abilities quickly become redundant and stale, as Lugh begins to use rather furtive and straightforward methods in order to defeat his enemies. 
Furthermore, the production value of this show is also underwhelming, as the further we progress the more the audio-visual quality decreases.
For the reasons previously stated, this story loses out compared to other nominations as the plot suffers from a lack of originality, with a cast of shallow and uninteresting characters and a show with a predictable outcome.
nominees.staff:
Silver Link, Studio Palette

Directed by Masafumi Tamura

nominees.writeup:
*Star Wars: Visions* is a fantastic anthology that has appeals not only to Star Wars fans, but also to anime fans in general.  Beloved studios including Trigger and Science Saru try their hand at evolving the worlds in the galaxy far, far away, unfettered by preexisting worldbuilding, and do so with mixed success.

Episodes like "The Twins" and "Lop and Ocho" are very familiar to anime fans.  The former has Trigger director Hiroyuki Imaishi's signature style and hype, while the latter is an endearing story about love and family.  Each expertly uses its runtime to give just enough context and maintain a sense of wonder while subtly building deep characters.  Some episodes were more controversial, such as "The Duel," with its daring artistic style that some could find off-putting.  The biggest miss of the series, "Tatooine Rhapsody," doesn't quite match the tone of the rest of the show.

Many of the narratives detail the journeys of new or upcoming Jedi, which develops a kind of rhythm in the show.  "The Ninth Jedi" is especially evocative, following a lightsaber smith's daughter finding her way amongst other chosen Jedi.  "TB-01" pays clear homage to the classic *Astro Boy* in both its story and TB-01's design.  Geno Studio executes Lop's complex, innovative character design from "Lop and Ocho" perfectly, even in action scenes.

The quality of *Star Wars: Visions* is certainly shaky at times, but its highs soar higher than many other shows do in multiple cours.  For Star Wars fans, animation studio aficionados, or just anyone who likes anime, *Visions* is worth checking out, and its inclusion among the year's best Adventures is well-deserved.

nominees.altname: Tensei Shitara Slime Datta Ken 2nd Season (Part 1 and 2)
nominees.writeup:
The second season of *Tensei Shitara Slime Datta Ken* continues with Rimuru's quest to establish the Monster's Federation with the help of his friends.

Like its predecessor, this season is centered heavily around political issues, often ending in conflicts between monsters and the other kingdoms. This results in a consistent story build-up all the way to the final battle against the antagonist of this season.

This show is predominantly known to have an extensive cast of characters, with a variety of unique designs and personalities. However, this season, some members of the supporting cast share the spotlight, giving space for character progression from other members and a fresh touch to the story.
Nevertheless, this sequel suffers from the same issues that the first season had. This largely stems from Rimuru being a seemingly unbeatable main character. He's always able to prevail against the obstacles he faces which removes a lot of excitement. This is especially true in the last battle of the season, which proves that Rimuru has not faced any real difficulties during his quest so far. Perhaps that fan service is the main driver of this story.

Despite these flaws, this season was filled with exciting and epic battles and a better story pacing, which is why it fully deserved the fourth spot on the list.
nominees.staff:
8bit

Directed by Atsushi Nakayama

nominees.writeup:
How far would you go to save everyone? Senku sets out to answer that in *Dr. Stone: Stone Wars*. This season is one arc, about the clash of ideals between Senku and Tsukasa. Senku's side of the story cuts back on the first season's edutainment comedy about science, giving fewer but still energetic summaries on how to make different quickly advancing technologies.

*Dr. Stone* remains a strong show well into its second season. That is not to say it is without issue. The animation does not stand out much, rarely having any moments that pop in a way you want to see again and again. The soundtrack did not have many memorable tunes aside from the opening. Every character has thick plot armor, and science is tossed around as an easy way to keep the characters idealistic.

With the above aside, the core conflict between the idealized world made by technological advancement and the horrors experienced in the world that helped define the difference in mindsets between the leaders of the two factions creates a compelling narrative. Senku's side of the story revolves around his understanding of the world, and his optimistic views powered by science in the face of overwhelming odds. He keeps a strong face, using a bit of wit and quick thinking to stay ahead no matter how dire the situation.

*Stone Wars* does well to cement itself in the middle of the rankings. It has a strong core that makes it a must watch for anyone interested in discovering what a science shonen has to offer.
nominees.staff:
TMS Entertainment, 8PAN

Directed by Shinya Iino

nominees.writeup:
*Fumetsu no Anata e* is a truly unique emotional roller-coaster ride about life, companionship, and death. It has one of the best opening episodes of the year that introduces Fushi and ends with an emotional gut punch and beautifully presents a story about mortality. The series continues to grow and develop Fushi's infant-like character through relationships with March, Parona, Gugu, and Pyoran who all have compelling stories of their own. Gugu, particularly, stands out with a compelling backstory and an impactful end to his character arc.

The second half however is a step down in quality. The characters introduced in the latter half fail to have the same impact that the first group did. The new characters have nowhere near the depth and comradery that Gugu and the shop crew had. It becomes clear that the series has a formula that kills a lot of the suspense and it becomes predictable. While the series has compelling protagonists the same cannot be said for the antagonists that were seen as bland and, in some cases, unnecessary.

*Fumetsu no Anata e* still has some of the best emotionally-driven scenes that will bring tears to many eyes and has some of the best written characters of 2021 landing it a third place spot.
nominees.staff:
Brain's Base

Directed by Masahiko Murata

nominees.altname: Mushoku Tensei: Isekai Ittara Honki Dasu (Part 1 and Part 2)
nominees.writeup:
Isekai is a genre that keeps growing in popularity. Given that *Mushoku Tensei*'s web novel was one of the first to popularize this genre, one would expect it to have the most basic plot and cast, but it's remarkable how it can break so many expectations and be so different from other isekais.

The characters are one of this show's many highlights. It's filled with deeply flawed individuals on the path of discovering the world, themselves, and how to improve. Seeing their evolution in such a detailed and well-paced story is fantastic. While some characters start out as known tropes, you won't have to wait long until they grow into something that exceeds what we are used to. Watching Rudeus overcome his trauma from his past life as a shut-in NEET is greatly appreciated.

An isekai's main selling point should be the world the protagonist is sent to, and *Mushoku Tensei* has one of the best worlds in anime. The world was built with such care and attention to detail and it shows. It feels lived in, interesting, different, wondrous, and perfectly sets the stage for many amazing scenes filled with action, drama and exploration.

It is a shame that the isekai that follow *Mushoku Tensei* didn't learn from it, as it truly is a masterclass.
nominees.staff:
Studio Bind

Directed by Manabu Okamoto

awards.name: Comedy
awards.blurb:
2021 showed that comedy transcends all formats, with TV anime, shorts, OVAs, and movies all having impressive showings. The nominees also incorporate distinct genres for a unique story. The over-the-top adventure *Meikyuu Black Company*, the character-driven fantasy and slice of life *Slime Taoshite 300-nen*, the monstrous suspense story *Mieruko-chan*, and a pair of new rom-coms, with the social anxiety of *Komi-san wa, Komyushou desu* and the non-stop teasing of *Ijiranaide, Nagatoro-san* all highlight this point. Moreover, two nominees return back: the continued ridiculous scenarios of *Zombie Land Saga: Revenge* alongside the more parody-focused *Kaguya-sama wa Kokurasetai OVA*. Lastly, a surprising yet deserving nominee is the stop-motion short, *Pui Pui Molcar*. 
 
Many strong potential nominees were discussed at length, and unfortunately shows such as *Gintama: The Final*, *Osomatsu-san 3*, and *Mairimashita! Iruma-kun 2* missed the cut. After selecting the jury’s nominees, the jury added them together with the selections from the public. While some nominees started to rise or fall during discussion, there was not a single entry with a consensus ranking, thus leading to much deliberation over differing opinions and overall ranking of the nominees. In the end, no ranking is perfect; however, it represents the jury’s thoughts as a whole together, given the many strong entries for 2021.

nominees.writeup:
*Pui Pui Molcar*, a charmingly odd little show, packs a lot into each two-minute episode. The show maintains a stream of gags from start to end, enhanced by the unique stop-motion presentation. Each episode contains plenty of surprises, which range from a somewhat mundane traffic jam to time travel. 


The show's comedy is fairly easy to get into, relying heavily on visual gags since the Molcars, and occasional plot-relevant humans, only ever squeak or make noises to imply an emotion. As such, this quick nature leads to a lack in nuanced character development, yet it may be especially preferable given the show's premise. Alternatively, it can lack depth at times due to this, but it has enough going on where it largely goes noticed by the end of any given episode. 

Additionally, the show incorporates well-handled pop culture references that are usually restricted to the background, with the exception of a magical girl and *Back to the Future* reference. Although not a huge part of the show, the references give a small nod to those who notice them. 

*Pui Pui Molcar*'s effective use of its runtime and rapidfire comedy makes it a strong contender for this year. The energy, unique design, and use of stop motion allow the show to stand out, even among the full-length shows that often overshadow shorts. With the entire show being watchable in under an hour, it is a joy that easily fits into any schedule, and thus fits snuggly into second place.
nominees.staff:
Shin-Ei Animation
Directed by Tomoki Misato

nominees.writeup:
Coming into the summer 2021 season, it was easy to miss this hidden comedic gem. Despite being an isekai, *Meikyuu Black Company* broke away from many overused elements of the genre. The plot loosely connects as the story changes unexpectedly and swirls the audience into action. One such arc switches the setting and presents a new short-term goal with additional characters. Not only does this prepare the audience for a fresh experience, it also presents the characters with varied situations and opportunities for comedy.

However, there are drawbacks to this. All arcs' goals are ultimately shallow to compensate for its pace. As the next arc begins, it frantically jumps to another, thus leading to undeveloped moments. The show is dependent on its gimmicks, from “we need to go there!” to “we need to defeat this boss!” without much elaboration.

Still, the way the cast was crafted and presented makes the show stand out amongst the oversaturated genre, even more so than the story. *Meikyuu* is not afraid to show characters their rotten and problematic personalities, such as Ninomiya's lack of work ethics. Each interaction does not play things safe, but rather brings personalities to the extreme for great comedic effect.

As each character shows off their absurdity, each episode becomes crazier as it goes on, and in a good way. The tight comedic timing and contrasting characters hyperbolize tension, before ending it all with a chilled-out ED. Therefore, *Meikyuu Black Company* lands strongly in third place for this category.
nominees.staff:
SILVER LINK.
Directed by Mirai Minato

nominees.writeup:
Isekai, where the protagonist typically spends their time going to the adventurer's guild for some jobs, exploring the world, or perhaps creating a nation for monsters...but how about chilling and killing slimes for 300 years? The exchange of a deep, intricate plot for a more relaxing, slow story is exactly what *Slime Taoshite 300-nen, Shiranai Uchi ni Level Max ni Nattemashita* does, and it is successful in doing that.

The cast is quite diverse, having many fantastical races alongside character tropes. Seeing their interactions as they somewhat become family is endearing, and many great jokes complement those moments. However, in order to achieve that, the characters end up being rather simplistic, which has its strengths and weaknesses. It helps the show achieve its serene atmosphere while maintaining the audience's enjoyment, yet it can also make the plot predictable and slightly stale.

Moreover, production can be better. Despite some scenes exceeding expectations in animation, the majority of the show's visuals are passable. Nevertheless, other production values are effectively unique, like the voiced sound-effects that greatly improve the show's comfortable ambience. This shows the careful considerations put into the show.

While *Slime Taoshite 300-nen* has its flaws, it still manages to be an entertaining and funny show that is great to watch as a de-stressor, thus capturing fourth place.
nominees.staff:
REVOROOT
Directed by Nobukage Kimura

nominees.writeup:
*Mieruko-chan* is at its best when not trying to be funny, with the emotional moments being the highlight of the show. It manages to surprise the audience by breaking up the usual flow of comedy and subverting the viewers' expectations. Unfortunately, the show does not explore these emotional moments often, and the comedy can be hit or miss.
Most of the jokes in the show fall into two types. Miko either tries to hide her reaction from the ghost or a misunderstanding occurs, as people who cannot see the ghosts are left confused by Miko's behavior. In relying on these two plot ideas, the enjoyment is largely dependent on personal preference. In addition, the production elements do little in aiding the comedic moments. The directing deprives the jokes of any impact, with numerous fanservice shots during tense scenes that flaw the parody horror show. Moreover, the art style and character design lack emphasis and do not quite stand out, losing the opportunity to effectively use it given the show's premise. In contrast, the monsters are memorable with their nice designs, even despite the limited runtime dedicated to each.
As such, while the premise is interesting with some decent moments, *Mieruko-chan*'s flaws and lack of comedic variety bring the show to eighth place.
nominees.staff:
Passione
Directed by Yuuki Ogawa

nominees.writeup:
The wild misadventures of Franchouchou return once more with the hilarious crew of adorable zombie idols and their larger-than-life Producer, Kotaro Tatsumi. And much like last time, the cast continues its quest to save Saga and deliver some hard-hitting, emotional beats while everyone is laughing. By this, MAPPA demonstrates that lightning can strike twice, as this sequel builds off of the foundation and the strengths of *Zombie Land Saga*.

*Revenge* thus soars to even greater heights, with the voice actors delivering impassioning and entertaining performances. Indeed, several standouts include Producer's hammy antics and THE LEGENDARY YAMADA TAE's guttural roars as the obligated mindless zombie of the bunch. Furthermore, hilarious, though plot-related moments are prevalent, a notable one being the zombie idols clawing out of debt through part-time jobs and sheer dumb luck.

Furthermore, the CGI improves from that seen in season one, as there are some effective and creative uses of it, like Yamada Tae going all in on a drum kit. The show also features more than just laughs, namely the amazing music and heartfelt episodes featuring Yuugiri's backstory to further signify its impact.

Overall, *Zombie Land Saga: Revenge* is a great success and a worthwhile watch. Thus, due to its depth and charm, it finishes at the top for this year.
nominees.staff:
MAPPA
Directed by Munehisa Sakai

nominees.writeup:
*Ijiranaide, Nagatoro-san* centers on Naoto Hachiouji, popularly known as “Senpai,” his relationship with the titular character, Hayase Nagatoro, and how she teases him while being secretly in love. The show is polarizing, though, due to its style of humor and plot development from the early stages. 
Nagatoro herself is a decent character, with good voice acting and character animation to highlight her personality. Yet, the base of her relationship with Naoto is contentious, as the line of her teasing being fun and toxic varies despite later developments on her character.
On the other hand, Naoto stands as the largest issue of the anime. His overall demeanor and reactions to Nagatoro's teasing make for a predictable and uncomfortable experience, diminishing its potential. It is particularly frustrating when there are hints of their relationship progressing, all for it to be reset by Nagatoro accusing Naoto of being a pervert instead of changing the formula. However, in the final arc Nagatoro is upfront about helping her senior to compete against the art club's president, with the hints of Naoto and Nagatoro getting slowly closer to each other becoming clearer, thus making for more pleasant interactions than the usual teasing.
In the end, the relationship of the main duo and nature of humor overshadows most of the show. However, it is appreciated that there is development in their relationship to various degrees, as well as the good use of the medium for a successful adaptation, which ultimately lands the show in sixth place.
nominees.staff:
Telecom Animation Film
Directed by Hirokazu Hanai

nominees.writeup:
The r/anime Awards is quite familiar with *Kaguya-sama*, as it was the winner in this category for the past two years. The OVA is more of what the audience already loves about the series, so expect good quality production and the highest grade of jokes.

The first half differs in tone than previous seasons with its prevalent sexual themes. It parodies the fan service culture that many other shows have, and to do that it properly uses the cast to set up great jokes. There is even a moment where the OVA goes back and forth, between Ishigami and Shirogane reading a manga and Chika and Kaguya taking a shower, that is used to joke on anime censoring and is well done with its great comedic timing. However, reception to this part may be mixed due to the jokes being made, given the premise and its themes.

Conversely, the latter half is one big skit that foregoes the sexual themes and returns to what *Kaguya-sama* is best at. Character interactions are excellent, and the jokes land easily. There is one specific joke with Chika that is rather lengthy and repeated, though it does not interfere other scenes from being funny and enjoyable.

While the *Kaguya-sama OVA* has many aspects fans know and love about the series, other nominees stand stronger this year, earning it a fifth place.
nominees.staff:
A-1 Pictures
Directed by Shinichi Omata

nominees.writeup:
Komi can't communicate, but her show can have some of the best production values of 2021. The smooth animations, effective framing, and complementing OST all help this show standout from other rom-coms. Moreover, the voice actors perform splendidly with such an expansive cast, as each character has a voice that perfectly matches their identity.

However, the cast and its interactions feels lacking at times. The main trio receives most of the attention and ends up being an excellent part of the show, but the secondary characters feel one dimensional and flat. Such interactions with them often were for one-off jokes, of which tend to be rather lengthy. Additionally, character progression is largely minimal throughout the show, even for the main characters.

Furthermore, many of the jokes that worked well in the manga did not translate as nicely to the anime. They often feel “ported” rather than adapted to fit more appropriately. Signs, arrows, and other manga expressions are effective, but as an anime it does not use enough continuous movement and sound to convey the jokes more properly.

*Komi-san* is a decent anime overall, though the flaws of character shallowness, minimal character progression, and ineffective adapted scenes lead to its seventh placement.
nominees.staff:
OLM
Directed by Kazuki Kawagoe

awards.name: Drama
awards.blurb:
As usual, the Drama genre gave audiences so much variety in 2021. This year brought informative historical dramas, exciting sports shows, relatable coming-of-age stories, and conclusive finale films to well-known series. From an initial list of 33 primary allocations and 45 secondary allocations, widely ranging themes and styles made nomination selections difficult.  
 
Some unique series such as *Kageki Shoujo* and *Cardfight!! Vanguard: overDress* had a few strong supporters, but ultimately failed to make the cut due to tough competition. In general, shows that were more successful in executing the core themes they attempted to present received nominations. The list of nominations included shows that the jury felt stood out in terms of storytelling, characterization, production value, and bringing something special to the medium. 
 
Unlike last year’s drama awards with *Chihayafuru 3,* there was no clear favorite among the jurors for the top spot. Every entry garnered support and criticism, and the process brought about a lot of interesting discussion. How important is an ending? How relevant is historical accuracy, and how much freedom of interpretation is allowed? Do cliches negatively impact a story? All of these discussions fed into the decisions made for the final jury rankings.

nominees.writeup:
*Uma Musume: Pretty Derby Season 2* manages to completely blow its predecessor out of the water with a gripping and emotional tale that captivates the emotions of the audience. Featuring compelling and fun characters, their rivalries and friendships shine through as the story explores what racing means to each of them. These bonds between the characters work well to get the audience invested in seeing them succeed. The individual trials they face are novel, such as the pressure athletes deal with when placed in adversarial roles or the fallout injuries can have on a promising career. The heart and emotions are well explored in each of these situations leading to strong emotional payoffs at the end of these trails.

Uma Musume manages to take inspiration from real life horse racing events and create a loving, respectful tribute to the sport with the additional flourish of emotionally resonant storytelling. That said, it's not without its flaws. The world-building is a bit nonsensical and challenging to make sense of. The production is generally strong but the races can occasionally suffer from dull and lackluster visuals. The series is also reliant on the viewer's penchant for its absurd premise. Despite its faults, *Uma Musume: Pretty Derby Season 2* was able to shine brightly with its heartwarming and powerful tale.
nominees.staff:
Studio Kai



Directed by Kei Oikawa

nominees.writeup:
*Heike Monogatari* is a modern adaptation of a Japanese classic about the tragic fall of the titular Heike. Characteristic of director Naoko Yamada's style, it utilizes gorgeous cinematography and flowery metaphors to bring the powerful emotions and themes, especially the buddhist understanding of impermanence, to the forefront. Between the Heike's struggle for power and the art of Shirabyoshi courtesans, *Heike Monogatari* beautifully captures an image of courtly life in the late Heian period. 

Despite its cinematic strengths, *Heike Monogatari* struggles to make its vast cast individually relatable. The script moves too quickly from one event to the next, and doesn't leave enough room for everyone to have a compelling arc. The story occasionally requires familiarity with the historical setting for aspects of the characterization to resonate, even leading to confusion about the power and allegiances of characters. Similar character names and designs also contribute to this confusion. Biwa is a controversial protagonist lacking agency for the majority of the story, but is crucial for the thematic and emotional framing of the whole work. Lastly, the OST's usage of modern elements like EDM and rock music hampers the tone of the series set by high quality visuals.

Altogether, *Heike Monogatari* remains a beautiful tragedy, delivering on powerful and complex themes of impermanence of existence, intergenerational injustice, and religious salvation. It's placement as fifth is a testament to the strength of the Drama entries this year.
nominees.staff:
Science Saru



Directed by Naoko Yamada

nominees.altname: Wonder Egg Priority + Wonder Egg Priority: Tokubetsu-hen
nominees.writeup:
The beginning of *Wonder Egg Priority* is truly excellent, offering some of the best production of the year alongside an engaging plot that tactfully addresses serious but rarely discussed topics. Suicide, self-harm, and trauma are touchy subjects and often mishandled, but early on *Wonder Egg Priority* tackles the subject with poise and nuance. This is largely due to the cast, which is wonderfully constructed with realistic dynamics and a core message of overcoming trauma through solidarity and personal bonds.
Unfortunately, cracks start to show in the ending. The science fiction elements feel very half-baked in a story more magical and personal than anything else, and introducing a major plot thread so late in the narrative left little time to resolve it. Indeed, this thread is left unresolved, stranding audiences on the unlikely hope for a sequel. The last episodes do offer legitimate resolutions to the immediate arcs of the main girls. The finale in particular delves heavily into Ai, not only closing her initial arc, but introducing a conflict that would shape a second season deftly intertwined with the evolution of her character.
Even if the story can be criticized, *Wonder Egg Priority* is a legitimately fantastic production. Sound design is somewhat hit-or-miss, with the mixing being very off at times, but the OST itself is filled to the brim with excellent and varied tracks. The visual production is superb, offering equal parts vivacious character animation and visually stunning high-action sakuga set pieces, in combination with standout cinematography - featuring superb choreography, meaningful framing, and stellar editing.
nominees.staff:
CloverWorks



Directed by Shin Wakabayashi

nominees.writeup:
On paper, a story about art and introspection could have been the least interesting premise. *Blue Period* challenges this notion by not only championing the relatable growth of Yatora Yaguchi, but also by celebrating a colorful cast of artists in a more approachable art world.

Yatora carries this openness to the art world with his mind bare to the audience, allowing the viewers to contemplate the dread of uncertainty and the joys of pursuing a passion alongside him. It is a story of personal development, from simply going with the flow to daring to march in time with the beat of his own heart. This is exhibited in his art pieces, which encapsulate a living presence. Unfortunately, Yatora's vibrantartwork is an awkward juxtaposition against otherwise bland visuals of the show.  For an anime focusing on art, it is an ironic weakness to see such flat motion and lackluster composition.

Fortunately, its strength in character writing extends to create a lively cast. Supporting characters not only complement Yatora's story but carry a sense of depth and individuality despite their short time on screen. They are portrayed as real humans with struggles, like Ryuji, who grapples with their identity. That vulnerability in turn invites the audience to relate to each of the characters. 

*Blue Period's* strong narrative and complex characters allow the series to truly excel as a coming of age story with prominent themes of self-discovery, introspection, and personal development.
nominees.staff:
Seven Arcs



Directed by Kouji Masunari and Katsuya Asano

nominees.writeup:
Nobody expected a second season from *Megalo Box*, not even its staff. Nonetheless, *Nomad: Megalo Box 2* surprises viewers with a timeskip that sent our champion Joe on a more personal journey focused on redemption and the importance of having a place to call home. The focus shifts out of the ring and onto Joe's interpersonal relationships, fleshing out his character in a manner sorely missed in season one. 

*Nomad* excels at introducing nuance to its characters and themes. The plot carefully handles complex and contemporary issues ranging from racism to corporate tech giants. Joe and the rest of the cast navigate these gray areas with a variety of perspectives and experiences befitting of their sensitivity. Through these intricate conflicts, *Nomad* showcases the strength of its cast and storytelling. It was awe-inspiring to see how *Nomad* intertwines the stories of Joe, Chief, and Mac, while commenting on larger ethical dilemmas. The only knock against the series' stellar narrative is that it stretches itself too thin at times, trying to cover too many conflicts in 13 episodes. Even so, *Nomad* wraps up Joe's story again in a way that is just as satisfying as his season one triumph. 

*Nomad* succeeds in pivoting from an action-heavy sports story into a character-driven drama, improving on the weaknesses of its first season. The production distinguishes itself even among the other diverse nominees, utilizing nostalgic visuals and songs sung in Spanish. This sequel is the complete package and a deserving champion of drama anime in 2021.
nominees.staff:
TMS Entertainment



Directed by You Moriyama

nominees.writeup:
*Beastars 2* is the much-anticipated sequel to 2019's Best Drama winner, and with many arcs and mysteries left unresolved, was well-positioned to repeat many of its predecessors' strengths seamlessly. The series captivates viewers just as much the second time around with its innovative 3D animation, world-building, and lead characters.
That being said, many of the deviations from the first season don't quite reach the same heights. Beastars' strong supporting cast is pushed to the side as the plot moves away from Cherryton Academy, leaving beloved characters like Juno and Haru underutilized. The arcs of Louis and Legoshi develop in enjoyable but absurd ways that stretch beyond the believable, leading up to a finale that is a bridge too far for many.
It is a testament to Beastars' world-building that its ambitious social commentary is seamlessly integrated into the show through the lens of carnivore-herbivore relationships. With the show so rich in themes, it is praiseworthy how the development of its politics never feels labored. This skilful interweaving of narrative and theme is best exemplified by Louis and Legoshi's navigation of ‘human' nature, and the parallels between them, producing a well-developed and captivating friendship.
nominees.staff:
Orange



Directed by Shinichi Matsumi

nominees.writeup:
*Shin Evangelion Movie :||* is undoubtedly one of the best the franchise has to offer. With unrivaled quality in numerous aspects, it gives Evangelion the send-off it deserves as one of the most defining anime ever made. 

The overall aesthetic of the film is perfect. Iconic shots are just as grandiose and awe-inspiring as they are intimate and warm. Varying color values and hues create atmospheric perspective and intensify emotional impact. The typefacing also gives this film a memorable quality that is immediately defining. Topping it all with a great ending song, the look and feel screams Evangelion through and through.

Stellar artistry is complimented by an equally stellar plot, especially in its beginning and ending. A calming section at the start captured the cast's intimate and human moments. It provides a much needed grounding for the characters in Evangelion. The final segment of the film is truly next-level. It gives long-awaited closure to Shinji's development, as well as the people around him. The symbolism and meta abstraction throughout is not done pretentiously, but in a rather innovative and clever way. However, while the two ends of the story are great, the middle action sequence drags on for too long, featuring confusing and nonsensical sci-fi jargon.
nominees.staff:
Studio Khara



Directed by Hideaki Anno

nominees.writeup:
The *Violet Evergarden Movie* is an enjoyable film with outstanding production values and some tear-jerking moments, but as a whole it felt like an unfitting end to the series. Communication as a core theme from the Violet Evergarden series continues to be a focus of the film, with memorable moments of letter-writing and heart-to-heart conversation. Scenes with Violet's client, Yuris, were far and away the best moments, and brought many people to tears. As can be expected from Kyoto Animation, top notch visuals and OST are major highlights of the film.

The inclusion of numerous story elements served to undermine the main Violet Evergarden series, in addition to unnecessarily prolonging the film. The most condemning of which was that the major twist came across as hollow, completely unnecessary to most, and detracted from Violet's overall character growth. While the execution of the twist was fine, its ramifications were controversial at best, despite the end result tugging at the heartstrings. The movie also felt too long, and some scenes could have been easily cut without losing much, especially those involving Anne's granddaughter, who didn't add much to the film.

The *Violet Evergarden Movie* has some incredible standout moments, but their integration into the main story could have been executed better. Kyoto Animation's final Violet Evergarden work brings an imperfect, yet enjoyable, conclusion to Violet's story.

Kyoto Animation


Directed by Taichi Ishidate

awards.name: Romance
awards.blurb:
As tends to be the case, the anime released in 2021 that have a romance focus are few compared to other categories. As such it is far from uncommon for shows with romance as a secondary focus to be considered for best of the year. This year was no different, with shows like *Tsuki to Laika to Nosferatu* or *Kanojo mo Kanojo* being viewed positively and getting rather close to being nominated, and Mewkledreamy actually making the cut. 
 
On the other hand, this year was rather rich with movies focusing around romantic development with entries such as *Kimi wa Kanata* or *Cider no You ni Kotoba ga Wakiagaru* both being on the table, not to mention the nominated *Josee to Tora to Sakanatachi* and *Omoi, Omoware, Furi, Furare*. 
 
At the end of the day the selection may have been rather narrow, but the discussion certainly did not reflect the limited field as once more the romance category had a record breaking number of messages, discussing each option in-depth. This includes entries that didn’t make the cut such as *Taishou Otome Otogibanashi* and the *Given Movie*. Do not be fooled by the ranking though, the competition was fierce and aside from first place, each entry was a strong competitor with the entries around it.

nominees.writeup:
*Omoi, Omoware, Furi, Furare* dives deeply into the hardships people face in relationships, through the exploration of four high school students' romantic woes. The main characters experience and learn to live with love and rejection, in the hopes of learning how to find a little more happiness.



The story introduces a haphazard love square featuring the childhood friends of Yuna and Kazuomi, who meet newly-related step siblings Akari and Rio. Akari and Yuna quickly strike up a friendship, and their increasing involvement in the other's lives lead to sparks flying with their respective pairing. The film strongly focuses on overcoming existing trauma on Akari and Rio's part, while Yuna (and to a lesser extent Kazuomi) is used to help Akari and Rio deal with their own feelings of rejection. An incestuous relationship is handled excellently with dignity and maturity, and the importance of communication between partners is re-visited time and time again. Despite the impactful themes it explores, a shift in character focus results in a jarring transition mid-way through the film.



Of the nominees this year, *Omoi* excels when it comes to background art, cinematography, and OST. These production elements take character dynamics and a simplistic story concept to another level. The highly technical musical score introduces, carries, and responds to significant relational moments on screen, pairing melodic variation with the characters' inner voices.  Overall, the production quality does its best to elevate cliché developments, but *Omoi* ends up falling short of greatness.
nominees.staff:
A-1 Pictures



Toshimasa Kuroyanagi

nominees.writeup:
*Mewkledreamy* is a mainly comedy focused show that follows Yume and her friends through her first year of middle school. After a talking stuffed animal falls from the sky into her arms she gains the ability to enter people's dreams.



This magical girl aspect is when the show is at its weakest though. While the exploration of characters through their dreams does help flesh out the personality of each feature character, the resolution to each episode is always the same and rarely satisfying. Also, the fact that only Yume is allowed to enter people's dreams severely limits character interactions and makes the rest of the cast feel unimportant.



Despite this, *Mewkledreamy* manages to mostly successfully juggle its large cast of characters. Maira is utilized well as a vehicle for a lot of the show's comedy and much of the romance in the show revolves around Asahi, whom the show explores a lot through his interactions with Haruto, Rei, and Yume. However, other characters (Kotoko and Tokiwa for example) aren't explored as well. Yume isn't very complex on her own, but she shines through her relationships with the rest of the cast. In fact, the chemistry of the cast is one of the strong points of the show.



This chemistry fuels the show's greatest strength, comedy. It's particularly adept at using animation for visual gags, and although Maira's puns can be difficult to translate they allow her charming characterization to shine through.
nominees.staff:
J.C. Staff



Directed by Hiroaki Sakurai

nominees.writeup:
*Shinigami Bocchan to Kuro Maid* (Bocchan) excels at many things from the OST to worldbuilding to the emotions and the comedy. It's an impressive feat especially considering the incorporation of 3DCG and its strengths. *Bocchan* successfully uses 3DCG to provide us with intricate visual-comedy, camera direction, and imagery that compete on the levels of other nominees using the tried and tested 2D art style. 



However, the main strength of *Bocchan* lies in the portrayal of the relationships each character has with the Duke and with each other. The Duke's relationship with Alice, friends, and even his family are all endearing journeys of growth and development that are rare to find. A particularly charming motif throughout the show is the constant teasing from Alice, much to the embarrassment of the Duke. Not only does this help to characterize and build a rapport between the main couple, but it also retains narrative significance with regard to the Duke's curse. It doubles down as wholesome fan-service for the audience while also setting the baseline level of intimacy for their relationship which then evolves throughout the show to become more than just playfulness but genuine attraction between each other and a method of communicating romantic feelings.



As they journey together to break the curse, the friendships and bonds formed ease the struggles the Duke is bound by and provide us with a poetic show that makes us feel bubbly but also empathetic at times. An amazing show that caught us all by surprise and thus, 2021's Romance of the Year.
nominees.staff:
J.C. Staff



Yoshiki Yamakawa

nominees.writeup:
*Josee to Tora to Sakana-tachi* is an adaptation of the late Seiko Tanabe's award winning 1985 short story by the same name, and provides an endearing and uplifting story about never letting anything stand in the way of your dreams and aspirations.



The movie's greatest strength is its main romantic couple, Tsuneo and Josee. Though they start off on rocky footing, they are able to slowly connect. Tsuneo is able to bring Josee out of her shell, and motivates her to pursue her dreams of being an artist. The chemistry established between the two leads was endearing, leading to cheers for their success throughout the film. Though the transition between the first and second half (with a plot event that was seen as rather contrived) felt lacking, the plot and characters of the film were still heavily praised.



This movie was hailed as visually exceptional, especially when it came to compositing and character designs. Evan Call's contribution on OST was also well received. Overall, this movie had a great combination of production and story, which is why *Josee to Tora to Sakana-tachi* is the second best Romance of 2021.
nominees.staff:
Bones



Directed by Koutarou Tamura

nominees.writeup:
*Senpai ga Uzai Kouhai no Hanashi* is an anime about an adult who just desperately wants to be treated as one.  Throughout the show Futaba is constantly confused for being a child, and it's no wonder considering she looks and often acts like one.  However, her actions and feelings will certainly remind you of what it felt like to enter the workforce for the first time, and this is a major strength of the show.  Underneath the hijinks, it does a remarkable job being a relatable story of how it felt to be new at a job, or living on your own for the first time.  Because when you are on your own, simple things feel impossible and you feel like you appear to people as a 5 year old.  Watching Futaba overcome this, and eventually be seen as a reliable worker and an adult by the titular senpai is one of the most compelling character arcs in the category.



The side characters also stand out, particularly Kazama and Sakurai.  The main couple in the show didn't really have the typical romantic relationship, so having another couple fill that void was definitely needed and appreciated.  While the story beats are familiar and the dynamic rather simple and predictable, it was executed very well, and the characters had clear chemistry.



Ultimately Senpai was one of the best romances of the year and was a worthy inclusion in the category.
nominees.staff:
Doga Kobo



Directed by Ryouta Itou

nominees.writeup:
*5-Toubun no Hanayome's* second season is a vast improvement over the previous one in essentially every domain. Its new production feels like a breath of fresh air compared to season one, with its character design shining very bright. Plot-wise, the show takes a dramatic turn, making it more engaging than ever.



Despite its much more colorful palette, *5-toubun ∬* takes a much more dramatic approach to its story. The show's greatest strength is still the interactions between the sisters, but they're not executed in the same way as before. The idyllic, peaceful interactions of Season 1—while not completely gone—are now less prevalent. We're left instead with a plot much more focused on drama, conflict, and scheming. While this new direction might upset some viewers, for many it served to deliver a much more engaging and gripping product.



This doesn't mean the show is without its faults. The focal point of this conflict, Fuutaro, is about as interesting as one can expect from a nerdy and arrogant highschooler: not at all. The sisters, while certainly better, aren't great characters in their own right either, and often feel like exaggerated harem stereotypes. The show's attempts at comedy weren't particularly successful either. This is partially due to the dramatic focus of the season, but also because most of the humor stems from the sisters playing into the tropes each of them fits in, which gets repetitive.



*5-toubun*'s stands out in a good way from the sea of generic harem anime. Despite its issues, it remains an enjoyable experience, especially when compared to its first season.
nominees.staff:
Bibury Animation Studios



Directed by Kaori

nominees.writeup:
*Fruits Basket the Final* is left with the unenviable task of concluding the twice-nominated reboot of the 2001 anime. With fifty episodes of getting to know these characters, it is no surprise that the emotional highs fit the occasion, and the show acts as a fantastic farewell to Tohru and friends.



Once again, Tohru is a compelling protagonist and is truly granted her moment to shine while navigating her relationship with the Sohmas. The show's large cast remains as vibrant as ever, with each character given opportunities to shine. While many of these arcs are romantic, the arcs remain both unique and distinct providing an excellent portrayal of many different varieties of love.



While the highs of the story cannot be disputed, the pacing leaves much to be desired. While Akito is a compelling antagonist, her arc was often intrusive on other character's arcs and came across as too cliché to feel either nuanced or fully developed. It is hard not to imagine that Momiji and Yuki's arcs could use this time far better. These issues meant that some elements were introduced too hastily, only hitting the emotional mark due to Fruits Basket's otherwise deft use of melodrama.



With so many moments building beautifully on the momentum of the previous seasons, it is a delight to watch, more than lives up to its predecessors, and earns its position as 4th best in Romance of the year.
nominees.staff:
TMS Entertainment



Directed by Yoshihide Ibata

nominees.writeup:
The story of an unusual relationship and the beginning of new friendships are key aspects of *Horimiya*. Popular girl Kyouko Hori and the kind, yet gloomy looking Izumi Miyamura are the main protagonists and the story revolves around them and their relationship.



The story about Hori and Miyamura is the strongest part of the show; it creates a nice dynamic between the two leads and sets up their relationship without feeling too artificial. It develops naturally and doesn't rely on tropes like dramatic confessions, which makes it feel comfortable and real. But the show's strength lies not only in the relationship between the two leads, but also the bonds they form with the friends and classmates they help along the way. The cast as a whole feels solid, with every character story resolved by the end of the show. However, *Horimiya*'s strengths don't stop there. The show generally shines in its production with particular praise being given to the character designs, both in terms of the animation-friendliness of the designs themselves as well as the delicate linework they see in practice thanks to supervision of seasoned designer, Haruko Iizuka. Despite this, some side characters come up a bit short in the overall story due to the accelerated adaptation. 



Overall, the show excels at portraying the development of a relationship without preconceptions about each other. It also presents a solid story about a couple spending their time together and creating a group of good friends.
nominees.staff:
CloverWorks



Directed by Masashi Ishihama

awards.name: Slice of Life
awards.blurb:
The Slice of Life genre is a beautiful melting pot filled to the brim with a diverse range of shows. Everyone can find at least one show to enjoy whether that’s one filled with growth and development, excellent cinematography and animation, or a relaxing “comfy” atmosphere. Slice of Life fans were treated to a variety of quality shows in 2021, giving us a wide pool of nominations to select from. Unfortunately, due to this plethora of nominations, some shows such as *ARIA The CREPUSCOLO* and *Love Live! Superstar!!* had to be cut despite them being very enjoyable. 
 
Every nomination was thoroughly discussed with such relentless vigor that no stone was left unturned. The final ranking was the result of deliberation over different aspects such as cast development, backgrounds and scenery, themes or messages, soundtrack, and humor. Many of these shows had a mix of supporters and opposers, but three shows stood out among the rest. *Non Non Biyori*, *Eiga Daisuki Pompo-San*, and *Yuru Camp Season 2* received some criticism, but this was outweighed by their nearly endless praise and vocal support; until the final vote was cast any of them could have taken first.

nominees.writeup:
*Majo Minarai wo Sagashite* finds excellence in its presentation of found friendship through media by exhibiting a wonderfully realistic take on adulthood, and how the series that we grow alongside can inform the connections and decisions we make later in life. 

It manages to execute this narrative all while still feeling like a love letter to its childish Mahou Shoujo parent series, *Ojamajo Doremi*, which it achieves mainly through its delightfully expressive animation. The film takes the bouncy motion, hyper-exaggerated reactions, and rounded character design of the original series, and modifies it to make it feel modern and aged-up, all while keeping the youthful energy that makes it feel distinctly "DoReMi".

However, that same association with Ojamajo feels somewhat tenuous within the narrative. The characters' connection to the series could've been replaced by any other interest and it still would've landed its thematic point.  This means that the connection doesn't feel directly necessary or meaningful to the story. Furthermore, the interaction with the original series's magical elements makes the film's more realistic drama sometimes feel out of place and tacky.

Nevertheless, the strength of the cast overshadows these small faults. Mire, Reika, and Sora are all charming leads in their own right. And while each fits into an established archetype, they all have decent nuance away from these roles to make them feel more balanced and whole. Yet, where they truly shine is their dynamic with each other and how, despite their differences, their mutual dissatisfaction with their lives draws them together in natural ways. Through this relationship, and its playful production, Majo Minarai's easy charm brings it to the top half of these rankings.
nominees.staff:
Toei Animation



Directed by Haruka Kamatani and Junichi Satou

nominees.writeup:
A movie about making a movie, *Eiga Daisuki Pompo-san* highlights the wonder and magic of filmmaking. The film features a strong cast, with Gene's dedication and love for movies shining through. The titular Pompo is another standout character, with her serving as a great mentor for Gene throughout the film, and providing unique and bold takes on the film industry. 

The film starts out strong, with character moments for Gene and Pompo that highlight the effort and passion needed to make a successful film. Gene and Pompo share a number of charming moments featuring their mentor-mentee relationship. However, the final third is notably weaker than the rest of the film. Individual scenes suffer from a variety of faults, from characters not suffering true consequences for their actions to scenes featuring over-the-top and outlandish ideas that end up breaking immersion. 

The film's greatest strength lies in visual production, most notably the exceptional cinematography and creative visuals. The editing sequences with Gene are the standout moments, with vibrant color schemes and a strong portrayal of the editing required. Other highlights include the creative and fun transitions, such as windshield wipers, as well as framing techniques around watching a scene in a theater. *Pompo*'s strengths are among the best the category has to offer, and is more than deserving of its second place finish.
nominees.staff:
Clap



Directed by Takayuki Hirao

nominees.writeup:
Barely missing the deadline of 2020, *D4DJ First Mix* is a series that deserves attention in 2021 as well. The series follows the DJ group of Happy Around. On their warming journey pursuing their newfound dream, their friendship bonds strengthen as well as their fun day-to-day activities.

What immediately stands out is that D4DJ is a full-3D CGI anime. While the series' technical use of the animation style is good and supports itself using 2D smear frames and sound effects, D4DJ's 3D animation still doesn't achieve the same appeal that 2D drawing does. 
The character interactions are fun and lively, but lack the depth required for compelling dramatic arcs. The character conflicts are often quickly resolved with one encouraging conversation before the concert, then they proceed perform like nothing bothered them  leading to an underwhelming experience.

The use of music and quality of concerts was also polarizing, with the music varying from charming to annoying; the ambient of concerts having repetitive settings and low quality crowds. The dance performances, however, were of higher quality, displaying better use of its CGI accompanied with good choreography.

Its cast and dramatic writing leave more to be desired, but it was overall a fun time with its silly humor and technical prowess with CGI. In what is a stacked year, *D4DJ First Mix* can proudly finish the race at 7th place.
nominees.staff:
Sanzigen



Directed by Seiji Mizushima

nominees.writeup:
Five years after the conclusion of the anime series about creating an anime series, Studio P.A. Works returns to the *Shirobako* franchise to make an anime movie about... making an anime movie!

As one might expect, the *Shirobako* movie maintains many of the original series's strengths – the memorable character designs like goth loli artist Ogasawara Rinko, strongly defined personalities like the well-meaning layabout Takahashi Tarou, and lovable character dynamics like that of the Don-Don-Donuts 5 all returning to make the movie entertaining and lighthearted.

However, this ties into the entry's primary weakness: being excessively similar to the original series. While its expected for a sequel to pay homage to the successful original, the Shirobako movie at times feels like it's *only* a callback, perhaps best encapsulated in how vestigial the primary new cast addition of Kaede Miyaki feels to the affair. In addition, while the movie's plot is reminiscent of the original show's individual arcs, the movie's reduced runtime causes noticeable pacing issues.

That being said, *Shirobako* still captures the magic of making anime – from what's shown, the movie that MUSANI puts together looks genuinely interesting and fun – but in a category filled with strong competitors, its issues weigh down an ultimately still enjoyable affair from placing higher.
nominees.staff:
P.A. Works



Directed by Tsutomu Mizushima

nominees.writeup:
*Shiroi Suna no Aquatope* is a story of two halves. The first half of the show covers daily life within an aquarium and the second half focuses more on workplace drama within the same setting. There is no consensus on which of these two halves is better. The first half is more focused on the central two characters within a smaller setting. Meanwhile, the increased number of dramatic moments in the second half create a more interesting story with new character developments. The common aquarium setting helps the show stand out and show how passionate the characters are towards aquatic life. The heart and soul of the show, however, lies with the strong bonds between the main characters, Kukuru and Fuuka.

However, one major problem is the side characters, who, considering their screentime,  aren't developed. None of them are bad characters but most aren't fleshed out. The jarring transition between the two halves is another problem, the conflicts from the first half are irrelevant in the second half.

Despite these flaws, *Aquatope* still has much to offer. The production of the show is one standout feature; especially, the compositing, backgrounds, character designs, and beautiful use of color. Although *Aquatope's* weaker aspects hold it back from the top spots, the strengths of the show still shine like a pearl, a very deserving nomination.
nominees.staff:
P.A. Works



Directed by Toshiya Shinohara

nominees.writeup:
*Non Non Biyori*'s third and final season “Nonstop” keeps the main focus on its depiction of the passage of time and impermanence. It shows episodic stories without a clear timeline or connection of events while also making it clear that time is passing and youth is transitory, with their graduation looming closer. 

Hotaru, Komari, Natsumi and Renge are spending their time together and enjoying their youth in the countryside to their fullest. Seeing them playing and laughing together is heartwarming. The new characters, Shiori and Akane, are a great fit in the cast and give the group an opportunity to explore new friendships. They all grow together through new topics like overcoming shyness and being more comfortable around people.

The main cast still stands in the spotlight and continues to have excellent chemistry. They manage to accept and overcome their weaknesses together, showing that asking for help is completely normal. NNB also excels at creating fantastic comedic moments, like Renge playing Santa delivering tomatoes, keeping the show lighthearted.

The show creates a calm and relaxing atmosphere by adding in segments without talking, letting the art and sounds of nature speak for themselves. The fantastic background art and OST also plays an important role in achieving that calmness.

*Non Non Biyori: Nonstop* delivers fantastic Slice of Life moments with a high production quality creating an idyllic depiction of living in the country and enjoying youth. This makes for a phenomenal finale to the series and secured it the first place.
nominees.staff:
Silver Link



Directed by Shinya Kawatsura

nominees.writeup:
*Yuru Camp Season 2* immediately dispels any concerns that it wouldn't meet the lofty expectations set by its 2018 predecessor. The leads, Rin and Nadeshiko, are strong characters on their own, and the premise of “cute girls doing camping things” keeps everything as low-stakes as possible. While this gives the two girls a chance to explore their individuality in a setting devoid of drama, their heartwarming bond and natural chemistry is what's truly noteworthy. It's compelling, and honestly it's just fun. When paired with production values that emphasize realistic background art and lighting—showing off the natural beauty of Japan—and a dynamic and well-utilized OST, this season of Yuru Camp continues radiating the same feeling of “comf” that the series initially became known for.

Unfortunately, "comfiness" in and of itself cannot be used to measure quality, and there are some weaker aspects of Yuru Camp. Relative to other characters, Ena, Chiaki and Aoi lack depth, and segments that place them at the forefront are sometimes underwhelming. Compositing is another weakness, with several instances of characters jarringly standing out against the background art, breaking immersion and detracting from the experience.
However, these flaws do not seriously hold Yuru Camp back. Its strong depictions of nature, camping and friendship, as well as its appealing tone and atmosphere, outweigh its shortcomings. Ultimately, this season is easy to love, which is why it finds itself in a very solid and hard-fought for third place, amid what can only be described as stacked competition.
nominees.staff:
C-Station



Directed by Yoshiaki Kyougoku

nominees.writeup:
The surprisingly wholesome *Kobayashi-san Chi no Maidragon S* (Maidragon) returns to its balancing act of gentle slice-of-life, character drama, and humor. All of this is packaged with both outstanding character animation and action sequences, making Maidragon one of our most visually appealing nominees.

Some of the main weaknesses of the show were due to its comedy lacking in variety. Ilulu, for example, is a fantastic character whose arc is often interrupted by repetitive breast jokes.
