Kanna and Kobayashi's relationship delivers good slice-of-life moments, but their moments together are often intruded upon by Saikawa,whose character feels one-note and lacking in novelty value.

Yet, the slice-of-life and drama were performed admirably. Shota and Lucoa find opportunities to develop independently of one another. Kanna, too, finds some independence by traveling overseas. Elma and Tooru's backstory provides impressive character-driven drama. With these dramatic moments and stories interspersed with classic slice-of-life, it is hard not to find the show compelling, even if it struggles to find the balance between its parts.

As with the previous series, the show was held together by the enjoyable (and incredibly shippable) dynamic between Tooru and Kobayashi. By the end of the series, Tooru is a much more mature and independent lead, and her antics remain an utter joy to watch. Earning a well deserved 5th best Slice of Life of the year.
nominees.staff:
Kyoto Animation



Directed by Yasuhiro Takemoto and Tatsuya Ishihara

awards.name: Suspense
awards.blurb:
Taking over from the awkwardly named “Thriller/Mystery” category of years past, our nominees for the Suspense category truly run the anime gamut. From adaptations of sequels to hyped, established franchises like *Shingeki no Kyojin* and *Re:Zero Kara Hajimeru Isekai Seikatsu*, to passionate, inspired originals like *Vivy: Fluorite Eye’s Song* and *Sonny Boy*, it’s hard to find a category that fills as many niches and covers as much subject matter as Suspense. 
 
Eligible shows in the category this year faced a grueling battle royale for final nomination positions. Notable entries which didn’t make the cut included the second season of Production I.G.’s adaptation of *Yuukoku no Moriarty*, a reimagining of the Sherlock Holmes mythos, and *Bishounen Tanteidan* from the anime power pairing of studio Shaft+auteur NISIOISIN (responsible for the mega-hit *Monogatari* series and 2017 Thriller/Mystery winner *Kubikiri Cycle*). The exclusion of standalone marvels such as these shows puts into perspective the final nominees as the cream of this year’s crop. 
 
As might be expected from a category with such a wide range of subject matters and themes, opinions were equally widely ranging on many of the nominated shows. Discussions ultimately reached a similar conclusion on the contenders for first place - a triple threat of originals in *Sonny Boy*, *Cocolors*, and *Odd Taxi* - with vocal support for all three. True to the category, the question of who would come out on top remained unanswered until the final vote was cast.

nominees.writeup:
*Cocolors* accomplishes in a 45 minute film what most shows fail to achieve in a single cour. The 3D animation manages to balance the yellows, reds, blacks, and grays of the setting against the colorful imaginations of the main characters. Each shot evokes a sense of eerie emptiness through its incredibly detailed backgrounds and unique character designs, while still feeling beautiful. Unfortunately, some of the voice actors do sound inexperienced at times, and the OST, while fitting, doesn't stand with the rest of the production. Still, the production manages to stand out among even the best shows this year.

*Cocolors'* main conflict and character development puts this fantastic production to full use. Although some conflicts near the beginning are a bit over-dramatized, Aki and Fuyu's dynamic is awe-inspiring and the crux of the film. Aki's knowledge of the outside world as a member of the salvage unit contrasts perfectly with Fuyu's hopeful and innocent mind. The way their characterization grows and shifts in conjunction with one another, learning about and coming to terms with their bleak world is intensely emotional and strangely cathartic. The world, shrouded in mystery, serves its purpose in facilitating these characters, while also feeling grand beyond the scope of what is shown. *Cocolors* is a fantastic movie that despite its short length and lack of popularity manages to stand with the best stories in this medium.
nominees.staff:
Kamikaze Douga



Directed by Toshihisa Yokoshima

nominees.writeup:
*Mars Red* is a theatrical adaptation that revels in vampirism and Taisho era culture. Its theatrical aesthetic and narrative are strongly grounded in reality, as characters bask in solemnity. *Mars Red's* level of craftsmanship helps the show come together with flying colors, with cinematic techniques utilized in a way that emulates the feeling of watching a live theater performance. It plays with shot compositions and aspect ratios to convey its thespian visual storytelling through the eyes of the characters. 

Where *Mars Red* displays its strength in visual direction, it unfortunately suffers in sticking with a consistent narrative flow and portraying adequate characterization. *Mars Red* often likes to not only shift its focus from the central perspectives of its plot, but also from character to character. The askew point of view and narrative discrepancies are unfocused and rather messy, and this ultimately hurts the flow of the show

Above all else, *Mars Red* is a great show with faults. The high level craftsmanship of its visual direction and theatrical nature were enough to hold its ground and remain in an impressive eighth place.
nominees.staff:
Signal MD



Directed by Shinya Sadamitsu and Kouhei Hatano

nominees.writeup:
*Shadows House* is a unique show that manages to mix intriguing mystery plots and relaxing slice of life moments in one go. Set in the Victorian era, the show provides well-crafted stories mixed with high society politics and fantasy elements. These points become even stronger with the inclusion of fantastic visual storytelling, resulting in a captivating show with an immersive atmosphere.

*Shadows House* places its cast at the heart of the show. Cast dynamics are widely varied using the show's fantasy elements, placing an emphasis on the dichotomy of its characters in accordance with the show's continual motifs pertaining to distinct contrasts in the story. As a result, some of the characters are quite quirky and use some extreme tropes. While the utilization of the tropes help slice of life moments, they might fall flat or feel immersion breaking for some.

A mystery story with horror elements can't be carried by its script alone, and *Shadows House* is aware of this. Background art supports the atmosphere of the show, building an immersive experience. The soundtrack feels authentic for the period style and fits the themes of the show. Animation as a whole throughout the show is given less care, due to the focus provided on other production elements, leading to inconsistencies in quality throughout the show.  

From the influence of story elements, the cast and their dynamics, to the production of the show, *Shadows House* lands in fifth place.
nominees.staff:
CloverWorks



Directed by Kazuki Oohashi

nominees.writeup:
Shingo Natsume's *Sonny Boy* is an abstract and transcendent ode to the struggles of youth, a fantastic passion project that asks questions and expects no answer. Deliberately hallucinogenic and nonlinear, *Sonny Boy's* narrative is nothing short of fascinating. It revels in its abstraction, and in turn births one of the most resplendent and thought-provoking original anime in recent memory.

The main aversions with *Sonny Boy* relate to its structure. *Sonny Boy* is so complex that heads are often scratched and questions are left unclear, unanswered. Its lack of a connecting storyline and relentless pursuit of nonlinearity, while wholly creative, dissuades viewers unwilling to engage with its abstraction.

Phenomenal production and usage of visual direction more than compensates for the awkward narrative progression, strengthening the philosophical nature of the show. Every surrealist background creates a beautiful grandiose landscape, and Hisashi Eguchi's fantastically crafted designs serve both a simplistic yet incredibly effective narrative and aesthetic purpose. 

*Sonny Boy* is not for everyone, but it is the most thought-provoking and surreal original product to come out of 2021, and one to be appreciated for a long time. Its unbelievably crafted abstraction and hallucinatory visuals were more than enough to propel it into the top prize.
nominees.staff:
Madhouse



Directed by Shingo Natsume

nominees.writeup:
While the sci-fi concepts explored in *Vivy: Flourite Eye's Song* may not enthuse the uninitiated, the show works at an emotional level. Vivy is an AI whose sole purpose is to make people happy with her singing. Vivy becoming Diva and discovering more about herself is the basic premise of the show.

Throughout the story, the show attempts to forge an emotional connection with Vivy, witnessing events unfold with the use of time travel. Stakes rise with every 'mission', and Vivy's state of mind remains quite clear despite the challenges she faces. This keeps us invested in her story as our respect for her struggle grows with every passing episode. However, when scrutinized, the story features plot holes and lacks novelty. The songs too were mostly underwhelming. Despite this *Vivy* sweeps you off your feet when taken at face value, and these flaws are easily forgivable under less scrutiny.

Side characters have decent backstories and seamlessly find their place in the narrative. No side character overstays their welcome except when the show wants to make a point about the emotional gravity of the character's mission. *Vivy* also boasts some excellent animation, with fight sequences becoming more impressive throughout the show. Matsumoto and Vivy have a no-nonsense chemistry with each other, led by a script filled with energetic and fast-paced voice acting delivery.

As a whole *Vivy* offers a flavorful viewing experience, but its lack of critical coherency results in a seventh place position.
nominees.staff:
Wit Studio



Directed by Shinpei Ezaki

nominees.writeup:
Re:Zero has always been one of the strongest candidates in the isekai genre when it comes to world building and the latest cour in the series is no different. The story truly shines when it gives as an intimate look on Emilia's past and how it gave birth to her indecisive nature and lack of self belief. Her journey of growth as a character is one of the biggest highlights for the entire cour. The exploration of the side cast through their individual arcs give a much needed insight on characters like Garfield, Beatrice and Roswaal not only making the story more intriguing but also solidifying the cast of Re:Zero as one of the best there is on offer. On the other hand, Roswaal makes for an intriguing antagonist but his existence often feels neglected to being a source of exposition and monologue for Subaru, rather than actually participating in the story leading to the resolving of his arc being somewhat anticlimactic. 

With that being said, *Re:Zero 2nd Season Part 2* also comes with its own fair share of problems. While the flashbacks were a much needed addition to the story they at times harmed the pacing of the show by overstaying their welcome. *Re:Zero 2nd Season Part 2* also had subpar production quality compared to *Re:Zero 2nd Season* part one, where the heavy usage of jump cuts, motion tweens and off-model character designs regrettably draw attention to themselves thus ending up at 6th place in the jury rankings.
nominees.staff:
White Fox



Directed by Masaharu Watanabe

nominees.altname: Shingeki no Kyojin: The Final Season Part 1
nominees.writeup:
The story of *Shingeki no Kyojin* continues with the first part of its final season, exploring the cycle of hatred and how it affects those that are involved. The first arc of the season held the most impact, with a new cast of characters and exciting reveals. The ideologies of the cast are expanded on from earlier seasons, and antagonists have depth added to their characters in the process. Compelling action sequences host moments of insight into the broader world of the Titans, and draw the viewer into this continuation of the story. 

The second part of the season is not as nearly as memorable or engaging as the first part. Although the detailed political aspects of this part provoke intriguing conversation, it is bogged down by a much slower pace and new characters that fail to leave an impact. 

The production value of this season also felt weaker than its predecessors, particularly in its use of 3D animation, compositing, and coloring. The OST provokes little more than ambivalence, with the works of the show's new composer feeling lackluster in comparison to the OSTs of prior seasons. 

When this season of *Shingeki no Kyojin* hits its mark, it's a gripping ride, but unfortunately the weaker elements of the season made it difficult for the jury to place it higher than fourth in the rankings.
nominees.staff:
MAPPA



Directed by Yuuichirou Hayashi

nominees.writeup:
*Odd Taxi* is a fantastic show with themes about delusion, escapism, and identity, all composed in a crime-centric mystery thriller. It features witty, natural, and dynamic dialogue with Odokawa as the star of the show. His extremely blunt and eccentric personality, combined with a dry sense of humor paves the way for this odd taxi driver to strike up interesting conversations with a diverse range of unique passengers, getting himself tangled up in a mystery. The excellent supporting characters, each with their own distinctive personality and flaws, make for an amazing cast that is full of variety. 

The underlying mystery of the show is exceptionally well written. In *Odd Taxi*, you are never truly sure which characters you can trust. The atmosphere goes from exceptionally goofy to extremely tense depending on the scene, and it makes for a varied, odd, and phenomenal environment with a great supporting soundtrack. Criticisms of the show relate to the visual production, namely the CGI being horrendous, backgrounds being rather bland, and sometimes, wonky character designs. The atmosphere was amazing, the soundtrack and voice acting was top notch, and the dialogue was exceptionally witty. With that being said, *Odd Taxi* takes home the number two spot on the list.
nominees.staff:
OLM



Directed by Baku Kinoshita

sections.name: Character
sections.blurb: These awards are given to the characters with exceptional writing among both dramatic and comedic roles, as well as memorable antagonists and casts.

awards.name: Main Dramatic
awards.blurb:
Main Dramatic’s characters came with a collective theme of rejection and growth, of moving forward and claiming agency. This year, we didn’t choose a line-up of heroes. The vulnerabilities and weaknesses on display highlighted what the medium can do in terms of creating affecting and realistic characters. 
 
Famously weak and vulnerable for decades, Shinji left both those qualities behind at last. The jury appreciated Shinji’s maturity as the vector for the (actual) end of *Evangelion*. Ai sought maturity too, which sparked a ton of jury discussion and interpretation befitting *WEP*’s ambiguity. Yatora surprised everyone by sneaking into the nominations on the back of a very well-executed, standard character drama, placing highly on many lists. Joe’s arc of reconciliation, perspective, and pride featured several metaphorical and literal gut punches, and impressed many. 
 
Odokawa and Rudy were widely recognized and appreciated for their unique perspectives, but there were some complaints surrounding aspects of their characters. Eren, jaded and world-weary, made some interesting character choices, but he barely featured in this season. Vivy’s character journey was muddled by her split personality, but the bonds she formed were highlights. 
 
However, as a whole, our entire cast of nominees could have easily been swapped for 20 other dramatic leads, such was the depth of our pool of candidates this year. We respectfully mention Teio, Biwa, Nagara, Kukuru, Gene, Kotaro, Lena and so, *so* many others. There were a lot of hard choices made this year, and not just by the characters.

nominees.writeup:
Yatora Yaguchi is noteworthy because of his relatability. As a coming-of-age story, *Blue Period* explores his sense of self, thoughts, and emotions vividly. This gives viewers an opportunity to go through this reflective journey with him.

The relatable character development stems from how Yatora finds his purpose and how he expresses himself in art. The first five minutes of the series exhibit his uncaring attitude towards art until he is enthralled by the mystique of Mori's painting. Starting at that point, the audience develops an empathetic connection with him when he feels despair or joy in painting.

The relatability does come at the expense of exceptionality. Yatora undergoes the same journey of self-discovery as characters in many other works. Fortunately, the simple set-up of his character has inherent appeal, and his arc is shaped more by himself than by others. Rather than requiring a rival or an external force to motivate him, he grows due to his newfound passion, striving to improve both himself as a person and his work.

Yatora is deserving of 3rd place because he feels like a real human. Viewers are able to feel the emotions and life that he pours into each of his paintings, and can enjoy the victories as if they were with him.

Ai's journey from an emotionally crippled and timid girl into an empowered warrior of love forms the emotional backbone of *Wonder Egg*. Like an extroverted sunflower, Ai follows the glimpses of light and clarity she finds in others. She turns relentlessly toward the positive despite the horrors and guides her show—and the others—towards that end.

Substantial screen time is given to Ai's desire to form relationships. What's more, her growth and decisions are all informed by talking out her issues with her newfound friends. Reciprocating, Ai provides that same shoulder to lean on for the egg girls, as well as for Rika, Momoe, and, of course, Neiru.

However, it was understandably difficult to interpret the final episode of the show, with some reading Ai's actions therein as an out-of-character regression instead of a character failing after being pulled in two different directions. Additionally, the speed at which the final scene arrives can be seen as one element of Ai's arc that ended up suffering due to *WEP*'s famously troubled production schedule.

Where the story of *Wonder Egg Priority* goes from here is anyone's guess. But if nothing else is ever made for the series, there will still exist the tale of one shut-in girl leaning on the ties that bind to work through and, quite literally, rise above her trauma. The vivid, colorful story of discovering the mechanics and meaning of friendship remains alive and well in Ai Ohto.

At its core, *Nomad: Megalo Box 2* is about a broken man trying to put together the long lost pieces of his life and find redemption and a purpose.

Joe's journey begins with him trying to come to terms with his grim past of regret and loss in order to seek his true self. The story depicts him as a new person who is capable of facing the inner demons birthed by the weak resolve of his past self, accepting them, and moving on. He fulfills his narrative and thematic role beautifully in relation to the cast and complements the other character storylines, which also act as a parallel to his own struggles.

At the same time, this parallelism comes at the expense of his story being less engaging and emotional, as he acts more as a foil for characterizing the rest of the cast. Especially so during the second half of the show, where Joe's personal journey comes to a halt. 
 
Still, this journey of reconciliation with himself and the people around him makes Joe remarkably different from who he was in season one. The self recognition, self recovery, and spiritual healing throughout this season mark the beginning of a humble life for Joe. He receives a new-found personality and a new life: a life where he is no longer the titular nomad, as he has a home to return to and people waiting for him.

Shinji's character in *Shin Evangelion Movie:||* builds on the franchise and serves as the perfect conclusion to his 20+ years as a talking point in the anime community. Shinji's lack of self worth and confidence in himself are a large part of his character and what makes him so captivating, so it makes sense that this film concludes these conflicts almost seamlessly. 

The first film starts at rock bottom as Shinji loses those around him as well as piloting, which had given his life meaning up until this point. Through his interactions with the villagers, he realizes there is more meaning to his life than the Eva, and this serves as a major foundation for his development at the climax. Finally, after this newfound discovery, it's poetic that he chooses to get back in the robot of his own volition.

A large amount of Shinji's struggle with self worth and depression stems from his strained relationship with his father, and the major climax of the film is his confrontation with Gendo. As Shinji's character has never really found peace due to the lack of a resolution to this relationship, it's only fitting that Evangelion begins and ends with it.

After finally having come to terms with himself and his role in the world Shinji pushes forward and fights a future that he chooses for himself, free from suffering and constant fighting. This perfect ending to his journey nets Shinji the position of best main dramatic character of 2021.

One of the strong points of Vivy's arc is her learning to grow beyond her programming. She pushes herself from just wanting to make people happy with her singing to protecting people. A lot of Vivy's strongest character moments come when she runs into her programmed mission and has to amend it to justify taking certain actions, or deal with the consequences of those actions. While Vivy is not the first AI to grapple with human concerns like the soul or the heart, this rendition of that familiar story has some great moments.

An area of the story that offered exciting possibilities was the end of the third arc. Vivy watches a man commit suicide in front of her. The idea of seeing her have to come to terms with this development was interesting. Unfortunately, the show did not go in that direction, taking an easier path instead by having her be rebooted. Vivy's factory reset version, Diva, takes over and is largely in control during the fourth arc. 

The biggest issue with the show, and our main character in particular, was with this change-up. Vivy's development had been progressing well, but this section of the story took the wind out of its sails. While Vivy does return, her arc has to make up for the stumble and does not stick the landing. Though perhaps the logical conclusion to her arc given where it started, the finale, and the answer to Vivy's mission, ends up being a bit frustrating as well.

Hiroshi Odokawa is inextricable from *Odd Taxi*—he drives the entire plot, connecting the disparate threads. Given the varied nature of the cast, this is no small feat, but Odokawa manages to keep the story grounded and plausible. Perhaps more impressively, Odokawa manages all of this while keeping up a refreshing dynamic with each of the colorful characters that inhabit *Odd Taxi*'s world. Perhaps this is a result of his stoic, disaffected personality, his considerate cynicism, or even his dry disposition that ensures that he never hogs the spotlight—regardless of why he consistently manages to draw out the quintessential and most entertaining parts of the rest of the ensemble.
That being said, he is somewhat half-baked as a dramatic character. While Odokawa is indisputably the grounding rock of the narrative, this inert nature somewhat resists the thematic development typically associated with a dramatic character. While he does change in interesting and unique ways, he changes as a person rather than as a part of the greater story, which makes his arc feel a bit hollow, especially compared to the poignant changes experienced by the other characters.
Nevertheless, the crafting of his character is superb. In a medium dominated by teenagers, *Odd Taxi* boldly centers itself around a grouchy, cynical 40-year old, and this novelty itself has value, offering a unique perspective to support its message. These personality aspects are nuanced and well-characterized, and his age—aside from providing contrast with the cast—makes these personality aspects feel appropriate and reasonable.

nominees.altname: Rudeus Greyrat (Mushoku Tensei: Isekai Ittara Honki Dasu Part 1 and Part 2)
nominees.writeup:
Rudeus Greyrat's narrative followed a conventional trajectory until the end of the second season, where the seeds of an interesting future arc were planted within the finale—after a major shift in character dynamics. While not a traditional redemption story, *Mushoku Tensei* is still a tale about “living life to the fullest.” On that front, Rudy's journey to overcome his status and woes as a hikikomori did not challenge or break new ground as an isekai character arc. However, the pacing of his character development, along with his dynamic with each character introduced, sets him up to be an endearing character. The juxtaposition between Rudy and the world around him, as well as how it affects his growth and arc, was well explored. 

The crux of the conversation is simply this: Rudy's moral degeneracy, specifically his pedophilia. This major flaw is detrimental to the viewing experience and hurt his otherwise decent bid at ranking higher on this list. This was due to the lack of clarity in his characterization—is his reincarnation simply the mind of an adult in a child's body?—and distaste at the lighthearted portrayal of such a delicate subject.

Rudeus is a decent character, with high potential, but not without issue. Due to the straightforward nature of his arc, along with some morally objectionable elements, Rudy doesn't place any higher than this. In further seasons, with further development, that could easily change.

nominees.altname: Eren Yeager (Shingeki no Kyojin: The Final Season Part 1)
nominees.writeup:
In *Shingeki no Kyojin: The Final Season*, Eren's sight of his original goals is gone with the spark in his eyes. The shaggy-haired, shouty teenager we knew in season three has vanished, and only the jaded, weary husk remains, shoulder-length unkempt hair covering his dead eyes. His nonchalant attitude towards genocide and the death of his friends accentuates this fatigue. 
Eren's new, apathetic behavior towards Reiner also brings attention to his reshaped values, his hatred and rage now transformed into indifference and even sympathy. 

*The Final Season* broadens the world from the small island of Eldia to the continent of Marley. However, this shift in perspective accompanies a shift in focus to the Marleyians, leaving much of the original cast underdeveloped. Hence, Eren is a black box; we see the inputs and the outputs but his perspective is never shown. The show's cast—and by extension the viewers—are left to put the pieces together. This ambiguity is a blessing and a curse. While thematically, this is effective at further isolating Eren and creating intrigue, he's also more of a cipher than a character: he suffers from a general lack of substance. In the end, this is the reason he doesn't place higher, despite fulfilling his role as the central source of tension and mystery in this season.

awards.name: Main Comedic
awards.blurb:
2021 was a year of long-awaited sequels and adaptations, and as such the category of main comedic character had its list of characters dominated by characters from these popular anime but still managed to find a few hidden gems that went under the radar. 
 
It was interesting to compare all these characters from different backgrounds, from the soothing emotion that the casts of *Non Non Biyori* and *Yuru Camp* to the highly energetic adventures of the protagonists of *Meikyuu Black Company* and *Sentouin, Hakenshimasu!*. And we can’t forget the myriad of emotions that romantic-comedies brought with their leads in *Kanojo mo Kanojo*. 
 
In the later stages of the category, Renge Miyauchi and Kinji Ninomiya stood almost unopposed at the top, but almost every other character was divisive. The performances of Katarina, Tae Yamada, and Tooru, while retaining what made them charmful, were criticized as not bringing enough to the table that they had not already in previous installments. Shouko Komi and Hayase Nagatoro had strong support but were not without criticism of their character traits that felt mishandled in an uncomfortable way. And not to forget the addition of the iconic character Sakata Gintoki coming from his final entry, where it was debated whether to analyze his entire character or within the vacuum of the final movie.  
 
While the category concluded with a satisfying and consensual winner, the rest of the nominees had their proponents that didn’t come without opposition, ultimately making a tight result for the brackets below the top.

nominees.writeup:
Kinji Ninomiya was a character with little fanfare coming into the awards. *Meikyuu Black Company* did not really have a particularly large audience when it aired, so its protagonist was not on many people's radar. However, his stellar characterization and utilization throughout the series was impossible to ignore, making him a pleasant surprise.

The core of Kinji's character is simple. He hates working hard, yet is willing to put an immense amount of effort into a variety of schemes in order to achieve his dream of leading a truly lazy life. The ways these schemes play out are at the core of nearly every facet of the series. His elaborate schemes are the main source of action, intrigue, comedy, fantasy worldbuilding, and commentary on the modern Japanese work environment in the series. Make no mistake, Kinji is often a scumbag, but he's an incredibly loveable one, with consistent motivations that are at times relatable.

Interestingly, the series never falls into the trap of treating Kinji with kid gloves. He receives his well-deserved comeuppance whenever it is merited, and he also does have a soft side that comes out at times. This soft side is never inconsistent with his core goals though. Whether any particular action of his will be agreeable or loathsome is a bit of a wildcard, but those actions are always entertaining. In the end, this dynamic performance earned Kinji a second-place finish.

THE LEGENDARY YAMADA TAE once again demonstrates how worthy she is of her title in MAPPA's amazing follow-up to *Zombie Land Saga*. Building off of the previously established strong foundations of her first appearance, she delivers a hilarious and entertaining performance with a shocking amount of depth in *Zombie Land Saga: Revenge*. This is seen in how Tae Yamada ranges from being a funny background event, a mindless zombie that her friends must keep masqueraded, and the absolute center of attention who channels the spirit of Freddie Mercury's Live Aid Speech in order to jazz up a crowd!

Tae Yamada's dancing skills and musical input are also a joy to behold, and she's even funny off of the stage, such as when she accidentally saves her idol unit from the despair of debt. From all of these examples, we can see how Tae Yamada is more than just a meme, as she's the unsung hero of her group and a fully realized character.

The amount of agency and respect afforded to her is heartwarming to see. She may be non-verbal, but Tae Yamada has dignity and an important role in the proceedings of her show. That said, it must be noted that while she did not have the most screen time out of the idols of Franchouchou, she made every second she had on screen count and delivered 120% effort on all of her humorous antics. Thus, THE LEGENDARY YAMADA TAE managed a commendable fourth place finish in Main Comedic.

Renge is the heart and soul of *Non Non Biyori*. Her antics are bewitching and her childlike attitude coupled with her deadpan delivery and surprising maturity make for a character that's difficult to dislike.

Renge's dynamic with Shiori is one of the strongest parts of this season, giving her a younger friend to bounce off. Renge's childlike excitement to be an older sister to Shiori is funny and the lengths she goes to be a good one is endearing. Her relationship with Akane is another highlight of the season. Renge pushes Akane to play games with her which leads to great gags. Renge is one of Akane's first real friends and she helps her make some big steps forward.

Let's not forget Renge's relationship with the usual cast of characters either. Renge's dynamic with Natsumi and Hikage is fantastic. She acts as a little sister to both and they are very sweet to her in return, happy to play along with her games. Her dynamic with Candy Store, who bends over backwards to help Renge, is touching, and would not be an exaggeration to say they have the most heartfelt relationship in the show.

Renge really stands out among the rest of the nominations as the most praised character by far. Beyond simply being a fun character to follow and creating heartfelt moments, her ability to carry her show, creating situations for other characters to shine in, is staggering.

nominees.altname: Katarina Claes (My Next Life as a Villainess: All Routes Lead to Doom! X)
nominees.writeup:
After her first season's triumphs and misadventures, Katarina Claes decides to continue on her cheerfully oblivious quest to avoid doom whilst seducing literally every single person in the world. Katarina, hereafter called Bakarina, more than lives up to her reputation and name in the most humorous of ways. Still under the delusion that her harem ISN'T in love with her, she cheerfully goes about her life while comically misunderstanding literally everything romance related.

This behavior is best exemplified during the Kidnapped Katarina Arc. While her harem is busy forging alliances and moving Heaven and Earth to track her down, Bakarina is happily treating this all as an extended vacation for her to laze about, read romance novels, eat sweets, and also charm and romance her captors Lima Syndrome Style. Much like before, Maaya Uchida continues to channel the overly eager moron that is Bakarina, as well as imbuing her with a sense of charm and genuine friendliness. Of course, Maaya Uchida's range extends to being able to bring the smug Ojou-sama to life, seen best during the play where, true to form, Bakarina forgot her lines and thus resorts to repeating her Villainess one-liners to the crowd's adoration.

Sadly, while clearly the high point of her show, the second season's weaker writing and missteps with the romantic progression hurt her overall ranking. She also did not reinvent the metaphorical wheel, relying mostly on her pre-established Season 1 gags. Regardless, she still managed a respectable sixth place finish in Main Comedic.

Tooru's journey in *Kobayashi-san Chi no Maidragon S* is one that elaborates on her past, present, and future aspirations. It's an emotional story wrapped in a coating of Kyoto Animation's fantastic “moe” animation. 

Tooru continues to be the cute maid for Kobayashi and her ensuing antics were no less funny than before. Her place in human society is now a part of her being as she ventures out to find out what kind of human-society dragon she wishes to be. *Maidragon S* also dives into the nitty-gritty details of her journey to how she got here in the first place. The amazing emotional beats alongside the revealed lore became more impactful as the show went on, giving us the story of how she met her peers. It helps us invest in her and the other characters. Her story comes back around to Kobayashi and how Kobayashi helped change her world, giving us a well-executed backstory that parallels the present. She is always one to neglect her own health in order to help out those she cares about whether it's an overreaction or not. 

To sum it up, Tooru acts as the glue that holds the family together. She's mature when it comes to those she must nurture and soft and/or cheerful to those whose days she wants to brighten. Strong and steadfast when she has to protect any of them. She is a fantastic character and deserves a spot in the top three.

Despite her lack of words, Komi manages to be one of the more interesting characters in this category. Her inability to communicate brings forth a massive barrier to her dream of making 100 friends, but *Komi-san wa, Komyushou desu.* is able to make this premise as interesting as possible. 

Her honesty shines and how she interacts with each character without judgment shows her compassion. Her simple design and timid personality feels loud and exuberant. Without even saying a word, the audience is still able to understand her thoughts and motivations. It's an impressive achievement in execution. Thanks to her gimmick of not being able to communicate, the moments where she musters up enough courage to express herself with words is an impactful gap that displays a lot of emotions.

The main strength of her portrayal as a comedic entity lies heavily on the interactions between her and the unique friends she makes along the way. These interactions make for fun skits and wholesome character development. However, due to the heavy reliance on side characters to make Komi continually intriguing and *Komi-san* fun, she's limited as a character.

Despite being overshadowed by her side characters in the comedy department, Komi still stands true as the main character with her various facial expressions of fear.

Nagatoro: the former hentai doujin-turned-manga-turned-anime heroine that fully unlocks the masochism trait in all of us. She emphatically captures the loving bully, between her magnificent voice actor, wonderfully deranged reaction faces, and gleeful character animation. But, behind this facade is the ultimate glass cannon, a girl with a crush who is all bark and no bite. 

The situations Nagatoro proactively presents come across as consistently funny, cringey, and charming in equal measure. She's earnest and transparent enough to the viewer (if not to Senpai) that embracing the invited fantasy of a cute girl paying *any* amount of attention to you is very easy. However, when her veneer fades, we see her goal of true romance and the unspoken desires she's too ashamed to admit. Whether she's chasing away other suitors or being caught off guard by Senpai's acts of compassion, flustered Nagatoro proves time and time again to be top-shelf moe.

Understandably though, many may find it hard to buy into the bullying. Nagatoro's actions can be seen as abuse and many claim that as a death knell for both romance and comedy. Also, the show often ends up resorting to overused, weaker jokes around characters being put into perverted scenarios.

Nevertheless, those willing to appreciate Nagatoro for what she offers will find a remarkably sincere and unique romantic comedy lead. If your manic pixie dream girl is going to be atypical, you could do far worse than being under Nagatoro's thumb.

After more than 15 years, the journey of Gintoki Sakata comes to an end in the form of the film *Gintama: The Final*. While the Gintama movie had gone under the radar, Gintoki was still welcomed as a favorite among many.
Gintoki was already appreciated for working as a great static protagonist, flipping between comedic and dramatic perfectly for each moment he was in. However, since the ending of the 2015 season, the story and Gintoki himself took a rocky turn, with his role in the remainder of the series never reaching the peaks of previous seasons.

The conclusion to Gintoki's journey didn't fully show his strengths. The structure of the movie didn't allow for good character interactions which are *Gintama*'s core. With most of the character reunions occurring in a rush to face the final boss, Gintoki didn't manage to show his best comedic side and there was the lingering feeling that his performance was carried by his voice actor.

On the dramatic side, the later developments of Gintoki, Takasugi, and their master's relationship was a good emotional moment that harkens back to Gintama's main theme of family but still fails to impress. 

Gintoki is a highly respected character, keeping the humor of *Gintama* fresh for more than 300 episodes. However, the handling of his character leaves something to be desired of what was meant to be a grand finale, landing him in seventh place of the category.

awards.name: Supporting Character
awards.blurb:
The nominations this year all approach creating a good supporting character in many different ways. Matsumoto and Ruijerd are integral to their respective stories, supporting their protagonists throughout the narrative. 
 
On the flipside is Hikage, who impacts her story significantly less yet stands out due to the strength of her character. *Re:Zero*’s Otto and *To Your Eternity*’s Gugu both only appear briefly, but they leave large impacts on the main characters and fight alongside them. In contrast, *Odd Taxi*’s Tanaka acts as a villain who opposes his protagonist. Perhaps the most bizarre approach is *Evangelion 3.0+1.0*’s Mari, whose thematic significance stands out instead of her character depth or story impact. 
 
Mari and Hikage's unique aspects made them contentious, with much of the discussion regarding these two characters. However, while having less discussion than Hikage and Mari, *Blue Period*'s Ryuuji was the nominee who stood out the most. The only reason they had less discussion was because every juror liked them, with the addition that they were the least controversial out of the nominees. While they are only around for a short time, Ryuuji pops into the story to make lasting impacts on Yatora, emerging as the best supporting character of the year.

nominees.writeup:
Hikage has a bigger role in *Non Non Biyori S3* than ever before. Her best moments are with Natsumi or Renge. Acting as a big sister to both, she goes out of her way to play along with their antics. It is touching to see how that relationship remains strong, with Hikage helping Natsumi even when they were young kids and dressing up as a villain in their games.

However, she does have some failings. Hikage's largest problem is that she is locked into these dynamics, not interacting nearly as often with other cast members like Hotaru and Komari. She is not always the highlight of her scenes either, usually serving as a straight man to the bigger personality of Natsumi. Thus, Hikage is not as complex or as impactful a character as she could be, staying as a foil to Natsumi and being a good sister primarily.

Despite these flaws, there is much to like about Hikage. The gap in her maturity level and how she desires to be represented is very endearing, creating some great gags. She is relatively level headed, but Natsumi can change that, and the two get up to hilarious hijinks. Some great examples include them waffling over the decision to do their summer homework as well as them attempting to shirk their responsibilities when they break Natsumi's mom's vase, terrified of the ramifications. 

While Hikage's simple characteristics keep her from placing higher, her strong emotional core and hilarious moments place her in sixth.

The best praise and biggest criticism to levy at Mari is that she operates almost entirely meta-narratively. Anno and Khara deliberately insert a coy, self-aware character into the *Eva* rebuild films, one who flirts with mocking the tone while flirting with a mocking tone. Whether that is cringe or cool is neither here nor there. What is undeniable is that Mari does not fit in.

Though she fights alongside the cast, stuck in the same maddening quagmire of a technobabble plot, Mari lacks the tell-tale crippling hyper-fixation, immaturity, or personal flaws of an *Evangelion* character. She is the only sane person who falls into a series that has been dominated by emotionally broken man-children since the mid-'90s.

Precisely because of her difference, though, she enables *Evangelion*'s metaphor for breaking out of depression and self-destructive mindsets. She showcases a stable worldview, one perspective able to stave off the absurdity of existence. And that stability allows Shinji to rise above the insanity that trapped him to finally move forward.

However, concerns over Mari's lack of development and agency in relation to the movie's plot may arise. Her activeness and interactions also may appear undeveloped due to little screen time. Despite these concerns, she successfully ruins everything known as *Evangelion*, precisely as intended. For a woman bearing the names of a traitor and prostitute, for a series that grew up with its creator and with us all, there could be no better final message.

Ryuuji, or Yuka, is a broken mirror since their struggles reflect *Blue Period*'s central themes of identity, non-conformity, and acceptance. Adolescence is a difficult part of life. On top of the usual struggles, such as identity crises, peer pressure, and physical and psychological changes, Yuka's situation is compounded by unsupportive and abusive parents. 

At first glance, Yatora and Yuka appear completely different, but there are several parallels: both want to be able to do and be what they love doing. While overlapping with Yatora's arc, Yuka's character is not tied to him. Therefore, when their paths cross, their interactions feel genuine and not forced. Despite being considered a supporting character, Yuka never feels like one. The three-episode-long arc is not merely a one-sided opportunity to highlight Yatora's growth but also to explore Yuka as a real person, recontextualizing much of what is shown in the opening episodes. 

As expected from a show about art, *Blue Period* excels at visual symbolism. Nowhere is this more apparent than the clothing, representing the facade Yuka hides behind. Yuka's identity is couched in general themes of non-conformity, and *Blue Period*'s depiction of gender identity is nuanced and deliberately vague.

One of the more unique aspects of *Vivy: Fluorite Eye's Song* is the character Matsumoto. His friendship with Vivy is a bit rocky, to say the least. On one hand, he wants to save the world from the calamity of the AIs by seeking the help of the AI Vivy. On the other hand, he will do anything in order to follow his principles, even to the extent of sacrificing innocent people simply because he does not want a “butterfly effect” to occur. 

Making a character seem cold, heartless, and unsympathetic for most of the show while also making them charismatic, funny, and likable is a fine line to walk. In this case, however, it succeeds. Matsumoto's friendship with Vivy is endearing, and it is great to watch him slowly develop empathy. 

Even so, he lacks depth outside of “sticking to his principles,” impacting his development. He may also appear annoying sometimes, as he continuously reminds Vivy that her actions will “save the world.” A reminder every once in a while is sufficient, though repeating it in nearly every episode becomes redundant and diminishes its emphasis. 

Despite his simplicity, Matsumoto's overall interactions with Vivy, his comedic lines, and how he begins to see AI's and peoples' lives as less expandable as the show progresses, alleviate his flaws. Still an overall great character, Matsumoto takes seventh place.

When Hajime Tanaka enters the stage in the fourth episode of *Odd Taxi*, his appearance is surprising, to say the least. His story interrupts the slowly opening threads around Odokawa, only tying them together near the end of the episode. But as his backstory unfolds what drives his actions, Tanaka reveals himself to be an engaging factor of Chaos in the cast's lives, particularly Odokawa.

What makes Tanaka interesting is his inability to confront his problems in a healthy way, contrasting him with Odokawa, who is equally broken yet more capable of taking steps necessary to help himself. While the former is often grasping at straws for solutions, Odokawa manages to find a path forward with the given information. Tanaka instead jumps at the easiest solution, be that an obsession with collecting a rare, though meaningless item or outright murder. He only turns himself around through the sheer coincidence of running into Dobu, confronting Tanaka with the fact that nothing that happened to him was more than just dumb bad luck, and he is finally able to let go of his previous obsessions by the end.

Some criticism may arise that Tanaka's arc is not directly connected to other characters beyond chasing them and that his story wraps up without much explanation in the finale, leaving little character development. While he is an interesting addition to the series that shake up the slowly forming expectations, these factors lead Tanaka to fifth place.

In the story of an immortal trying to understand life, Gugu's role exemplifies both tragedy and perseverance. It is not difficult to sympathize with the boy when his heroics leave his face scarred, and the booze man decides to use him as an experiment even while saving his life in return. A fate that would leave many permanently damaged is used to show that humanity can overcome, as Gugu does the best he can despite what has happened to him. 

Somewhat mixed is his relationship with Rean, as his passivity and lack of confidence make it hard to enjoy the otherwise fun interactions with his crush. More singularly positive is his relationship with Fushi, as they form a brotherly bond that both benefit from despite a somewhat rocky start. Both characters are distinct from the people around them, and during their time together, Fushi learns valuable lessons from Gugu about being human. The tight bond highlights each of the character's growth, as Gugu's supporting role shines especially bright here.

While Gugu's story does not end on a particularly positive note, it serves as a testament to his and humanity's capacity to persevere and rebound from adversity. Wrapping up his personal arc in a satisfying manner and sending Fushi back on his journey as a wiser man is what earns Gugu second place.

nominees.altname: Otto Suwen (Re:Zero kara Hajimeru Isekai Seikatsu 2nd Season Part 2)
nominees.writeup:
*Re:Zero* is full of fantastic supporting characters, and the loveable Otto is the shining star of the pack. Ostracized by his peers for his divine protection, Otto lived in misery for most of his life. After leaving his hometown, Otto decides to become a merchant and eventually someone who Subaru can call a true friend.

As far as his backstory goes, it is a bit shallow since it is essentially the cliché of “the kid who is bullied because of how special he is” without giving a unique spin to it. With that said, Otto, who is driven by his will to help his friends, is a quick-witted, loveable, honest, and all-around fantastic character. He is shown to have a backbone, especially when it comes to calling out Subaru's wrongdoings while pulling him out of hopeless situations by offering his help as a friend. He is straightforward and sometimes even brutally honest, yet all of it is not out of malice, but rather out of benevolence. He is mostly powerless, though he is still able to fend off Garfiel, an opponent much stronger than him, by using the environment around him which shows his ability to think on his feet.

Although Otto appears shallow and his backstory not being particularly unique, he is still great overall. His resilience, honesty, and kindness highlights him as what many consider “best boy” of the cast. Therefore, Otto lands safely into fourth.

nominees.altname: Ruijerd Superdia (Mushoku Tensei: Isekai Ittara Honki Dasu Part 1 and Part 2)
nominees.writeup:
*Mushoku Tensei* is at its best when exploring the problems of the empowered. Giving characters agency then having them deal with the results of their choices never gets old, and the show loves to play in this space. Nowhere can we see that better than the demon warrior Ruijerd and his mandate against child violence.

Once the show adds Rudy's otherworldly and informed values into the mix to foil Ruijerd's, philosophical debates, tough choices spring up. While never totally in favor of either Rujierd's or Rudy's methods, the show fully explores both, crafting a few poignant scenes exploring the nature of violence and justification of power. These situations unsettle and upset the characters, forcing them to talk out their decisions as equals, and the friction generates wonderful character growth and drama.

That is not to say it is all smooth storytelling with Ruijerd. The plot dump detailing his past is not particularly great storytelling, and at times his moral code feels like an excuse for him to use violence without having the audience lose sympathy because of it. Still, he plays an integral role in Dead End's dynamics with a relatable goal, respectable passions, and understandable weaknesses that complement Eris and Rudy. Rujierd walks the path toward an ending of redemption and social acceptance after learning how to from the children. Because it is easy to root for Ruijerd and fun to watch him struggle to find his way in the world, he places third.

awards.name: Cast
awards.blurb:
A solid cast is the foundation for engaging character drama. Seeing characters struggle, change, and grow along their journeys creates an immersive experience that invests audiences in their development. 2021 presents a slate of not only beloved returning casts, but also brand new faces that immediately draw attention. 
 
The impressive variety of dynamics characterizes this year's selections. Whether it's *Jujutsu Kaisen*'s blood-pumping struggle to become stronger or the found family of *Maid Dragon S*, there's something for everyone. Ensemble casts continue to shine with *Zombie Land Saga: Revenge*’s lovable weirdos, Aggretsuko*'s relatable workplace comedy, or *Odd Taxi*'s tight writing in service of wild personalities.  It's an excellent year for lovers of diverse, nuanced casts. 
 
Nevertheless, *Fruits Basket: The Final* stands alone at the top of the rankings. The adaptation is a triumph, and accomplishes more in its 13 episodes than any other nominee. It gives valuable time to every side character and puts to rest all the burning questions present from the very beginning, giving closure to Tohru and the Somas. *Fruits Basket* is a winner among winners in a strong year of enchanting casts that anyone can fall in love with.

nominees.writeup:
*Aggretsuko*'s cast impresses with another season that builds on its previous successes. Retsuko's increased confidence is emphasized, coming off her stint as an idol. Ton gets great characterization and demonstrates his love for his family as he swallows his pride in the face of troubles at work. The character development of Kabae, Anai, and Fenneko in previous seasons is respected, and it never feels like they're reset to how they were at the beginning of the series.

This season delves more into Haida's troubled relationship with Retsuko. Unfortunately, the excuses he comes up with border on unbelievable at times, and it diminishes his impact as a character. This season sells itself as one that could resolve the questions about their relationship, but instead shows a different side of Haida. He starts to crave the attention and validation that he never got under Ton, but now does under the new CEO Himuro. This side plot destabilizes what should be easy character development for Haida.

Still, *Aggretsuko*'s large, diverse cast makes for a great workplace comedy, and continues to make its characters some of the most intriguing to follow. Whether it's Kabae's gossip, Ton's bullheadedness, or Retsuko's evolving romantic relationships, it's easy to find someone to empathize with in *Aggretsuko*.

With the group's death drama now largely buried in season one, *Zombieland Saga: Revenge* instead leverages Fanchouchou's personal ambitions for fresh character arcs. Everyone, even previously marginalized characters and new episodic foils, have vivid and tangible stories that hit harder than a runaway truck; well-timed, funny and emotional.

At the heart of this show is a tale of misfits, failures, and cast-offs finding purpose and acceptance in undeath for a world that never really gave them a chance to flourish in life. The joke of monsters being idols and shambling through the day may have rotted a bit, but in its place, *Revenge* showed us far more high-minded and intriguing concerns: identity, desire, belonging, and living—truly living—for more than just oneself.

For a character-based show, the group dynamic doesn't feature heavily this season. The drama exists mostly as zombie vs. society and zombie vs. zombie self. Leaving the tight found-family untouched helps the show's strict episodic aims, but the absence of awesome moments of tension or rap battles between members leaves a rap battle-sized void in this season, only partially filled by Tae's Freddy Mercury impression.

Still, *Zombieland Saga: Revenge* stands out as a paragon of episodic character writing and engaging ensemble casts. Franchouchou's failures, triumphs, and realizations arise directly from their own actions, and it is only by the strength of their bonds that these girls carve out a place in a society that truly accepts them for who they are and who they want to be.

*Kobayashi-san Chi no Maidragon S* both develops and expands its diverse and eccentric cast. As the leading duo Kobayashi and Tooru continue to learn more about each other, they build up their relationship beyond where it was in the first season. The season also fleshes out its supporting cast beyond their one-note character tropes from season one. Elma in particular is now a much stronger character with a compelling, lore-relevant backstory that expands on her relationship with Tooru. Shouta was also a strong character this season with an arc that seeks to define him beyond his relationship with Lucoa. There's plenty of room for the expansive supporting cast to shine with Kanna and Shouta even having full episodes to themselves, although Riko remains one-note.
The cast's newest addition Ilulu is the latest dragon to crash-land in Kobayashi's life, and her reliance on sexual humor is bound to be hit-or-miss with audiences. However, her backstory is emotionally engaging and fits well with the show's overall themes surrounding the co-existence of dragons and humans. 
The sequel to *Kobayashi-san Chi no Maidragon* maintains its cast's colorful energy while developing them as well earning the fourth place spot.

No cast of characters was more gripping in 2021 than *Fruits Basket: The Final*. Despite its massive cast, *Fruits Basket* manages to give each character a befitting conclusion, showing off to a new generation what made the series a shoujo manga icon.

While the season suffers rushed pacing and moderate contrivances, the character writing is stellar. From the main grouping of romantic interests all the way to near throwaway characters, everyone receives the proper amount of focus to complete their stories neatly. However, just tying up loose ends is not what garnered the adoration of audiences. The emotional connection to the cast, weight of their story conclusions, and entertaining characters surpassed all of its competition. Akito's development stole the spotlight, completing an arc rivaled by few in the romance genre. Their story managed to both delight and disturb viewers with its twists and reveals. Kyo's series-spanning story also reached its climactic boiling point alongside his reconciliation with the rest of the cast, specifically the other Zodiac Members. The overarching narrative of character's hiding their true selves behind a mask is portrayed beautifully as well, with the theme of those masks being shed given a bright spotlight.

*Fruits Basket*'s unparalleled character writing made it a clear choice for first place as the best cast of the year. Its dedication to tying together story and character arcs spanning three seasons brought about an immensely satisfying conclusion which left very little up to the imagination of the viewer.

*Re:Zero* is a show known for its diverse cast and character interactions. However, this season tries to do something different and develop characters through backstories. This approach gives a unique edge to the show by elevating peculiar characters such as Emilia, Roswaal and Beatrice more engagingly.

Emilia stands at the center of this season as we explore her past alongside her. By watching the difficulties she encountered, viewers gain newfound insight into her current personality that's sorely needed. This type of approach comes with a cost however. Since the series spends most of its screen time on past events that mostly concern Emilia, the present story slows to a halt with less developed characters like Garfiel.

One of the potential problems with this retrospective approach is that newly introduced characters have less time to shine. This might result in weaker characters but *Re:Zero* manages to flesh out and humanize them with empathic character writing. As a result, these characters hook audiences in and create an immersive experience.

Overall, *Re:Zero*'s cast shines once again by using a different approach to storytelling and switching between past and current timelines. However, some major players were left in the dark, resulting in weaker character resolutions. For that reason, *Re:Zero* lands in sixth place on the list.

The Jujutsu Sorcerers of *Jujutsu Kaisen* are uniquely defined by their fighting styles, and a firm cast of villains ensures a progressing back and forth conflict between the forces of good and evil.

Each new sorcerer that enters the fray has a recognizable fighting style and distinct mannerisms, not just the ever-present handful of main characters.What you see is what you get with this series, and the personalities of its cast typically don't ever move outside of expectations at face value. In this regard, characters' depth is explored and developed through the progression of their proficiency in combat.

A generally “edgy” theme is present with the majority of the cast, and many characters come across as brooding just for the sake of breaking into a fight with the next person they see. Maki and Nanami were notable highlights for the way in which their involvement in the world of Jujutsu Sorcerers comes about. Other characters such as Gojou or Mahito stand out for being incredibly charismatic to suit their dominating displays of power, but have little in the way of substance to support their individual motivations. The character dynamics between Yuuji, Megumi, and Nobara were reminiscent of the classic interactions between members of Naruto's Team Seven. However, the exploration of the first-year trio leaves much to be desired to reach the same realm of camaraderie and interpersonal relationships.

*Odd Taxi* has one of the strongest casts of the year by providing an expansive roster of characters, each with their own nuanced storylines. Despite having an impressively large cast, each and every character matters in the grand story. Characters balance both their connection to Odakawa and the series of odd events while also dealing with issues found in everyday society. The series showcases these characters' struggles to succeed in their desires despite the pitfalls of life, causing them to get themselves into trouble and shady situations despite their best intentions. 

Every character from the largest gorilla to the smallest feline is developed efficiently. Eccentric personalities, impactful interactions, and memorable backstories breathe life into them not only individually, but as a cohesive unit.. Despite what each character brings to the table, the characters are lively and brimming with dry humor. Their animal designs still manage to humanize them and reflect their unique personalities right off the bat.

While *Odd Taxi* has an impressive cast, it does have a weakness. Due to the expansive cast and the show's focus on it's storyline, the characters lack depth as they aren't as developed outside of the main storyline. Despite this limitation, *Odd Taxi*'s characters manage to comprise one of the top casts of the year with strong individual and shared storylines that all fit together perfectly.

nominees.altname: Mushoku Tensei: Isekai Ittara Honki Dasu (Part 1 and Part 2)
nominees.writeup:
While “sword and sorcery in another world” fantasy series have been done to death, *Mushoku Tensei* brought forth a level of polish and world-building not seen in many of its contemporaries.

Across two seasons, Rudy comes across all sorts of new experiences as he explores the world. His development throughout the series is phenomenal and genuinely comes across as watching a real person grow throughout their formative years in an organic and believable manner.

However, a stellar cast requires the combined chemistry of many well-written and multifaceted characters. *Mushoku Tensei* delivers interesting storylines for Roxy and Paul, but falls short developing female cast members or providing them substantial agency. Furthermore, almost none of the other side characters have any meaningful interactions with each other beyond shallow surface-level conversations and cooperation. In terms of antagonists, *Mushoku Tensei* runs on a standard “conflict of the week” formula, only hinting at a possible overarching antagonist. These characters are not particularly memorable, and lack chemistry. Rudy is generally the only person with whom cast members have meaningful interactions, as everything is through his lens. Aside from Roxy, characters rarely have substantial development in any situation that is not directly connected to Rudy.

*Mushoku Tensei* ultimately lands in seventh place, not due to lacking well-written characters, but instead lacking a wide enough cast with substantial synergy and particularly memorable antagonists.

sections.blurb: These awards are given to the shows that have displayed exceptional performance in technical areas. From visuals to sound to OP and ED, every award in this section showcases a different aspect of the process of anime production.

awards.name: Animation
awards.blurb:
Anime production in 2021 would be defined by animation pipelines managing the pandemic with an ever-increasing amount of delays and productions collapsing left and right. Examples like *MagiReco S2* not even getting 8 scheduled episodes out display the industry’s struggles to get an increasing amount of content out in any manner possible. In these circumstances we also saw some incredible highlights with a slate of ambitious original anime like *Wonder Egg Priority* and *Sonny Boy*,  lavish adaptations for high profile titles like *Mushoku Tensei* and *Jujutsu Kaisen*, and the return of the ever-consistent in KyoAni in the joyful second season of *Maid Dragon*.  
  
The jury gave a thorough check to the aforementioned titles and a lot more for choosing our nominees. The public nominees were mostly a pleasant surprise for us in terms of overlap, but the surprise inclusion of *Vivy* in place of *Egg* meant we had a hard decision to choose three titles from *Sonny Boy*, *Sk∞*, *Heike Monogatari*, *SSSS.Dynazenon*, and *Bakuten* and land at the current nominees. 
  
Our final rankings were done after thorough discussions based on consistency of both action animation and character acting throughout the show that give the show an identity as well as the highlights that enhance the narrative at the right moments. Therein, the jury arrived at pretty unanimous rankings for our first three places and the bottom choice of *Vivy*, but the other rankings were extremely competitive with everything from *Sk8* to *Heike* standing on almost equal footing in the jury’s eyes.

nominees.writeup:
*Sk∞*'s animation philosophy could be described as a combination of realism and extreme exaggeration. Director Hiroko Utsumi and her team used their extensive research of real skaters to make something exciting and full of personality. With that in mind, the animators do not limit themselves with grounded recreation of skateboarding, so the accuracy of the skate movement is usually supplemented by [more cartoony reactions]( https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/141712) and the presentation of races quickly goes overboard by adding [insane physics](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/163649) [slow motion](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/141723),  or [out of this world imagery]( https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/144631).


The show relies heavily on CG backgrounds, which gives room for some [long tracking shots]( https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/141720) and [extreme maneuvering]( https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/141720). It also tries to express character personalities through animation, like when ex-Kyoani veteran Chiyoko Ueno adds [hesitation to Langa's hand gestures](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/142405), or [Adam's dance] (https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/144629) by Takahiro Kagami. With [various]( https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/141714) [Kameda](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/142393) [eyecatchers]( https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/143136) and even [more goofiness]( https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/145401) with Takuya Igarashi episodes the show brims with energy even outside of the main skating parts.


Unfortunately, in the second half *Sk∞*'s character acting becomes more conservative, and even the races were simplified, with some animation cuts not having the same level of complexity as the first half. But the show still picks up in the last episode, delivering a satisfying finale which helped it to secure fourth spot.

nominees.writeup:
Character acting takes the spotlight in *Heike Monogatari*. Lively emotive expressionism makes it stand out from the more restricted seriousness, which tends to be the norm of historical dramas. The intriguing balance between realism, cartoony exaggeration, and preservation of appealing compositions, well exemplified with [Joan Chung's excellent sequence](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/165163), turns the grand historical figures into endearingly human folk while also offering strong characterization. The diverse personalities of Shigemori's children in the aforementioned sequence, [wild spirit of Yoshinaka](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/169943), and [Kiyomori's infectious amusement](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/165169) are great examples of the show's nuanced characterization through character acting. With clear mannerisms established for each character, moments breaking from the norm convey their intention effortlessly: [Tokuko breaking her usual noblewoman's composure when with Biwa](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/165765) demonstrates their closeness.


However, *Heike Monogatari*'s animation isn't simply a victorious venture, especially when it comes to battles. Episode nine's [duel by Kouki Fujimoto](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/171253) is a brilliant action set piece, which unfortunately turns into a rarity within the show; Genpei War's huge armies turn into daunting foes for the show's production, as static shots and stiff motions become awkwardly common midst the action climaxes.


The effects, especially with water and fire, are memorable assets that mesh well together with the show's unique aesthetic and create immersive [atmospheres](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/171374) on [numerous](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/172173) [occasions](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/165155). Thanks to moments like [episode six's epiphanic nightmare](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/168721), the animation finds its means to elevate the experience in the show's middle stretch, where even the strong character acting's metaphorical butter gets spread too thin. Lacking in volume but not in diversity, *Heike Monogatari*'s animation earns its placement as seventh.

nominees.writeup:
While the premise reads as a surreal fantasy, *Sonny Boy* is a shockingly grounded and realistic story, and this very much extends to the animation. [Character animation](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/165919) is [fun](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/163933) and [varied](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/162602) throughout the runtime of the show. Routine actions like running, talking, and gesticulating are animated carefully to give very genuine, nuanced motion. A handful of characters are very muted and unemotive, which leverages the lively animation less than it otherwise could, but otherwise *Sonny Boy* effectively and realistically brings its cast to life.


Perhaps more impressively, the liveliness of the animation doesn't end at the human characters – there is extensive and impressive animal animation as well. Birds - a recurring motif in the series - feature [motions](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/160282) that are both true-to-life and clearly indicative of their purpose. Recurring characters include a [trio of cats](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/165905), complete with unique mannerisms but overall grounded movement – and a [human-turned-dog](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/162667) animated with an unnerving mix of dog movements and human mannerisms. There is also an [incredible cut](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/162074) of an entire school of fish as the characters swim through the ocean.


On the other hand, it has a relative dearth of truly memorable moments and highlight cuts compared to the first and second-place entries. There aren't none, of course – there is some truly impressive effects work to convey the [special powers](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/163926) at the core of the story, but the aforementioned realism means much more emphasis is placed on the mundane than the exceptional.


At the end of the day, though, it's this focus on the mundane that gives a permeating realism to the story, which is certainly impressive in its own right. The consistency of the work is truly laudable, and the baseline of the show is very high and offers few gaffes to undermine its goals. This consistency is especially laudable considering it did not have a traditional chief animation director.

nominees.writeup:
*Wonder Egg Priority*'s first half is a non-stop barrage of *egg*cellent character acting and *eggs*hilarating action. Its [nuanced acting is led by renowned character animator, Keisuke Kobayashi](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/144885) along with a star-studded staff of guest animators who are able to perfectly convey the personalities of its entire cast, [from Rika's gregarious nature to Neiru's subdued one](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/145637). This specificity in mannerism, further helps the show in making standout statements where it breaks form as in [eel's depiction of Ai's cathartic declaration](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/145665). Its action animation while still having established veterans, is also the space of two breakout young animators in Yusuke Kawakami and Harumi Yamazaki with their dynamic ability to [portray huge traversals of space](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/142645) and [the momentum needed to defeat Egg Killers](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/143565), all the while keeping the sturdiness of the characters that typifies the show's acting. This convergence in character and action animation is best exemplified by Takuya Niinuma, who's mainly a character animator, working on [one of the most brutal action scenes in the show](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/146423) powerfully conveying the weight of Ai's missed strikes and the guttural punch she receives.


Of course, the show's production famously fell apart in its second half with the show putting in no compromises and brute forcing its animation at the cost of its staff's health. This not only leads to a loss of nuance with increasingly wobbly in-betweening and ill-fitting mannerisms, but also the complete disaster of shoddily put together walk cycles that is the special episode. Still there are enough highlights in its last few episodes, from [the vivacious acting for Frill's backstory](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/149220) to [the emphatic finisher in the tv run's finale](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/150068), that *Egg* comfortably earns its place as the second best animated show of the year.

nominees.writeup:
*Kobayashi-san Chi no Maidragon S* is an illustrious showcase of animation at its best. Character movements range from well-executed [walk cycles](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/165173) to [flowing fabric](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/160808), [delicate hair brushing](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/156395), and [ruffling frills](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/159009). These lavish movements facilitate characterization through delicate precision and accuracy.


There are various types of animation that are superbly executed, ranging from character acting to magical effects. [Ryo Miyagi's flames](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/159088) exhibit strong shape, volume, and coloring; demonstrating the ferocity of Tohru's and Ilulu's clash. Character quirks showcase exaggeration through [smears](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/160790) and [squash and stretch](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/164457) for comedy, to more [subtle gestures](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/165776) that convey a sense of realism and heightened emotion through their weight and timing. Each cut feels like a work of draftsmanship, given how strongly animators adhere to good fundamentals and cleanup work.


*Maid Dragon S* offers incredibly resourceful magical animation through its use of effects. [Tatsuya Satou's spell chant](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/159004) paired with an orb and good smoke work helps to elevate the “enchanting food's taste” maid cafe joke. Good linework and compositing aid [flame effects](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/159007), [galvanizing waves and lightning](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/161257) deliver on timing, shape and volume. [Smoke](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/159512) can convey an explosive burst of energy. Working several of these elements in unison, [Tamami Tokuyama](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/163857) brings us quite the spectacle to behold. 


It goes without saying that it is the most consistently well-executed entry this year, and it never quite loses its steam or feels too conservatively produced. *Maid Dragon S* is a steady movement machine that encapsulates the spirit of the medium and its endeavors.
