nominees.writeup:
*Vivy: Fluorite Eye's Song* was arguably nominated on the energy of its memorable fight sequences, animated by Masahiro Tokumaru, in episodes [four](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/174090) and [nine](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/174110). The bold, action flick-y camera movement and clear close combat choreography effectively sell the fights' intensity as well as gained traction on the subreddit.  


Unfortunately, *Vivy* doesn't offer much else to be impressed about, paling in comparison to other nominees in other aspects. The character acting is very sparse due to Vivy's muted personality while her energetic partner Matsumoto being mostly relegated to a cube form causes limitations.


While CGI scenes offer diversity to the show's action, the execution often leaves much to be desired with its generic digital effects and lack of cohesion such as the CG usage in a climactic battle in episode 6. The 2D fight scenes stand out, but they are not without fault either: Tokumaru's sequence in episode 4 is a good example of the show's occasional jerky movements and bold layouts causing awkward results. The frantically moving background glides underneath the characters' feet and makes the setting's depth feel very hard to define. This causes in-depth motions and sense of each movements' speed to feel unclear and clumsy.


As the fights mostly stick to traditional, acrobatic martial arts action and the show lacks noteworthy dance sequences, the potential of a show about a fighting robot idol doesn't feel fully realized. While not an uneventful experience, *Vivy* fails to offer enough to reach the level of the other nominees.

nominees.writeup:
*Jujutsu Kaisen* stands or falls based on its 24 episodes of exciting action and fight scenes.  The fight scenes have very well executed [martial arts choreography](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/144501) and the animators manage the pacing of the scenes such that they never feel exhausting.  They also include creature animation and body deformation that [convey the weight and power of the fights](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/134442) that make credible the level of destruction left in their wake.


Several imperfections were noted that affected its final ranking.  One factor was the lack of variety, as most characters fight in similar styles.  Another factor was that scenes outside of action scenes mostly consist of wide shots of characters on opposite sides of the frame, close ups with only their mouths moving, or just a simple walk cycle.  Another was that character animation is rare, except for in a handful of comedic sequences.  Finally, there were some jarring background animations which [lead to an overly flat appearance](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/146601), and at times the ways in which the [different animators used effects](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/146601) clashed with the show's established style.


*Jujutsu Kaisen* deserves praise for the great fight scene choreography, and also for the many instances of effects animation, such as the portrayal of [curses as inky streaks and blue flames](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/138329).  Overall, while the action scenes are enough to carry the series to its present ranking, some technical imperfections and its over-reliance on the fight scenes above all else detract from it achieving the highest award in this category.

nominees.writeup:
*Mushoku Tensei* is an assortment of animation that adheres quite closely to the school of realism in nearly all of its facets. Character acting is abundant and varied, ranging from this dance sequence from [Kosuke Yoshida](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/171624) that showcases meticulous effort and practice, to [Kouta Sugawa's running and hair movements](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/142470) that coordinate a reluctant but accepting goodbye. Fight animation can showcase a sense of quick movement via [Hayato Kurosaki's background animation](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/168947) or use [Q Kawa's excellent smears and storyboarding](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/170553) to showcase a level of dexterity and skill while sparring. Effects animation can bring about good shape and volume like [Hiroyuki Takashima's fireball](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/144706) or [Ken Obata's background animation](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/142466) to portray the level of skill of the caster or the strength of their magic.


However, there are several weaknesses that exist. Despite the presence of acting, it becomes sparse in places and occasionally weakens character actions such as [Roxy's tearful reunion](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/171123) which is missing a sense of friction from hands rubbing on their faces, or [Nokopara's limited cycles](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/148935) when being threatened by Ruijerd. Fight scenes feel scarce compared to the training skirmishes throughout the show. [Magic](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/143913) and [general effects](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/167610) feel limited by striving for realism, are sparsely used, and are only at their best in the hands of an animator like Takashima.


Despite some of these limitations, the show looks marvelous at its best. Kishirika's expressive meeting with Rudy is filled with lovely and [cartoony exaggeration from Toshiyuki Sato](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/166757), episode 11 displays the deft power of our group against a [formidable foe from a full stafflist](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/166488), and episode 21 shows us quite well how [Hiroyuki Takashima](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/173105) can express primal fear through his use of reactions.

hms.name: Doraemon: Nobita’s New Dinosaur
hms.writeup: The new remake of the 1980 Doraemon movie about Nobita and his dinosaur friend has also become one of the best animation spectacles in recent years. Takashi Kojima designs allowed for some really fun and expressive character acting throughout, which is supplemented by instances of breathtaking background animation and multiple flying sequences. The climax of the movie also had an appearance of many action and effects animation aces, such as Takeshi Maenami, Keiichiro Watanabe, and even *Attack on Titan*’s Arifumi Imai. Even if you’re not familiar with Doraemon, this movie shouldnt be missed.

hms.name: Mobile Suit Gundam: Hathaway's Flash
hms.writeup: The last installment of UC Gundam timeline shifted focus towards human characters, which led to some of the most thorough hyperplastic character animation in Gundam’s history. Chief animation director Naoyuki Onda emphasized solid drawings and accuracy of the secondary motion no matter the angle characters are shown, but there’s also enough personality that comes up in their movement and expressions, without breaking the sense of realism. Even though it’s the most “human-focused” Gundam in recent memory, with even realist aces like Hiroyuki Okiura making an appearance, there are still instances of great drawn mecha animation by Hirotoshi Takaya and Shingo Tamagawa. It may not be as flashy as some other Gundams, but definitely one of the most cinematic.

hms.name: Boruto - #189 and #217
hms.writeup: *Boruto* delivers two big action setpieces in 189 and 217 to set the mood for Kawaki’s character introduction and the climax of Naruto’s battle with Isshiki. Both episodes' fights are headed under the experienced leadership of Hiroyuki Yamashita, featuring strong choreography under his storyboarding and attention to detail. With a star-studded lineup ranging from experienced series animators like Chengxi Huang and Masaaki Endo to newer foreign talent such as Vincent Chansard and Daniel Baron, these episodes bring us some of the best action in the show since episode 65

hms.name: Shin Evangelion Movie:||
hms.writeup: The 4th Rebuild finally came out and it looked better than ever. The first hour of the movie presents intricate character animation complemented by Anno’s directional style with a lot of unusual angles, and the rest is relying on Khara CG team and colorful effects. As expected the movie brought together the biggest names of the industry, including Studio Trigger’s Hiroyuki Imaishi and Kai Ikarashi, effects specialist Takashi Hashimoto, veteran character animator Toshiyuki Inoue and many more. It’s easily amongst the best animated movies of the last few years and an amazing visual experience like no other.

hms.name: One Piece - #957, #978 and #982
hms.writeup: 2021 was a momentous year for One Piece with it reaching many milestone chapters and episodes, but what stood out in particular were two episodes directed by Megumi Ishitani - 957 and 982. While they aren’t the insane action extravaganza Isuta Meister and co put out in episode 978, they have lifelike acting and full usage of the Straw Hats varied powers to create a fantastic calm before the storm with a snazzy dance number by Yang Huang and Yong-ce Tu and the impactful introduction of various new characters as portrayed by powerhouse animators like Masami Mori.

hms.name: Bakuten #01
hms.writeup: Bakuten’s premiere is one of the most thorough character acting showcases of the year featuring some of the best draftsmen in the tv anime scene with people like Shugo Matsumoto and Mitsuru Chiba. The episode not only puts out a showstopping gymnastic performance but also does a remarkable job of thoroughly animating crowds and brimming personality into its very wide cast.

hms.name: SSSS.Dynazenon #10
hms.writeup: Kai Ikarashi’s statement piece and inarguably one of the best episodes of the year, Dynazenon #10 is one of the most dynamically animated works ever presented on TV with Ichigo Kanno and Ken Yamamoto, in particular, putting out their best work. The episode captures the show’s particular cartoony energy, limited framerate, and focus on Kanada posing but filters it through such an extremely angular and kinetic lens that makes it stand apart from the rest of the show and anything else this year.

hms.name: Tropical-Rouge! Precure #29
hms.writeup: Every time Yuuta Tanaka directs a Precure episode, it becomes an event. And this year it's not just him directing, but also Masami Mori, aka soty as animation director, creating a totally different look from the rest of the show. They brought in not only Precure big names such as Nishiki Itaoka and Yuu Yoshiyama, but also some famous action freelancers like Nakaya Onsen and Hakyuu Go. And with that Tropical Rouge 29 became the most expressively fun action episode of the year, something worth checking out even if you’re not a Precure fan.

awards.name: Background Art
awards.blurb:
2021 saw a resurgence in the use of traditional painting for background art with Studio Pablo and Deho Gallery leading the charge in this preservation effort with their work on diverse titles as diverse as like *Sonny Boy*, *Heike Monogatari*, and *Shin Evangelion Movie:||*. Increasingly, even digital pipelines have tried to mimic analog aesthetics, be it the cel illustrations in *SSSS.Dynazenon* or the crayon style of *Kobayashi-san Chi no Maidragon S*. The jury’s final four nominees chosen from a large field of deserving candidates are good representatives of both these trends in anime. *Mars Red* and *Vlad Love* in particular stand out as some of the most interesting usage of digital background art to recreate painterly or graphical aesthetics in recent memory.  
 
While the public nominated two jury shortlists in *Mushoku Tensei: Isekai Ittara Honki Dasu* and *Yuru Camp△ Season 2*, the jury also had to go a period of intense catchup as nobody in the category expected *Jujutsu Kaisen* to be a nominee in Background Art. Following that our final ranking discussion focused on the cohesiveness of the chosen artstyle for every nominee - both interior and exterior scenes; their diversity in locales and stylizations to avoid the buildup of fatigue from overexposure; and perhaps most importantly the ability of the background art to visually inform the viewer about the narrative goals of the work as well as the personality and culture of the characters via the world they inhabit. Under these criteria we came to a unanimous ranking for our top two and bottom three picks, with only the order of the middle pack of *Mars Red*, *Vlad Love*, and *Mushoku Tensei* being contentious.

nominees.writeup:
*Vlad Love*'s most noticeable strength is its extreme stylistic variety. Live action [drone footage](https://i.imgur.com/tL7gl6x.jpg), [expressive harmonies](https://i.imgur.com/vC9HdTm.jpeg), and [graphically illustrative flashbacks](https://i.imgur.com/9COA65M.png) populate the show's runtime. Even the show's standard backgrounds are worthy of praise, with the faux [watercolor-esque style](https://i.imgur.com/VfPetOa.png) enhancing the often dark and moody atmosphere. *Vlad Love*'s biggest triumphs are the episodes presented solely via background art and narration without sacrificing expressiveness or detail. They take form in many different styles, from [detailed illustrations](https://i.imgur.com/EqyI9fy.png) to [abstract representations of emotion](https://i.imgur.com/crEIsoH.png) perfectly conveying the mood. 



Despite its strengths, *Vlad Love* lacks the consistency required to reach the level of the top nominees. The show overuses blue-green and yellow-orange palettes in its standard backgrounds, and its foliage can clash with visual filters. Otherwise, *Vlad Love*'s foray into visual experimentation is fitting for its subject matter. The vampire Mai takes on the characteristics of things she consumes, and similarly, the background art takes on different aesthetics to match the episode's content. The most striking is episode nine's homage to classic manga artist Yoshiharu Tsuge as it takes on the deep red colors and dystopian imagery that typify his work to create the most surrealist episode of the year. *Vlad Love*'s experimental and boundary pushing background art make it deserving of its fourth place ranking.

nominees.writeup:
*Mars Red* is an undeniable standout in background art this year, a pseudo-Taisho world full of visual depth, painterly aesthetics, and retro appeal. Utilizing bold brush strokes and lighting to convey rich texture, it achieves a level of opulence with its high focus on composition and impressionistic realism. 



While its strengths are not to be understated, *Mars Red* does notably falter in its consistency. The cinematic filters and effects used makes the scenes look foggy and almost sterile. And although the 3D models and elements add depth, they also look out-of-place, hurting the cohesion and strong composition.



*Mars Red*, however, sports the best interior designs of its contemporaries, effortlessly achieving a balance between commodiousness and intricacy, rich with personality. Another showcase of its brilliant sense of light, the interiors make use of negative space and architecture similar to the time period it mimics to build a beautiful and effective composition.



Its production blunders don't hold it back in the slightest though. *Mars Red* is a very strong show both technically and aesthetically. Its phenomenal interiors, rich brush stroke techniques, and it's theaterly aesthetic no doubt help push *Mars Red* backgrounds to an exemplary third place.

nominees.writeup:
The art in *Heike Monogatari* is a fusion between modern background art and classical Japanese painting. The gentle and delicate linework of the background art beautifully captures the essence of the Heian Period.



*Heike Monogatari*'s strongest feature is its thematic approach to landscapes. The show offers diverse backgrounds capturing the change in seasonality; this is marked by the changing fauna depicted in stunning detail and is one of the major strengths of the show. It uses rich soft pastel colors to create a spirited atmosphere befitting for this picturesque period piece. While the show is compositionally flat, it's not necessarily a bad thing given its aim to recreate the painting style of the Heian period. The vivid bright red for sunsets and dark gray to capture the scenes of war cleverly differentiate these scenes from the usual soft color palette, emphasizing some of the most emotionally impactful scenes in the show. The biggest weakness of *Heike* comes from the setting itself as the period appropriate largely empty interiors with the same pastel brown walls and floors grew tiring after a while. Still, this is a minor fault considering the show's other triumphs.



The show shifts its minimalistic artstyle to a more watercolor aesthetic Kamakura period art style near the epilogue showcasing the naturalistic deviation from the Heian art and signifying the beginning of a new era. All in all, *Heike* is a masterfully crafted period piece and a near perfect depiction of the Heian art style, easily leaving its mark on the jury and as such is deserving of being the runner-up of this year.

nominees.writeup:
*Sonny Boy* is an artistic triumph for Mari Fujino's team at Studio Pablo. They employ a [gorgeous painterly style](https://i.imgur.com/r7achuu.jpeg) depicting water and light as being composed from [distinctly visible layers of paint](https://i.imgur.com/vtwby0k.jpeg). Even the monochromatic backgrounds are painted with a technique that is almost Rothko-esque in its application of thick and dense brush strokes with different tonal values to form unified color paintings with incredible depth, a feeling further enhanced by the [rich dichotomies](https://i.imgur.com/G47SFR3.jpeg) between colors the show often employs.



Color in general is a strength of the show with the [saturated palette](https://i.imgur.com/wLXdTDS.jpeg) of Hatano Island's [verdant vistas](https://i.imgur.com/FSOCWqI.jpeg) perfectly evoking Hisashi Eguchi's pop art illustrations.



Besides how genuinely striking this base aesthetic is, the show has a lot of stylistic variety as it visits other "This World's" depicted in both analog techniques like [this homage to Rousseau](https://i.imgur.com/AUkPXdY.jpeg) and digital ones like depicting a world as [QR code mosaics](https://i.imgur.com/mNXSTCu.jpeg).



The backgrounds of the show also help greatly in visually telling the narrative of the show, be it neat shorthands like Rajdhani's [coded elements being demarcated by white borders](https://i.imgur.com/SqaXOEx.jpeg) to important thematic statements like the [dour, earthy mundanity of the environments](https://i.imgur.com/kJVkMYq.jpeg) in Nagara's final chosen world.



Given this excellence in cohesion, variation, and narrative integration, *Sonny Boy*'s background art was an easy winner in this category.

nominees.writeup:
The speculative science fiction setting of *Vivy: Fluorite Eye's Song* offers a lot of opportunities for interesting set pieces and locations in the show's background art. When this potential is taken advantage of, the results are effective—adding character and detail to the show's world while maintaining strong aesthetic sensibilities. The AI Island, ["Metal Float"](https://i.imgur.com/Bez0RFC.jpg) is the show's crowning jewel with regards to background art and setting design. It's a fun concept with a strong visual contrast from the rest of the show. The metallic tendrils and irregular shape give credence to the show's idea of the island itself growing and evolving.



Otherwise, the show's world is a barebones futuristic science fiction setting. Architecture is the usual vaguely sleek neon-tinged skyscrapers with little variation and personality. The Archive is a visual experiment that misses the mark, with coloring that is more garish than appealing. This is a pressing issue as a significant portion of the show's last arc takes place with the Archive as the backdrop. This lack of variety in setting is a consistent problem throughout the show.



However, the backgrounds aren't without strengths. Interiors are often solid, with strong texturing throughout. [Wood textures](https://i.imgur.com/1g2JlJD.png) in particular are appealing and offer a needed contrast to the abundance of bland sci-fi material. With such stiff competition, *Vivy: Fluorite Eye's Song*'s safe approach to backgrounds isn't enough to move it past seventh place.

nominees.writeup:
*Jujutsu Kaisen* mainly takes place in the seedy underbelly of a Tokyo haunted with curses. This setting poses a difficult job for the show's debut art director Jeong Ryeon Kim and his army of outsourced background artists as they have to show off the grungy nature of the world and still make the show appealing to look at. The show sometimes succeeds at this task, notably in episodes directed by Ryohei Takeshita, where it is able to make attractive displays out of its grim environments. For example, [the alleyway where Junpei first encounters Mahito](https://i.imgur.com/nckWAMl.jpeg) depicts the squalid condition of the area while capturing the bewitching presence of a special curse. Sadly, beyond those episodes it is plagued with overtly gritty texturing and a gross purple-tinged gradient which makes the show's art highly unappealing.



The show also has fairly limited settings, with the second cour largely set in a forest beset with garishly bright-green foliage. This limitation is counteracted by the biggest highlight and source of variance in the show's art direction: its Domain Expansion scenes. These can transform an otherwise unremarkable setting into a parade of abstract backgrounds that at [their best](https://i.imgur.com/tXKqamK.jpeg) stunningly convey [the power of a Jujutsu user](https://i.imgur.com/EKAvnJd.jpeg). These scenes do a lot of heavy lifting in making the show an interesting nominee for this category.

nominees.writeup:
While some of the other nominees attempt to create engaging background art with expressive art styles, *Yuru Camp△ Season 2*'s backgrounds are the complete opposite, designed with photorealism in mind. This decision makes for a wonderful showcase of Japan's natural beauty.



However, this attempt at creating lifelike backgrounds leads to a number of problems with compositing. Some of the backgrounds feature [poorly integrated stock foliage](https://i.imgur.com/bB3tJoM.jpg) and 3D elements, such as the water which leads to [shorelines that don't mesh properly with the rest of the terrain](https://i.imgur.com/sMb4CvN.jpg).



The show's winter setting also leads to some issues. It utilizes excessive desaturation in an attempt to match the season, but this also creates an uninteresting color palette. This dour palette is further exacerbated by the limited foliage in winter, and ultimately results in the show's backgrounds lacking variety.



The final section of the show is stronger in both its variety of locales and consistency. The trip to Izu shows off a number of topologically interesting and beautiful geospot locations where the show is finally able to fully show off the strength of its photorealistic backgrounds.



In the end, while *Yuru Camp△ Season 2*'s backgrounds are a sight to behold when they work, they are held back by their inconsistency.

nominees.altname: Mushoku Tensei: Isekai Ittara Honki Dasu (Part 1 and Part 2)
nominees.writeup:
The art team of *Mushoku Tensei: Isekai Ittara Honki Dasu* filled the background art of the fantasy isekai world with minute details or otherwise insignificant items like [blades of grass or bricks in a wall](https://i.imgur.com/NzwYwuX.png) to make the world come alive.



However, there were some downsides which could not be ignored.  The first cour is a generic fantasy world setting with poorly integrated elements, such as the CG house and [wheat fields](https://i.imgur.com/ovXH8Sn.jpeg) in Rudy's hometown. It provides some variety by ending in the Demon Continent, but while that is topographically interesting, it has a color palette of [ugly yellows and browns with very unappealing gradients](https://i.imgur.com/cwZGEA7.jpeg) that ultimately makes the setting a negative. There are also many scenes in which the backgrounds are just plain hazy or blurred because of the show's usage of a heavy grain filter. The end result muddies the foreground and background and makes the scenes visually unclear.



In spite of these issues, the background art team does a great job in making the isekai world a real, living place by introducing highly detailed landscapes with culturally varied settings. In particular, there are examples of [great background art in the second cour](https://i.imgur.com/XmpUFIV.jpeg), with beautiful depictions of environments and cityscapes, such as the rice paddies and the [monumental architecture](https://i.imgur.com/TifMPcf.jpeg) in the capital city of Shirone, the fantastic tree village of Doldia, and the turtle shell houses in Roxy's village. Background art like this sets a high standard for future anime of this genre to follow and lands *Mushoku Tensei* at a commendable fifth rank.

hms.name: Artiswitch
hms.writeup: *Artiswitch*'s art design is all about depicting the insane diversity of Harajuku's style with its own bold stylistic diversions. This variety particularly comes out during its episodic dream sequences which are invariably attractive and personable, be it the striking pop art cityscapes in Mana's free-flowing imagination or the surrealistic maze of an art museum in Tiara's envious nightmare. This is not to say *Artiswitch*'s excellence is limited to the dreams as Nina's shop's chic interiors and the graffiti-filled streets outside it also get an inordinate amount of attention and make the short series such a stand out.

hms.name: Bishounen Tanteidan's Illustration Scenes
hms.writeup: The beautiful [illustrative backgrounds](https://imgur.com/VBmEAoc) of *Bishounen Tanteidan* support the show's whimsical nature and its obsession with aesthetics. From the abstract starry skies in the opening scenes of the show to the fireworks created by the background team for the flashback to Mayumi's childhood, the show often dabbles with art that diverges from its default style to maximize aesthetic wonder at choice moments. These one-off moments are a striking example of using background art as a narrative tool and merit an honorable mention.

hms.name: Wonder Egg Priority's Greenhouse
hms.writeup: Acca and Ura-Acca's greenhouse is the lusciously vibrant garden hiding the sinister under-trappings of the egg system, and is the most evocative setting in the show. It is further utilized to seed the slurry of feeling in its characters' minds through gorgeously depicted flowers - from framing Rika's introduction alongside purple hydrangeas that reveal her pride to be a facade for her self-loathing to framing Momoe's denouement alongside hibiscus flowers denoting her acceptance of femininity. The ever-evolving nature of the setting creates thematic grounding for the show and deserves to be recognized for its excellence.

hms.name: Umibe no Etranger
hms.writeup: *Umibe no Etranger* is a lavishly detailed depiction of an idyllic Okinawan summer. Yumiko Kuga's work alone justifies the price of admission to the movie as she creates an endless parade of eye-candy background from the pristine windswept beaches of the island to Mio's charming and quaint cafe. Amongst these plethora of beautiful backgrounds, Shun's house in particular stands out with its backyard featuring a border wall overflowing from a kaleidoscopic array of gorgeous flowers and serves as the movie's jaw-dropping centerpiece.

hms.name: Shin Evangelion Movie:||
hms.writeup: The *Shin Evangelion Movie:||* slows down and shows off Deho Gallery's gorgeous background work. The film's portrayal of the goodness and beauty of humanity through its backgrounds is core to the first act's optimistic outlook. The picturesque village and lush landscapes offer a reprieve from the decaying world Evangelion usually situates itself in. The back half is filled with abstract settings and reimaginings of iconic moments from the franchise, exemplifying the eerie atmosphere. The final rebuild's commitment to detail and stylistic variety with its background art earns a nod of recognition.

awards.name: Character Design
awards.blurb:
Finalizing Character Design nominees is a tough nut to crack for any jury, since it's a balancing act of both recognizing excellence while acknowledging variety in styles. While the jury looked at over two dozen shortlists, the shortlists chiefly fell into four different camps: the minimalist realism of *Sonny Boy* and *Heike Monogatari*; the vibrant moekko designs of *Wonder Egg Priority* and *Selection Project*; the joseimuke-catering designs of *Sk∞* and *Vanitas*; and the tokusatsu homages and diverse casts of *SSSS.Dynazenon* and *Godzilla S.P*. All of them had their own unique pros and cons and the jury had the unenviable task of picking four of them to fill our limited slots, especially given the lack of overlap with the public nominees besides *Jujutsu Kaisen*. After much discussion, we landed on our current four nominees. 
 
It is important to specify that the discussion to whittle down the nominees focused on multiple criteria. The most important of these were: animation friendliness and expressivity; suitability of the designs for a character’s personality and their ability to inform the narrative; and aesthetic qualities like coloring, diversity of shapes, and lineart. The jury used these same criteria to finalize our ranking, where many placements became immediately obvious. The winner, though, was a battle down to the wire between *Sonny Boy* and *Dynazenon* as both shows not only excelled in creating attractive designs but also got an insane amount of narrative mileage from them.

nominees.writeup:
Norifumi Kugai's adaptation of [Hisashi Eguchi's original character designs for *Sonny Boy*](https://i.imgur.com/sCQwzam.jpg) captures his most essential qualities as a pop art illustrator: a combination of pristine line art, high-contrast one-tone colors, minimal amount of shadows and line work to provide depth and illustrate fabric folds, and, perhaps most importantly, a heavy de-emphasis on big *moe* eyes in favor of a facsimile of Japanese eyes with epicanthic folds that remain realistic yet graphically attractive. The last factor also serves as a useful way to create understated ethnic diversity with Rajdhani's eyes being far wider than the rest of the crew. While realism is a strength of the designs, their minimalist traits are also effectively applied for the surreal characters in the show's later half, particularly, [War, who casts a striking figure with just three base colors](https://i.imgur.com/DYR6B31.jpeg).

Beyond their aesthetic prowess, these designs also do a great job at conveying the personality of the characters and their role in the narrative. Nozomi's distinct blue uniform informs the viewer about both her status as a transfer student and a catalyst in the plot as well as her vivacious and transparent nature. During episode 2's election backstory, Mizuho's free-flowing hair and unkempt uniform contrasted with Pony's tightly-bound ponytail and prim attire to provide a delightful amount of dramatic irony. This ability to capture the narrative minutiae, combined with its unique aesthetics, gave *Sonny Boy*'s designs the edge needed to win this category.

nominees.writeup:
A natural evolution from his work on *SSSS.GRIDMAN*, Masaru Sakamoto's designs for *SSSS.DYNAZENON* balance eye-catching elements with subtle details beautifully. Vibrant colors and angular linework create an abundance of vivid imagery throughout the show, and an emphasis on flexibility gives the designs an [energetic distortion](https://i.imgur.com/5Bwm62T.png) during intense animation. Eyes are a distinct highlight– their prominent colors act as a [point of contrast against the designs' cohesive palettes](https://i.imgur.com/tkF7RWF.png). The designs achieve these visual strengths without compromising their ability to hint towards characters' innerworkings through details such as Gauma's bandages or Chise's arm wrap.

*SSSS.DYNAZENON* excels in its breadth. The Kaiju Eugenicists' military uniforms are a clear divergence from the main cast, but the villains aren't without charming customizations that convey their unique personalities. Even minor characters such as Yomogi's boss or Yume's friend have bright colorwork and careful details that allow for a seamless fit with the expressive main cast.

It would be remiss to forgo praising the titular Dynazenon mecha and its Kaiju enemies. Dynazenon's inclusion of each individual component in the final design is a strong visualization of the group's teamwork, and the mech's ability to flow between 3D and 2D animation leads to stunning animation. The Kaiju continue to carry over the “man-in-suit” aesthetic from the series' tokusatsu roots, cementing the show's visual language. *SSSS.DYNAZENON*'s striking color and linework decisions, and impressive care for all aspects of design made it a strong runner up.

nominees.writeup:
Michinori Chiba's design work for *SK∞* definitely belongs in any shortlist recognizing the best in character design this year.  The show's vibrant colorscape extends to its characters, making them pop off the screen against an already vivid background.  The designs are great at reflecting the personalities of the various skaters while also allowing for smooth animation.  The outfit design stands out in particular. Adam's flamboyant costume garnered worthy praise for reflecting his theatrical and often over-the-top personality.  While such grand costume designs were noteworthy, the everyday outfits are also strong in their ability to reflect the character's personalities. Reki's design in particular embodies the best elements of the show's design. Individual elements such as a hoodie under a school uniform or a headband have been used in anime, but the way Reki wears them makes the design aesthetically pleasing and unmistakably unique, all while allowing for ease of animation.  The show further imbued personality into the designs through the skateboard design, which were all incredibly unique and doubled as a fantastic worldbuilding tool.

While the main cast sported stellar designs, some felt the side cast felt comparatively lackluster.  Some character designs such as Kiriko, Tadashi, and the skate shop owner didn't quite match the strength of other designs in the show. Some felt that some of the production falling off as the show went on deserved to be a bit of a negative when evaluating the overall success of the design work.  Overall, *SK∞* is a worthy nomination, but ultimately wasn't consistent enough to compete for a top spot.
nominees.staff: Character Designs by Michinori Chiba

nominees.writeup:
Quite like the show itself, *Vivy: Fluorite Eye's Song*'s character designs reflect both the similarities and differences between AIs and humans within the show. For example, the AI characters have slightly off-color skin tones and eyeball cameras. The most obvious showcase of this difference is during the stunning hyper-detailed shots that highlight the uncanniness of the AI's designs.

The titular character, Vivy, is the highlight of the show's character design, particularly in her strong color design with her striking blue hair. Her design perfectly encapsulates the virtual idol aesthetic that the show is trying to achieve. The rest of her sisters match this same aesthetic well, but often feel significantly less inspired than Vivy. The designs for the human characters are similarly uninteresting with nothing that makes their designs stand out.

The show does have some strong designs outside of Vivy though, namely the AI bots during the Metal Float arc and Matsumoto's two forms. His teddy bear form works well as a mascot character for the show, complimenting Vivy's hair with his own blue color. His cube form, meanwhile, allows for some fun combinations to occur during fights, despite generally subpar CGI.

Despite many designs lacking depth, those that do standout lead *Vivy: Fluorite Eye's Song* to an eighth place finish.

nominees.writeup:
Takahashi Saki's unique and colorful designs in *Wonder Egg Priority* are a treat for the eyes. The over-the-top designs of the monsters help create a fantastic mix of both intimidating horror and goofiness, with their exaggerated proportions and their colorful bodies. Each monster's unique design ties-in into the narrative smoothly, which makes their ridiculousness fit in with the show. It also uses a more simplistic, yet effective approach for some of them. The Wonder Killer, for example, is a high-school girl with a censored face and bizarre lips that makes her look odd and unsettling. 

There were also some monster designs that were a bit underwhelming, especially the last one near the end of the show, which is basically just a glorified flying head. The main characters' outfits are memorable, without being too unrealistic or over the top. The existence of Ai's heterochromia, however, is poorly made, since it's whole purpose is to give a reason for her to be bullied. That being said, the designs for the characters and monsters were well-executed and the production team clearly put a lot of time and effort  into perfecting them. 

*Wonder Egg Priority* definitely has memorable and unique designs and deserved its nomination, even if it didn't get any higher in the rankings.

A solid addition to the storied catalog of the legendary character designer Tadashi Hiramatsu's work, *Jujutsu Kaisen*'s high execution is not without praise. Its designs excel in creating an appealing aesthetic, highlighted by its bold lineart and sharp, angular faces. *Jujutsu Kaisen* leaves an imposing and distinguished mark among its design contemporaries. The designs also lend themselves to exceptional character animation in any given scene.

However, while *Jujutsu Kaisen* succeeds in prominence and appeal, it falters at times in its originality. The long black uniforms sometimes had faulty rendering and an unassuming color palette, leaving some possible creative liberties to be desired. The monster designs were typically far more outlandish than the human characters, which often hindered serious immersion.

Though its creative choices are conservative, *Jujutsu Kaisen*'s designs are not to be underappreciated. They are bold, distinguished, and undeniably well-executed and visually appealing. These designs will no doubt be remembered as a strong member of Hiramatsu's polished works, earning the show an admirable fifth place.

*Mushoku Tensei* succeeds in showcasing strong design sensibilities. Its focus on the intricacies of its fantastical outfits and characters creates a colorful cast rich with culture. Above all else, *Mushoku Tensei*'s cast is both attractive and picturesque, a strong exemplar in fantasy design.  

However, the show ultimately falls short in several aspects of production. Its thin, unassuming line art causes the characters to blend into the background and even interferes with the composition of the foreground. The characters' edges often look blurred and unclear, far less cohesive than the rest of the designs. The color design is also generally uninspired and milquetoast; for example, hair and outfits are always painted with desaturated and muddled shades.

Though *Mushoku Tensei* is not without rather significant blunders, its clear design sensibilities and attractive characters are enough to propel it into a respectable sixth place.

nominees.writeup:
First-time character designer Baku Kinoshita showcases his design background with *Odd Taxi*'s signature animal designs that excelled  in explaining each character's personality and strengthening the narrative. For example, Odokawa's often prickly social demeanor is well represented by his walrus form, given how the animal has been seen to act.  

That being said, the designs usually lacked a variety of shapes and sizes.  Even though the characters are all based off of different animals (for example, Shibagaki a boar), their models all  employed similar builds.  In Shibagaki's case, however, the teeth do accurately reflect the unique characteristics of his animal.  Of all the characters, the one with the strongest design that showcased unique model shapes and elements exclusive to their animal was Shirakawa, whose design succeeded at representing an alpaca with her long neck and wool/fur.
  
The coloring and line work often fell flat, failing to make a distinct impression with many.The designs were generally stiff despite their simplicity. .The change in designs at the climax of the show supported its narrative, but the end results seemed too goofy or bland.  While *Odd Taxi*'s designs were sometimes lacking in execution , they provided a solid concept and earned the show a spot in seventh place.

hms.writeup: Having Kanna Hirayama, more affectionately known as *Kappe* as a character designer on your show is a unique blessing. She is not only able to create highly attractive characters with fashionable outfits and cute charm points that are easy to animate, but her insane work ethic means she supervises every episode in the show. This is especially a benefit for high impact scenes like the dance performances, where she not only corrected the taxing traditionally animated bits, but even the expressions on the CG models to make sure her idols always shine brightly.

hms.name: Uma Musume S2 - Twin Turbo
hms.writeup: Twin Turbo is the epitome of the maximalist design trends that’s been driving anime-adjacent industries of vtubers and mobile gacha games for the past few years. Simply being a character with a kemonomimi isn’t enough in this arms race, now you need to be a shark girl and a horse girl with ears that double as exhaust vents, while dressing up with exuberantly colored parka jackets, streetwear boots, and asymmetrical striped ribbons. Still, despite all these disparate elements, Twin Turbo is a design that just *works* which is a commendable achievement.

hms.name: Cider no You ni Kotoba ga Wakiagaru
hms.writeup: Aikei Yukiko’s designs for *Cider no You ni Kotoba ga Wakiagaru* are a major contributor to the film’s energetic personality. The characters are flexible and expressive, allowing for fun cuts of animation throughout. Design choices are smart— Smile’s buck teeth, while cute on their own, play a major part in her character arc as a relatable point of insecurity for an otherwise outgoing character. The wider cast is also impressive; the film's colorful supporting cast is never a bore. The film’s bright personalities and charming dynamics find their roots in the varied and poppy character designs.

awards.name: Cinematography
awards.blurb:
This year sees the return of the Cinematography category in the awards as a mixture of the erstwhile Compositing and Storyboarding categories, as well as including production roles like Color Design that have never been fully represented in the awards. Given such a wide gamut of production aspects to be judged in this category, it is imperative to create robust judging criteria. Storyboarding elements like framing and mise-en-scène, camera movement within a shot, the length of cuts and transitions between them, and visual symbolism to deepen the narrative; Compositing elements like the addition of lighting, grain, blur, and attractive digital VFX; as well as the show’s ability to use Color in an attractive and narratively effective manner were all given important consideration in our discussions while selecting the nominees and finalizing the ranks in this category. 
 
Our shortlists before finalizing the nominees included the current jury nominees, eventual public nominees like *86*, near misses like *Wonder Egg Priority* and *Sk∞*, and many dark horses like *Vlad Love* and *Super Cub*. Given the aforementioned criteria, however, we satisfactorily arrived at our final nominees, with *Dynazenon* holding up the storyboard end of the spectrum and  *Maid Dragon* representing excellence in compositing.  
 
After reviewing and discussing all the nominees, we realized that the jury held similar thoughts for most of the lower-placing nominees. However, there was intense debate between the middle pack of *Heike*, *Maid Dragon*, and *86* as well as a tossup between our top two of *Sonny Boy* and *Dynazenon*. Eventually though, *Dynazenon* with its impressive mix of evocative layouts, strong theatrical lighting, charming VFX, and deeply integrated symbolism built across the franchise came out at the top of the heap.

nominees.writeup: *SSSS.Dynazenon is a show that utilizes a strong show-don't-tell approach. The visual language is akin to *SSSS.Gridman*, although the focus now is more about the entire cast and less about its world. The show commands a strong dichotomy between realistic everyday scenes and mecha battles. The everyday scenes utilize principles of limited perspective, usually only focusing on a handful of main characters within the frame. The mecha battles, meanwhile, are full of references to classic mecha and tokusatsu shows, namely the 90s live-action *Denkou Choujin Gridman*. The cinematography of *Dynazenon* gives viewers context about the characters, their inner thoughts and their chemistry with each other. Conversations have a [fantastic sense of framing](https://i.imgur.com/U2m5ZOB.jpeg) that makes them engaging to follow and creates [striking compositions](https://i.imgur.com/1RxHS2G.jpeg) with its combination of character placement and mise-en-scène in dozens of scenes every episode. The show's shots are so [dense with symbolism](https://i.imgur.com/E1mtWaM.jpeg) and visual motifs like Yume's ankhs that [each characters' thoughts and feelings can be immediately displayed](https://i.imgur.com/7gTyNgw.jpeg), further marking the characters' progression throughout its motifs. Episode 10, for example, remains a masterclass of visual storytelling as it expertly intercuts between multiple characters experiencing and then waking up from their dreams with its striking images of shattered mirrors and freeze frames. In *Dynazenon*, Akira Amemiya and his staff are at the top of their game and in total control of their craft, granting the show the well-deserved top award for Best Cinematography for 2021.

nominees.writeup:
*Heike Monogatari* leans heavily into the visual elements to reinvent a well-known tale. The most striking cinematographic element of *Heike* is definitely the visual symbolism. Flowers are a [recurring](https://formeinfullbloom.files.wordpress.com/2021/09/saltree4.png) [motif](https://i.imgur.com/tw2S7Xy.png) throughout the series, offering not only insight into the characters and narrative using traditional Japanese floriography, but also development of the [thematic ideas of impermanence](https://imgur.com/a/kl4xOhH/). Other motifs, such as [Biwa's eyes](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/166412) or [fire](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/171374), receive heavy focus to emphasize her role as an observer and incorporate ideas of fate into the story's central thesis. The show also incorporates a variety of aesthetics, most notably one that [imitates woodblock](https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/897599670019301407/913206831847964672/ssSubsPlease_Heike_Monogatari_-_05_1080p_768AB9CD00_16_18.311.png) to emphasize the historical nature of its source material.

There were some missteps, of course. The middle episodes are noticeably weaker, making extensive use of panning and featuring less creative presentation. The numerous battles of the narrative have been publicly noted as a reason the classic hasn't been adapted, and *Heike Monogatari* certainly justifies that concern, as the battles are often messily directed and overuse stills to poorly depict a dynamic and crucial part of the story. 


From a directorial standpoint, there's a lot to love. Although some of the techniques that mimic modern live-action techniques (such as [lens flares](https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/897599670019301407/935352018527203358/unknown.png) and [chromatic aberration](https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/897599670019301407/935372795548942367/unknown.png)) often fall flat, the use of [rack focus](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/166410) aids in directing attention in the show's highly detailed world. Editing [seamlessly connects](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/171373) disparate scenes that tie different places or characters together, often in concert with the aforementioned flower symbolism to tastefully but unambiguously convey characters' demises. Framing in *Heike Monogatari* is also excellent: for example, Biwa is often placed at the edge of scenes to reinforce her nature as an outsider, and [Dutch angles](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/170686) are frequently used as the Heike's situation gets progressively desperate to mirror their anxieties and pain.

nominees.writeup:
*Kobayashi-san Chi no Maidragon S* returns for another season, featuring production that goes above and beyond what you'd expect in a slice of life show. Some of the best camera and effects work of the year can be found in the show's wide range of displays.  The dragon battles were a notable highlight, with [Illulu and Tohru's](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/159087) battle as well as the many battles between [Tohru and Elma](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/163857) bringing a level of cinematography not found in most action shows.  Even outside of obvious action moments, mundane moments such as [cooking](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/159001) or even [playing soccer with a shoe](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post/show/162510) dial up the visual presentation to eleven. .  While strong effects work makes for an enjoyable watch, other facets of the show deserve equal praise. In particular, the bright color palette is not only aesthetically pleasing, but a perfect fit for the show, and really brings out the best of the myriad of environments explored in this season.

All that said, the overall reception for the show's cinematography was mixed.  Many felt that while *Maid Dragon* was always proficient, it was rarely spectacular, which made it tough to compete with the upper echelon of the category.  While the show's boarding does improve with stellar episodes in the back half of the season, the first half of the season had storyboarding that would most accurately be described as mediocre.  While there were some instances of stellar lighting choices, particularly involving “golden hour” lighting and fireworks shots, there were also many moments of dull lighting.  Ultimately, the show's strengths were enough to put it in the top half of the category.

nominees.writeup:
Over the course of its run, *Sonny Boy* covers a broad range of tones - mysterious, dramatic, chaotic, personal - all requiring careful cinematographic execution to be depicted effectively. *Sonny Boy* deftly delivers this through the use of intricate framing, clean compositing, and lighting. Its strengths lie in the variance of its presentation, largely depending on the ever-changing settings that still manage to remain cohesive.

The cast is a significant focus of the story, made evident through intricate perspectives and framing of characters. Visual motifs are used often, such as focusing on Nozomi's eyes or Hoshi's star mark during key moments in the script. These creative decisions add thematic value to the narrative overall by visually introducing more weight to scenes. For example, episode eight highlights the [distance Yamahiko feels between himself and the rest of the students](https://i.imgur.com/Os97MUz.png) through both the framing as well as the coloring of the students - which works in parallel with [Nagara and his viewpoint through the](https://i.imgur.com/Bi7Y46t.png) [first half of the series.](https://i.imgur.com/5jEI8uV.png) The creative decisions also help preserve the slower but thoughtful pacing the show holds, allowing for the swift and lively visual bursts to be even more impactful.

While *Sonny Boy* is largely driven by director Shingo Natsume's own vision; having been given the rare gift of a blank slate to create something special with, the various episode directors instilled their own visual flair for their respective parts. Episode eight stands out especially in this regard, with Keiichiro Saito's [excellent storyboarding](https://www.sakugabooru.com/data/f1860154219c2fb9973f095212973d85.mp4) elevating the impact of what was a [very personal and melancholic backstory](https://www.sakugabooru.com/data/ecd343f7e72d2e6ebd9cf3e14580b361.mp4). Episode 12 offers a profound conclusion through the contrast between the [surreal lift-off scene](https://www.sakugabooru.com/data/02bea0a9b196a0f04741b0eb2483d6aa.mp4) and the [dour reality of their chosen world.](https://i.imgur.com/NVRFcAK.png) The combined talent and strengths of the production staff is what helped *Sonny Boy* present a raw and thought-provoking experience to its audience - something it certainly accomplished visually, resulting in its second place ranking.

In a competitive year, *Vivy: Fluorite Eye's Song* impressed with its cinematography most notably through Studio Wit's trademark close-up “makeup shots” and the action direction. The use of these detailed close-ups to highlight key moments was widely regarded as a positive, while the action storyboards earned praise across the board.
When it came to other aspects of *Vivy*'s cinematography, the show garnered more critique. The storyboarding was unremarkable outside of a few select scenes, particularly the classy action scenes of episode nine and moments such as Vivy chasing Matsumoto in episode one. Other key moments, however, including the flying in episode six, suffered from weak use of CGI and poorly composited visual effects, while the beautiful choreography in the fight between Vivy and Elizabeth is let down by the shoddily-inserted backgrounds. The lighting is generally flat and riddled with continuity errors, and fails to impress even with the stage lighting due to the aforementioned problems. failing to impress even with the stage lighting. 
While *Vivy* contained several strong moments, other shows in the category contained either more impactful standout moments or were more consistent in their production.

nominees.writeup:
Like many similar shows, the main draw for *Jujutsu Kaisen*'s cinematography is its action scenes. The fights are breathtaking with impressive choreography and dynamic camerawork. However, the show gets overambitious at times. The 3D backgrounds practically required for fights of this level feature awful texturing and there are a number of continuity errors in some fights.

Action scenes aren't the only thing in which *Jujutsu Kaisen* excels. The cinematic aspect ratio and shift in aesthetic during the fake backstory between Itadori and Toudou are great, and the baseball scene in episode 21 shows that *Jujutsu Kaisen* can also have some great comedic cinematography.

Outside of these positives, *Jujutsu Kaisen* doesn't have much to offer. The framing, shot selection and editing are too standard for the most part. The color palette is also uninteresting, consisting mostly of dull grays or garish greens depending on the setting.

The supernatural elements of the show do add some interest from this perspective, however. The visual effects and color utilization of blues and reds for cursed energy creates striking contrast between the rest of the color palette. The domains are generally strong, particularly Gojou's with its ethereal feel.  In the rare times when the show does shift from its usual aesthetic, it leads to some spectacular highs.   

Despite *Jujutsu Kaisen*'s strengths, the amount of mediocre moments leads to its seventh place finish.

nominees.writeup:
All of *86*'s excellence in storyboarding stems from the remarkably powerful decision to separate each episode of the show into two wholly distinct chunks: one with Lena's time at San Magnolia and the other with Spearhead Squadron's at the frontline. The boarding follows through on this inherent dichotomy by heightening the contrast between scenes with its signature abrupt transitions that emphasize the thematics between the desperation of the soldiers and the hedonism of the ruling class. 

Resolving these symbolic dichotomies gives the show's narrative propulsion that wouldn't exist without the deliberate direction. Perhaps the best example of this is Lena's arc. She starts out by trying to understand the squad from a position of naive charity captured with a bold uninterrupted shot that doesn't let the audience leave her headspace. This facile connection quickly blows up in her face and gives way to the development of genuine camaraderie via shared pain that the show reinforces by [mirroring her](https://i.imgur.com/dplMGKw.jpeg) and [Shin's framing](https://i.imgur.com/oJknD3k.jpeg) in key moments. Another highlight is Episode ten's flashback montage through Fido's lens that effectively sums up the squad's journey.

The action scenes are not as engagingly boarded as the rest of the show, with rare exceptions like the fight between Shin and Sho. They are also hampered by the usage of stock visual effects which creates for a dull spectacle. However, this is a minor setback for a show that otherwise excels in evocatively communicating its intent and thoroughly deserves its favorable fifth ranking.

*Mushoku Tensei* separates itself from other isekai in its ability to guide the viewer and slowly unveil its setting through its captivating shots. This is the main strength of the show's cinematography – it creates a distinct look by implementing a muted color palette, adding grain filters and simple camera tricks. It also completely discards traditional opening animation and shows in its place a montage of various locations, which further immerses the viewer into the world.
The show presents action well, especially in Eris' fights. Deftly switching from wide to perspective shots maintains clarity and showcases the strengths of individual fighters.. The series also features dynamic camerawork, namely in episodes five, 21, and during the dance in Episode seven.
All this said,  the show's predominant usage of brown, green and gray hues makes many of its locations blend together and leaves little lasting impression. Outside of climatic episodes, the framing, editing and shot composition are standard, and the effect work is inconsistent, especially regarding fire or the filters in the Hitogami room.
Despite the amazing highlights of several episodes, the rest of the show pales in comparison and ultimately places *Mushoku Tensei* in a respectable sixth place.

hms.name: Super Cub #01
hms.writeup: Super Cub’s premiere was a stunning exploration of Koguma’s depression. The entire episode is rendered with muted color grading that gets you into her headspace, but the palette is so refined that not only does it not feel drab, it makes for some of the most evocative night for night photography in anime. Furthermore, the storyboarding with its languorous establishing shots and repeating visual motifs like the crossroads helps enhance this melancholic tone. The episode’s final trick plays on these aspects as Koguma buys a Cub, chooses a different path on the crossroad and momentarily brings color to her life.

hms.name: Wonder Egg Priority #01
hms.writeup: Egg’s first episode took the anime community by storm. This was largely down to its exceptional direction that delivers a bizarre horror experience through the nostalgic lens of a Naoko Yamada show and all of her unique quirks: the usage of depth of focus, the importance of legs as a window to the character’s minds, and ofcourse, lots of flower language. However, it weaponizes those tricks to ground its grisly subject matter from the shadowy school bullies to the gruesome corpse they leave behind. The careful balance of this challenging mix of tones created a unique experience that is going to be remembered for years to come regardless of how the show turned out.

hms.name: Pompo the Cinephile
hms.writeup: Pompo’s emphasis on the process and struggles of filmmaking is brought to the forefront through its stellar visual strengths. The incredibly slick and well timed transitions, which helped preserve the motion in scenes, use various movie-related techniques that compliment the setting. The switch back and forth between the real world and the film recordings are utilized caringly, and integrate not only a stylistic change but also tie nicely into the narrative by showcasing the progressive improvements of the actors. A ‘Hollywood’ vibe is brought out through the usage of glossy and vibrant lighting, emphasizing the star-dazzled environment as well as the occasionally playful moments within the movie.

awards.name: OST
awards.blurb:
The purpose of the Original Soundtrack award is to recognize anime that sound good.  These are the anime that have strong emotional moments that hit that much harder because they are paired with the perfect song.  These soundtracks have a heavy hand in establishing setting and atmosphere.  This is accomplished through not only strong compositions with dynamic and fitting instrumentations but also through the way the songs themselves are used in the anime.   
 
This year in particular, the focus was shifted a bit from how the category has been judged in the past, as the weight of how the songs sound while listening separately from the anime was significantly decreased.  At the end of the day, we felt that it was much more important to evaluate how the songs sounded in the actual anime, as that’s how all of us experience them.  To this end, there was much more discussion on usage and mixing than in years past, and this is reflected in the final results. 
 
There are many familiar faces this year, with both the jury and public nominees featuring familiar composers and their efforts from this year.  It was a tough task for the jury to narrow the list to four, and it was unfortunate to see both sides leave out worthy candidates, such as Sk∞ and Jujitsu Kaisen.  Ultimately, while this year was one of the toughest nomination slates in recent memory, there were clear frontrunners who are probably some of the strongest contenders in the history of the awards.

nominees.writeup:
The soundtrack Yuki Hayashi brought to life on *Bakuten* was nothing short of exceptional. The music he creates is inspirational, emotional, and heartfelt; tracks like “Comeback” or “Fascinated by Feathers” are great examples of this. The incorporation of electronics can not be understated as they contrast exceptionally well to the more traditional instruments you hear in a soundtrack, like violins, flutes, pianos, which led to having a notably varied tracklist in terms of instrumentation and experimentation. The backing vocals also add more depth to quite a lot of songs, such as “Our Home Full of Fun” or “Destined Rivals”. Due to that variety, there are also quite a lot of different tones and emotions that the soundtrack gets across better than a lot of its contemporaries.


Some of Bakuten's tracks unfortunately felt a bit derivative of Hayashi's previous works, specifically *Kaze ga Tsuyoku Fuiteiru*, due to the similar style of instrumentation and emotions presented. Many felt that other nominees were more unique and interesting compositionally. Additionally, some felt that there were some issues with overuse of tracks, such as “I Want to do a Backflip”, during the dramatic moments.


The tracks during the rhythmic gymnastic performances are the best part of the soundtrack due to the accompaniment having an excellent sound and fit, which makes sense because Hayashi used to be a rhythmic gymnast. With that being said, *Bakuten* rounded out the top half at the fourth place position.

nominees.writeup:
*Shadow's House* was hailed as the strongest contextual soundtrack of the year. The main theme, “Shadows House”, highlights Kenichiro Suehiro's expertise in creating highly memorable melodies, with his compositions containing a selection of leitmotifs that are cleanly tied into many character themes throughout. These are great for establishing scenes and creating a narrative within the music that adds to the visuals and script.


Despite the large number of tracks, there are some consistent factors that keep the overall product cohesive. The instrumentation is a specific highlight, with a wide variety of wind, brass, and strings for the core of the tracks. The Victorian inspiration is immediately recognizable from a first listen, with additional layers and bits of flare added in to create a fresh but recognizable soundscape. Violin and cello solos add some extra spice to many themes, with surprise accordion appearances and Suehiro's exceptional keys leading the tracks along.


Utilization was an integral part to *Shadows House's* success; the tracklist is filled with various mood- and tone-setting pieces that are used wonderfully to complement the show. Be it the mystery vibes, slice-of-life moments, or even very intense sequences, each moment had a unique track that elevated the experience. The mixing is also of note, never overpowering scenes but also allowing space for the sound effects and voice acting to hold their own.


The combination of all these factors is what led to *Shadows House* taking the second placement among the jury rankings and being a standout soundtrack for the year.
nominees.staff: Music by Kenichiro Suehiro

nominees.writeup:
Listening to the actual tracks themselves, it's hard to think of many anime that have ever boasted more impressive compositions than *Wonder Egg Priority*.  Dé Dé Mouse and Mito pretty much emptied the chamber, and the resulting OST is one without a single bland track.  The soundtrack draws influences from a number of different sounds while still sounding completely like it's own thing, conveys a variety of emotions flawlessly, and experiments with rhythm and instruments to create a soundtrack even more mind boggling than the show itself.  Not exactly what you expect from a contentious third-place finisher.


Unfortunately, the OST suffered similar issues that many other aspects of *Wonder Egg* suffered.  Nowhere was this more evident than in the mixing.  While slice of life tracks and happy moments had great usage and mixing, the battle music rarely came through under a sea of overpowering vocals and sound effects.  Ultimately though, the positives outweigh the negatives, and it is worthy of the recognition it deserves as one of the best anime OSTs in recent memory.
nominees.staff: Music by Dé Dé Mouse and Mito

nominees.writeup:
Among all the anime that aired this year, a single entry shone through as the jury's clear favorite. With advice from the legendary Shinichirou Watanabe, director Natsume Shingo invited onboard an assortment of contemporary musicians to create a soundtrack brimming with both variety and personality. The range of the soundtrack is truly remarkable, with tracks varying from experimental mood pieces like “Yamabiko's/Kodama's Theme,” to beautiful insert songs like “Let There Be Light Again” and “Lightship.” Despite the tracks being composed by different artists, *Sonny Boy* is able to ensure that the different musical styles never feel dissonant with each other.


While watching *Sonny Boy*, the most notable thing about the soundtrack might very well be its extremely sparse usage, with the entire first episode not featuring even a single track. This restraint when it comes to background music allows *Sonny Boy* to save it for maximum emotional impact. Already in episode two, we bear witness to a wonderful build-up of synths in “Seagull,” effortlessly encapsulating the episode in question. In episode six, the midseason finale, we're treated to the first of many insert songs, “Let There Be Light Again,” providing us with one of the most powerful usages of music this year as the cast attempt to return back to their world. Yamabiko's backstory in episode 8, in many ways the show's most experimental episode, fully delivers musically with equally experimental episode-spanning tracks which capture the unusual mood of the episode, while the finale of the show sends us off with a math-rock rhapsody.


*Sonny Boy* rises above its competition through its sheer ambition — ambition which in this case is coupled with close to flawless execution— and thus takes home first place in the category.
nominees.staff: Music by 曾國宏, Jewell Fortenberry, VIDEOTAPEMUSIC, MC.sirafu, Mitsume, Ogawa & Tokoro, Mid-Air Thief, Mina Chitose, Risa Nakagawa, toe, Conisch and 坂本浩美

nominees.writeup:
The second nomination for Hiroyuki Sawano and Kohta Yamamoto, *86: Eighty Six* debuted with a wild OST befitting the intensity of the first season. *86*'s OST shows off a variety of influences and uses tracks that effectively support the scenes. 


The best moments of this OST came during the battle scenes, and most of the variety on this OST comes from the fights. Sawano shows off modern influences to create futuristic war themes. “The Answer” in particular represents the style in this OST, with wailing guitars and a touch of 90's R&B. The song choices work coherently with each scene, but even these strong tracks are severely hampered by overwhelming sound effects.


When the action stops, the OST slows things down and tackles the emotions at the core of *86*. These tracks are somber and focus on traditional instruments, dropping the electric guitar in favor of violin and piano, connecting the soundtrack to the internal struggles of the cast (Lena in particular). These tracks were not as memorable as anything that plays while sparks are flying, but they bring balance to the OST as a whole. 


*86*'s OST cements itself as a competent action album and has quite a few memorable themes. It was ultimately held back by some severe mixing issues and a general lack of variety but still more than earned it's nomination.
nominees.staff: Music by Kohta Yamamoto and Hiroyuki Sawano

nominees.writeup:
It should come as no surprise that a series about an idol android attempting to save the world would pay particular attention to its OST. *Vivy: Fluorite Eye's Song* relies mostly on electronic-backed tracks to set its futuristic cyber-dystopian atmosphere, and it generally does so quite effectively. The diversity in these electronic tracks is one of the OST's greatest strengths, as it prevented it from becoming stale or too one-note. The track “Matsumoto, the Stuffed Bear,” for example, sees chiptune elements joined by an accordion in order to effectively convey Matsumoto's quirkiness, while these elements aren't used in other parts of the OST where they wouldn't make as much sense. 


The addition of typical orchestral string arrangements to some of the tracks was the most significant point of criticism, as they feel unnecessarily shoehorned in. Instead of adding to the scenes they were used in, the tracks featuring these string arrangements instead feel a bit dissonant from the rest of the OST. 


The insert songs are the main standout of the series, as they effectively convey both the intensity and nuance of the scenes they were used in and allows those scenes to shine. A notable example of this is “Fluorite Eye's Song,” used in episode 13. As the culmination of Vivy's personal journey to both save the world and sing powerfully, the insert itself wraps up several of the show's thematic arcs. Overall, the high points of the OST earned it a fifth-place finish.
nominees.staff: Music by Satoru Kousaki, Ryuichi Takada, Keigo Hoashi, Kakeru Ishihama

nominees.altname: Mushoku Tensei: Isekai Ittara Honki Dasu + Mushoku Tensei: Isekai Ittara Honki Dasu (Part 1 and Part 2)
nominees.writeup:
Yoshiaki Fujisawa's soundtrack for *Mushoku Tensei* does a great job at placing us into its medieval fantasy world. In a competitive year, the soundtrack effectively utilized its individual compositions, and did an excellent job at enhancing not only key moments with its fantastical sounds of wonder, but also providing subtler moments with appropriate music.


Despite the positives, the soundtrack garnered some criticism. A common criticism was that the tracks were reused often, leading to inconsistency in the show's usage of its music. Additionally the lack of variety in the instrumentation was a negative, with an overreliance on flutes and other generically medieval instruments being especially noteworthy, which leads to the soundtrack failing to distinguish itself from other fantasy isekai. Despite this, the soundtrack was praised for how it managed to change its sound depending on what location the cast was visiting, for example with the tribal-style music played in the beastman village. In addition, the show's utilization of its opening sequences for establishing the episode was also a positive.


Overall the *Mushoku Tensei* soundtrack was competently used and well composed, but lacked an x-factor to allow it to reach the heights or consistency of its competitors more than occasionally, which is what keeps it eighth in the rankings.
nominees.staff: Music by Yoshiaki Fujisawa

nominees.altname: Shingeki no Kyojin: The Final Season Part 1
nominees.writeup:
The *Shingeki no Kyojin: Final Season* OST says, “If it ain't broke, don't fix it.” Hiroyuki Sawano returns to deliver more of the intense orchestral pieces that have defined the series. Joining this season, composer Kohta Yamamoto brings somber tracks to give greater weight to the emotional moments, even if they were lacking in variety. 


The final season struggled with tracks outside of the action, which can be troublesome for such a dialogue-heavy season. These tracks are still effective in creating a depressing atmosphere, but there was an emphasis on piano and violin for any sad scene. This makes it hard to differentiate between them. Even with a handful of standouts, they were less interesting than the epic battle arrangements. 
 

There are parts of *The Final Season*'s OST that rely too heavily on the influence of previous seasons, especially as the season progresses. However, this OST sets itself apart with wind-heavy instrumentation and some compositions that sound close to the 20th century. The new ideas come through especially in the new setting. The renaissance instruments in “Liberio Festival” or the emphasis on brass in “The Other Side of the Sea''. These tracks create a sense that Marley is a different country from Paradis. The modern styles also remind us that Marley is more advanced. All of that, in addition to stellar mixing for the action sequences, come together to create new iconic moments for the series. 


*Shingeki no Kyojin* earns its nomination with one of the most effective soundtracks from 2021. While there are stronger nominations which present more variation and original ideas, *The Final Season* has effective mood-setting music, smart composition, and more of the best action tracks in anime.
nominees.staff: Music by Kohta Yamamoto and Hiroyuki Sawano

hms.name: Golden Kamuy 3 (Snipe duel with Ogata and Vasili)
hms.writeup: [The scene](https://youtu.be/2XScl7MuTQo) starts out with low, deep rumbling bass notes with a distant violin. The sound is unsettling, but is obviously building up to something - there is a sense of dread in the music. During a quick flashback we get some jarring reverberations before we get brought. Then the music gets louder and is presented more forward to the listener. The climax to this event is becoming closer by the second. We get a little more guitar sprinkled in as the violins grow in size and sound. The drums come in - and with each layer and addition of a new instrument, the size, scale, and presentation grows larger. The situation increasingly stressful, and music executes that emotion wonderfully. As the sound and instruments build up, our expectations and emotional investment follows suit. When Vasili finally realizes he was almost played, the camera pans up and a jolting sound accompanies this, perfectly matching the visuals. Once the gun goes off, it’s immediate - all else falls silent. All you can hear is breathing. The mental battle he has been struggling with is over. He has won. And then BANG! Our expectations are subverted, but the silence still creeps on from here…

hms.name: Re:Zero Season 2 Part 2 "Reason to Believe"
hms.writeup: “Reason to Believe” is rather reminiscent of the classic “Reqiuem of Silence”; a strong track with some excellent instrumentation, but with a more hopeful tone. What makes this track especially standout is the progression and utilization. During the aptly titled Reason to Believe scene, the track slowly progresses, adding more instrument layers on until it crescendos- but is then sharply cut when the conversation between Emilia and Subaru turns sour. This sudden twist is also flipped in a positive way towards the end, during the Choose Me scene between Beatrice and Subaru.

hms.name: Re:Zero Season 2 Part 2 "The Eternal Freezing of Elior Forest"
hms.writeup: “The Eternal Freezing of Elior Forest” is used for some of the most heart-wrenching moments of *Re:Zero Season 2 Part 2*. Much like the events being portrayed while it is playing, the track itself is simultaneously haunting, beautiful, and painful. Its mixture of piano and strings are masterfully paced and create an ebb and flow that captures both the immense pain that young Emilia is experiencing after having her world turned upside down and the tiny slivers of hope that still remain in this situation.

hms.name: Tsuki to Laika to Nosferatu "Irina: the Vampire Cosmonaut"
hms.writeup: Yasunori Mitsuda returns to anime with an excellent showing through *Tsuki to Laika to Nosferatu*’s soundtrack. Known for their wonderful Chrono series scores, the track progression carries over into *Tsuki to Laika*’s composition, offering a solid selection of memorable melodies - with “Irina: the Vampire Cosmonaut” especially of note. Bits of Classical Eastern European tones can be heard throughout, complimenting the Cold War setting nicely with big brass instrumentation. Many tracks have a monumentous feeling, nicely incorporating the vastness of space and the size of the operations into the soundscape - all of these factors are accumulated in Irina: the Vampire Cosmonaut.

hms.name: Sk8 Episode 1, Langa vs Shadow, “Dimensions of the Wind”
hms.writeup: The mixing of Sk8 was excellent, and the first episode is particularly exemplary of this. The track perfectly matches what’s happening on screen, with the track building up as the contestants enter the abandoned warehouse. As Langa spots his opening the vocals pick back up, leading to a dramatic break in vocals as he falls off the ledge, only to pick back up as he makes the landing. As he makes the final jump and Shadow in desperation throws the firecrackers at him, all audio is cut until the soundtrack gently picks back up before the end of the episode.

awards.name: Voice Acting
awards.blurb:
Good voice acting isn’t necessarily about speaking fast or generating over the top reactions, which Japanese voice acting has a tendency to do. Instead, we are looking for performances that enhance the role and convince us of the emotions that are transferred. The acting needs to contribute to the story and can’t just be as simple as reading some lines. Nevertheless, there have been some incredible performances this year. 
 
2021 put out a great number of phenomenal voice acting performances.
