Directed by Nobutaka Yoda

nominees.writeup:
Hoshimachi Suisei's sixth original song, *GHOST*, topped the iTunes Japan and Amazon Music Japan charts and drew widespread attention from the VTuber community. The lyrics tell a story about Suisei's inner psychology, her thoughts, and anxieties as she struggles to figure out her identity as a VTuber. The song represents the emotional turmoil she faces as she struggles behind-the-scenes to understand her place in the world as a content creator. The title “ghost” draws parallels to how VTubers somehow exist, yet don't at the same time, and how Suisei struggles to find her relationship with the fans due to the inherent distance between them.

The astronomy and night sky visual themes are a nice touch, as is the simple pleasantness of some of the visual shots. The song also features catchy instrumentals and emotional vocals. However, the repetitive still shots and lack of movement throughout the MV is a big mark against *GHOST*, as the stillness significantly detracts from any potential emotional resonance. Additionally, the imagery in the MV lacked the substance and nuance found in many of the more highly-ranked short films. Overall, despite the song's strong musicality, *GHOST* was near unanimously agreed upon as the weakest of the ten short film nominations.
nominees.staff:
Clover Corp

Music by Suisei Hoshimachi

nominees.writeup:
Short, sweet, and to the point, *Kyoto Animation: Souzou-hen* is a cute and inspiring commercial from one of the anime industries' most prolific studios. Kyoto Animation used this opportunity to foster new young talent; newbie director Haruki Sakamoto gets a chance to shine, and Tamami Tokuyama receives her first character design and animation direction credits. The short succinctly captures the joy of creative imagination stemming from mundane everyday experiences. The idea of being stuck daydreaming since childhood brings the characters together, their shared passion and imagination never faltering as they grow up. It's fitting that a short about the power of young people's creativity is helmed by up-and-coming artists.

The CM clearly embodies the classic Kyoto Animation style, with round, expressive designs and clear care put into the smallest details. Despite its strengths, it's not perfect visually. Transitions during the first half could flow better and the CG animation feels a bit lifeless. Unfortunately, the 30-second runtime does restrict the heights and breadth the short can reach, and even the smallest visual hiccups can lower its standing among such a strong list of nominees. 

As the first CM from Kyoto Animation since 2013, it's an unexpected and exciting new work. Full of the passion and care emblematic of the studio, *Kyoto Animation: Souzou-hen* is an absolute joy to watch.
nominees.staff:
Kyoto Animation

Directed by Haruki Sakamoto

nominees.writeup:
When the *HOLOLIVE ALTERNATIVE* Teaser PV came out, it ignited exciting debate and theorizing in the community. The mystical intrigue of the PV opened possibilities for the Hololive universe, showcasing a wide lineup of VTubers in a cornucopia of environments, including a majestic world of sky islands, a traditional Japanese palace-themed city, and an ordinary urban Japanese landscape.

The detailed background art and environment designs are immediately eye-catching, though the compositing and storyboarding were less so. There are some stunning animated sequences, particularly the electrifying dragon battle sequence, even if the fast transitions and aggressive compositing diminished their enjoyability. The blazing-fast pace of character introduction shots are a decent way of seeing everyone within a limited time span, and the character acting is full of life, Aqua's clumsy handling of dishware especially so. Despite those charming moments, the shots are still rather one-note and too brief to leave an impact. Additionally, the vocal performance doesn't stand out as anything particularly special. 

Even with the teaser PV's narrative shortcomings, it still does a solid job at blending an exciting amount of fanservice while also teasing future projects for what's to come to the Hololive universe.
nominees.staff:
Clover Corp

Directed by Shun Enokido

awards.name: Short Series of the Year
awards.blurb:
One of the Shorts jury’s first tasks was to select a short for the Jury Writing Project. A tight vote narrowed the final contenders to the student film *About You* and the Disney+ series *Star Wars: Visions*, with *Star Wars: Visions* ultimately being selected. [The jury discussion on *Star Wars: Visions* can be found here.](https://old.reddit.com/r/anime/comments/rezo5i/ranime_awards_2021_shorts_jury_discusses_star/) 
 
Although the short films were overall stronger than the short series from this year, there was still no dearth to judge from. They greatly varied in length (from 3 minutes to 5 hours), source (from side story to original series), and genre (from ecchi comedy to angsty drama), thus making them difficult to compare. With 70 short series eligible, narrowing down to 4 nominees was truly difficult. Series with solid support, such as *Girl X* and *Yatogame-chan Kansatsu Nikki Sansatsume*, barely missed the cut.  
 
From the beginning, the two frontrunners in this category were *Pui Pui Molcar* and *Yoru no Kuni*, as both had widespread approval, with *Yoru no Kuni* pushing ahead in the latter half. The other rankings were heavily contested, as each nominee had positive and negative aspects, and though *Fate/Grand Carnival* finished behind the rest, it had its supporters as well.

nominees.writeup:
In this 6-episode miniseries, director Kazuma Ikeda explores the idea of finding and acknowledging one's true desires via a magic-enhanced form of therapy, presented as eclectic musical numbers. These setpieces use distinct and evocative imagery to contrast the mundane outside world with inner worlds that represent their individualistic sensibilities with abstract vistas and artistic color keys. In particular, these scenes show off the array of fashion scenes in Harajuku - the suburb the show is an homage to - with styles as diverse as Visual Kei and Himekaji being respectfully recreated in its short runtime.

The one questionable area of visuals is the 3DCG animation which falls squarely into the uncanny valley. Although, arguably it only adds to the bizarre and uneasy atmosphere the show is aiming for with its off-kilter cinematography and kooky sound design.

While the show is an episodic character study whose brief wishes and struggles might be hit or miss for the audience depending on personal experience, it also runs a background through line which gives the show more depth. During the course of the series, its main character, Nina, goes from the witch gleefully granting wishes to doubting the efficacy of her actions and their results. This character arc along with the series' audiovisual excellence secures *Artiswitch* a terrific third place spot.
nominees.staff:
Sunrise

Directed by Kazuma Ikeda

nominees.altname: Yakunara Mug Cup Mo + Yakunara Mug Cup Mo: Niban Gama
nominees.writeup:
*Yakunara Mug Cup Mo* is a heartwarming and genuine exploration of four school girls' admission into the pottery club. Located in Tajimi, a Japanese city famous for its pottery, the show portrays the eccentric lighthearted Himeno as she follows her mother's footsteps in exploring pottery. 

High moments of *Mug Cup* are incredibly fun, with impactful, emotional moments and some breathtaking animation and lighting. Character designs are also pleasing with the surprisingly robust adult cast. Combining with the bright, peppy personality of the core cast, they provide an extremely fun and unique atmosphere that brings the show to life. The slice-of-life moments feel relatable due to the characters' genuine natures and the attention to visual details.

However, as the show follows the "cute girls doing cute things" format, the characters are relatively weak. Being visually inconsistent at times as well, certain individual character moments shine at the cost of overall visual production. Furthermore, the plot can be boring due to its weak narrative, yet it may also be interesting because of how the show uses pottery as a means to reminiscence and process grief.
nominees.staff:
Nippon Animation

Directed by Jun Kamiya

nominees.writeup:
*Yoru No Kuni* is poignant in its themes of overcoming loss and moving forward towards new opportunities, with focuses on death, friendship, and careers. The beautiful pastel art dreamscapes, combined with Yoru's mesmerizing voice, are therapeutic in effect, and the wide camera angles on the characters allow the audience to properly take in the beauty of the world. The show relies on a mixture of 2D and 3D that meshes amazingly well to enhance visuals. The watercolor stars and warped crayon drawn trees are seamlessly drawn in 3D, leading to immersive composition when exploring the world, as the 3D allows for sharper camera movement and impactful motion work.

Furthermore, the characters are down to earth and relatable, as each is thoroughly fleshed out in terms of their trauma and how they overcome it. Each story also feels relatable, as it covers intrapersonal narratives with effective visual storytelling through imagery from each of the girl's lives. So much is packed into this short series where each episode could be watched multiple times to grasp something new every time. From the subtle changes in the landscape in terms of emotional responses from the girls, to the careful accompaniment of Aimer's soundtrack, *Yoru No Kuni* develops an utterly beautiful world.

Thus, it takes the crown as it is simply bounds ahead of the rest of the competition in terms of audiovisual excellence, storytelling, and character writing.

nominees.writeup:
One of the best stop-motion projects in recent memory, *Pui Pui Molcar* is incredibly unique, charming, and quirky. It is a bizarre world where people drive sentient vehicles that are hybrids between guinea pigs and motor vehicles. With each episode being short and usually focusing on solving a problem, *Pui Pui Molcar* delivers a surreal and adorable comedy in bite-sized pieces. Each episode has a unique storyline and delivers eccentricity as well as amusing comedy. 

The use of humans inside the cars and the “live” aspect is less than exceptional, despite occasionally presenting a fun aesthetic dichotomy. Other times, the “live” aspect creates a conflicting visual style with the superior Molcar aesthetic and the cloth world that make both halves less powerful.

Interestingly, the blending of real-world stop-motion animation is a strength of the Molcar sequences, creating an environment that feels distinct and alive. The fabric and creativity of the felt world make it seem homey and inviting. The camerawork is also creative, with various scenes having multiple angles and compositions that create a fluid and wonderful aesthetic presentation. The bright, vibrant color scheme brings every scene to life, while the sound design supports its comedic timing and maintains a sense of realism. 

Overall, *Pui Pui Molcar* is simply fun to watch while being full of life and energy. It is rare to find such simple fun in a show, let alone a stop-motion one. As such, the relentlessly charming *Pui Pui Molcar* takes home a well-deserving second place.

nominees.writeup:
*Ganbare, Douki-chan* is a pleasant surprise, as the adaptation ends up being less ecchi and more of a sweet adult rom-com. The show utilizes its runtime well, as introductory episodes that establish its formula give way to later episodes that deliberately subvert the expectations set by this formula for great comedic and romantic effect. 

The comedy is strong, and the side characters add enough flavor to maintain the show's interest. The romantic leads, aka the two “doukis,” develop a charming, subtly expressed romance, and their chemistry results in many fantastic moments. Whether it be stumbling home from bars, office parties, or Valentine's Day antics, perhaps missing the typical high school over-the-top bits is a nice change of pace. Additionally, the character design is spot on and pleasing, with Douki-chan standing out in particular. 

Unfortunately, some other aspects of the show's production fall off as the show progresses.  While the character designs remain consistent, the melting of the show's visuals increasingly grows. Coupled with weak, nearly non-existent backgrounds, the animation appears stiffer over time as well. Regardless, *Ganbare, Douki-chan* maintains being a worthwhile watch with its short episodic runtime telling a compelling romance story, thus landing in sixth place.

nominees.writeup:
Featuring everyone's favorite slightly-ahistorical servants, *Fate/Grand Carnival* is a look into the lighthearted side of the well-known franchise. A large number of different beloved characters make an appearance in a relatively short time frame, although some only briefly. With many different servants featuring in gags in which they can shine, *Grand Carnival* manages to create a short addition to the franchise that appeals to fans of almost any individual character from that franchise.
With a variety of different skits and gags, there is something for everyone's different comedic sensibilities. One skit that is widely successful is the YouTuber gag, as it perfectly captures the idiosyncrasies of the platform while fitting the established personalities of Ereshkigal and Osakabehime. However, the downside to the decision to go for broad appeal is that it also means that nearly every viewer will be presented with some bits that will not work for them. Additionally, the generic chibis that the series occasionally cut away to further disrupts the comedic flow, as their usage adds little to the series and prevents those scenes from having the same expressiveness as the rest of the short. 

The character dynamics are another high point for the short series, as it allows for multiple jokes about the power imbalance that exists between different servants. Some servants are more useful than others, and this series lets that be known loud and clear. In the end, the hit-or-miss nature of *Fate/Grand Carnival*'s comedy lead it to an eighth-place finish.

nominees.writeup:
The *Kaguya-sama OVA* is a mix of the show's usual brand of comedy with the trashiness of an ecchi series, fully taking advantage of the OVA format's less strict guidelines to maximize the fanservice it can deliver. 

It still carries the typical charms of the series. The characters are effortlessly charming and dynamically bounce off of each other. Series Director Mamoru Hatakeyama's storyboarding continues to be stellar, with even trite material becoming engaging, clever transitional elements like the back alley with the porn magazine neatly threads the disparate segments, and theatrical framing, such as putting a spotlight on Fujiwara as she feigns her abilities as a food critic, enhance the effectiveness of the gag. 

However, a lot of the most interesting visual ideas are not able to be executed to the heights of the second season, as this OVA feels like a low-priority production put out as a stop-gap before the upcoming third season. The exception to this are the fanservice scenes, which do have an oomph to their animation, but the inclusion of those scenes is contentious from a conceptual standpoint, and the production resources would have been better spent elsewhere.

The OVA's usage of self-aware jabs to justify its amount of fanservice also feels awkward with the delivery being far more comfortable and consequently funnier during the short cooking segment at the end. Given these issues the OVA could only rank as high as seventh despite being fairly enjoyable for most.

nominees.writeup:
*Star Wars: Visions* is an anthology of short films that departs from the traditional “Star Wars style” of previous works to create an innovative work of art for the franchise. With each episode helmed by a different director and studio (all given plenty of creative freedom), the individual stories feel like an exciting new tale while still tying into the iconic Star Wars mythology.

Each episode features a different art style, ranging from the spectacular and sleek presentation of Hiroyuki Imaishi's “The Twins” to the gritty black-and-white aesthetic in Takanobu Mizuno's “The Duel.” There is also no shortage of audiovisual spectacle, such as the stunningly animated climax of ”Lop and Ocho” by Kai Igarashi, and creative ambition in the anthology, such as Eunyoung Choi's unique spin on a traditional Star Wars tragedy in ”Akakiri.”

However, *Star Wars: Visions* is also the most divisive short, as it consists of varying strengths and weaknesses that spread across independent of each episode. For that, the episodes do not easily show which are the strongest and weakest, which is rather befitting for an anthology with creative voices targeting different niches in mind. Still, some episodes such as ”Akakiri” and ”The Village Bride” were more successful than other episodes like “Tattooine Rhapsody” due to differences in effectiveness of storytelling and such.

Overall, *Star Wars: Visions*'s audiovisual marvels and artistic ambition lead the anthology to land at a respectable fourth.

awards.name: Anime of the Year
awards.blurb:
Anime as a medium is in constant growth and various studios work hard to create new experiences for viewers. 2021 was no different, with exquisite shows ranging from immersive character dramas to fantasy shows with real-life commentaries. Finding and ranking shows with such diversity was a challenge for us. 
 
The jury sampled and discussed every show suggested by their peers to find the best of the best. Discussions were fierce as each suggestion excelled in at least one area. For example, *Odd Taxi* had strong character writing combined with intersecting storytelling, while *Fruits Basket: The Final* impressed with its compelling romance story and diverse cast. In the end, the jury made a consensus despite the limited number of slots. 
 
Among all steps of the awards process, *Sonny Boy* and *Heike Monogatari* were the most discussed shows. Both offered immersive experiences by excelling in all areas, especially at script and other aspects of production such as background art. They were tied down until the end even but the jury ultimately appreciated the visual storytelling of *Sonny Boy* more, resulting in it becoming the best anime of 2021 for them.

nominees.writeup:
A follow up to their 2018 series *SSSS.Gridman*, Akira Amemiya's Studio Trigger team did an exemplary job with *SSSS.Dynazenon*;  building on established ideas while forging a unique identity for the show. Expressive and flexible designs lead to some of the most memorable moments of animation this year. Static shots and an emphasis on integrating backgrounds into the visual language creates a tense atmosphere that lingers over the series. This is mirrored by the feelings of dissatisfaction and longing shared by the lively and likable cast— their individual arcs weaving together to create the thematic core at the heart of *SSSS.Dynazenon*. 



The five main characters all explore grief and dysfunction in distinct and compelling manners, from Yume's uncertainty about her sister to Gauma's regrets of a past long gone. The cast's  tight chemistry spurns development, and these bonds form the basis of their growth. The Kaiju Eugenicists offer a collection of fun and varied personalities while undergoing meaningful arcs of their own.



*SSSS.Dynazenon*'s presentation transitions from nuanced character drama to hot-blooded mecha-on-kaiju action at a moment's notice, flipping from subdued to bombastic seamlessly. Kai Ikarashi's episode 10 stands out from the myriad highlights of the show, brilliantly concluding character arcs with striking audiovisual presentation. A powerfully cathartic experience, the episode is one of the best in all of anime. All of *SSSS.Dynazenon*'s pieces come together to create one of the most cohesive and complete show's of the year, garnering a deserved third place.

nominees.writeup:
*Non Non Biyori Nonstop* picks up right where previous seasons left off, combining superb comedy and relaxing slice-of-life moments into a lovely package. Of course, simply repeating a formula isn't enough, and *Non Non Biyori Nonstop* meaningfully adds to its already successful recipe. New characters, particularly Shiori and Akane, add depth to existing characters, such as Renge's newfound older sister role. Needless to say, these additions don't detract from the series's hallmark strengths. Excellent cast chemistry and immaculate comedic timing continues with lighthearted, natural sounding dialogue. Renge is great as always, but her aforementioned dynamic with Shiori is truly a highlight. Side characters get increased emphasis, as Candy Store and Konomi have more frequent and varied skits.



Production is a mixed bag: the OST remains equal parts whimsical and atmospheric, the voice acting delivers childlike excitement to fuel comedic moments, and the bucolic backgrounds sell the laid-back atmosphere. Other production aspects, however, leave much to be desired, with animation offering the bare minimum and other visual production being similarly economical.



Given this is likely the final entry, fans may be satisfied with the show's typical fare,, but *Non Non Biyori Nonstop* changes as much as it maintains the status quo. Graduation and childbirth demarcate a newfound focus on endings and beginnings. Eventually things will change, even the idyllic world of *Non Non Biyori Nonstop* - but that's not necessarily bad. Renge put it best:



>  “It's not the same route every day. When it's rainy or cloudy, it's a little bit different. That's what's fun.” 



Summing it all up, it's easy to see why this was a truly excellent work.

nominees.writeup:
Presenting a historical tale about the fall of the once mighty Taira clan during the Genpei War, *Heike Monogatari* emphasizes the Buddhist truth that all existence is impermanent. Reflecting on this idea about the ever-changing state of all things, the anime ambitiously explores the shortsightedness of a pursuit towards worldly power, the collective's relation to fluctuating social values, and the individual's necessity to accept the inevitable decay of all things they hold dear.



Despite the grand stakes, the portrayal of the cast is endearingly human, from the joyously emotive animation to the lighthearted dialogue. Due to this great balance of very human characters with poetic fates, *Heike Monogatari* offers some of the best written characters of the year, while also providing emotionally resonant journeys with each of them.



The visuals triumph in elevating those emotions. Immersive sceneries, emotionally charged visual motifs, poignant compositions that guide viewers through the whole shot, harmonizing color schemes, and meticulous shot pacing all combine to produce impactful moments throughout the series.



While the imitation of woodblock printing aesthetic evokes a sense of history, the incorporation of modern elements, like the OST's electronic instrumentals, create a daringly time-transcending work. This ties to the intriguing meta-awareness about retelling a tale repeated through centuries, embodied in the anime original protagonist Biwa, a biwahōshi storyteller aware of the story's ending since the beginning.



As an adaption of a Japanese classic epic filled with ambition and compassion, *Heike Monogatari* is a must-watch from 2021.

nominees.writeup:
*Kobayashi-san Chi no Maid Dragon S* continues on from where the original season left off with a large focus on community and making the mundane fun, backed by its impressively consistent production.



*Maid Dragon* boasts some of the most impressive animation of the year with constantly fluid movement in both its fun slice of life scenes and its more action oriented moments involving battles between two majestic dragons. Every single gesture is filled with nuance and conveys the characters' respective emotions and personalities. The series constantly takes advantage of its near perfect production, using well-timed visual comedy with the movements of the cast. 



Unfortunately, the inconsistent cast  held back the show. Lucoa does get some appreciated development this season, but her relationship with Shouta and the comedy derived from it is still distasteful. Ilulu was a mixed bag: her design gives a bad impression before her strong character arc occurs, and her necessary dynamic with the rest of the household as the teenager of the family was notable.  



Tohru's relationship with Elma received significant screen time, and it was interesting to see the dragons before they came into contact with humans. Tohru's relationship with Kobayashi continued to get focus, thoughTohru's feelings have evolved to feel more genuine. Whilst *Maid Dragon* wasn't without its problems, its stronger moments earned it the title of the sixth  best anime of 2021.

nominees.writeup:
No better word describes *Sonny Boy* than an "experience". The anime is a vibrant and personal venture through the worldview of its director, Shingo Natsume. With the ever present trend of the anime industry to push for the next big hit, rarely do such flexible and freeing productions for anime come to fruition. That isn't to say that being 'fresh' is commendable by itself - execution is a crucial factor, something in which the show evidently excels.



*Sonny Boy* offers much intrigue through its storytelling, though it thrives further beyond its high school sci-fi and mystery premise. While largely a "coming-of-age" focus, the thematic strengths of the narrative tie the whole product together through empathizing the ideals of its characters. The show's relatively episodic structure and diverse cast offers many opportunities for the core cast to collaborate with each other, creating impressively emotive and understandable character developments throughout the series.



*Sonny Boy*'s visual front is phenomenal - its crisp and clean drawings, carefully managed compositing, and its creative and sincere framing and storyboarding are all outstandingly executed. A facade of simplicity and minimalism complements the more thought-provoking and human sequences. Generous character animation conjures additional depth from expressions and movements, bringing the feelings of the cast to the forefront.



The show's soundscape is tremendous as well. *Sonny Boy*'s soundtrack and the utilization of it was among the best exhibited throughout the year. Individual tracks were intimate, refreshing, and varied in instrumentation, complementing the fluctuating tone of the series. An emphasis on silence throughout offered the strong seiyuu cast space to flavor the gaps, while the most impactful scenes were accompanied by excellent insert songs.  Its sound design was also noteworthy, bringing believable life to the bizarre worlds featured.



The factors above combine into a cohesive and shining entry, granting *Sonny Boy* the title of Anime of the Year for 2021.

nominees.writeup:
*Vivy: Fluorite Eye's Song* burst onto the scene this year as an original anime whose futuristic setting, frenetic fight scenes and android idol protagonist quickly gained it a large following despite starting off with little fanfare. Its focus on the “one-task directive” for its android characters provided an opportunity to explore the setting in a way rarely seen in previous sci-fi anime.



The series starts off strong, solidly establishing a distinct atmosphere with its dystopian portrayal of a robot uprising. The self-contained nature of subsequent arcs, however, led to a lack of cohesiveness in its overall narrative. This caused the worldbuilding of the series to be noticeably shallower than needed for its setting, with Archive's role in particular having a huge impact on the series while receiving little to no depth or exploration.



The production was a mixed bag, with elements such as the OST alternating between effective and forgettable. At certain points the visual production showcased eye-catching fight scenes, while at other times it stumbled, such as in the battle between Vivy and Kakitani in episode 9. The character designs read well throughout, but there were moments where the choice of backgrounds didn't mesh well with them.



Slick fight choreography was one of the most consistently successful aspects of the series, as the battle scenes repeatedly showcased an engaging ebb and flow in their combat. In the end, the mix of intriguing premise with hit-or-miss execution led to a tenth place finish for the show.

nominees.writeup:
*Jujutsu Kaisen* is an eccentric entry imbued with bombastic fights and a darker focus on the ethereal. The show's distinct character designs, good sense of choreography communicated through its storyboards, and brisk narrative pacing accentuates its frequent brawls. Characters such as Yuji, Gojo, or Sukuna feel quite distinct - they have good vocal delivery and refreshing interactions with other members of the cast, rounding out those characters and the setting altogether.



Due to the combative nature of the story, introducing a group of “special grade” curses as our primary antagonists has been a mixed decision. While it creates an interesting point in the plot due to the categorization itself becoming arbitrary, it also has led to a lack of urgency in the fights. These constant clashes remove much needed tension and their outcomes feel unrewarding. 



The show has a garish art direction and mixed compositing that often harms its greater assets, namely seen in bad blending between characters and their background or thinning smoke. Occasionally weak visual cleanup on the animation either lessens the impact from blows or weakens the timing of character actions.



That being said, the fights themselves are executed well, with notable highlights including visual clarity, the retention of curse effects, and high caliber close-ups. Fight styles are unique for each character and the sound direction syncs the OST and fights in an evocative and memorable manner.

nominees.altname: Shingeki no Kyojin: The Final Season Part 1
nominees.writeup:
*Shingeki no Kyojin* airdrops into its final arcs with another solid installment. This season gives a much-needed alternate perspective as it follows Reiner, Gabi, and Falco. Seeing them confront the propaganda that has shaped the lives and morals of his home country emphasizes how much he has changed since the beginning of the series. The characterization isn't limited to these characters, though; many have compelling development that reflects their experiences in previous seasons.



This season, Studio Mappa takes over for Studio Wit, and although the production is still satisfying, it has some shortcomings. The compositing is inconsistent and distracting. For example, the 3D titans don't blend with the grimy aesthetic of the show. Splitting the season in two also caused pacing problems: instead of a cohesive show, it feels like one that ended prematurely, with plotlines such as Mikasa's background being shoehorned in near the end. Still, the character designs portray the weight of time and trauma upon the characters, with dark resting expressions accentuated by additional linework.



*Shingeki no Kyojin* never fails to engage with its action-packed fight scenes or jaw-dropping reveals. Fans of the series will continue to enjoy it, and anime enthusiasts can revel in a storytelling experience which few shows can match.  It is a worthy inclusion amongst this year's best, earning it eighth place.

nominees.writeup:
*Odd Taxi* provides a unique and distinctive experience that captivated audiences and stakes its claim as a contender in the 2021 anime landscape. The show features a tight narrative that weaves together many characters and storylines seamlessly. 



*Odd Taxi* shines with its varied and strong cast, each with compelling backgrounds and characterization that makes them charming to watch. Their interesting personalities combined with their realistic and uncovered issues makes for an appealing ensemble. Every character has their own role in the story, creating a large and balanced cast that has few weak points.



While *Odd Taxi* excels in some areas, there are limitations to the work. Despite the compelling cast, many of the characters are tied to Odakawa's presence. While the show has a distinct visual style, its animation sometimes fail to provide as vivid a viewing experience as other entries from this year.



That said, *Odd Taxi* provides a unique and charming experience that makes it one of the top shows of the year. The script stands out as top notch. There is no time wasted and every detail ends up being important in the long run, rewarding the viewer for paying close attention and setting up a story that fits like a puzzle. These details create a satisfying sense of mystery for all viewers.

nominees.altname: Mushoku Tensei: Isekai Ittara Honki Dasu (Part 1 and Part 2)
nominees.writeup:
Despite the controversy around it, *Mushoku Tensei* excels in several areas. The visuals are stunning, showcasing high-energy, well-choreographed fight animation that is incredible to watch. Its unique approach to opening sequences is noteworthy as well, utilizing them to explore each region and elevate the already strong world-building and story. This alternate reality of sword and sorcery may seem complex, but the narrative is cohesive and well-paced, providing numerous opportunities for characters to grow and their voice actors to shine.



However, opportunity alone is not enough. *Mushoku Tensei* is a character study about Rudeus Greyrat, his initial flaws and his prospective growth, and the writing tries to balance between “absolute scum” and “someone the audience can cheer for”—Rudy leans too heavily into the former category. Despite developing in some ways, his treatment of women is consistently awful, and the tendency of other characters to turn a blind eye to his antics is awkward and off-putting, dragging them down with him. This massive flaw remaining unaddressed after 25 episodes is a massive detriment; Rudy comes across as too perverse to be redeemed. 



The fact that *Mushoku Tensei* manages to accomplish so much despite this handicap is impressive. It's easy to see why the show is so beloved, and the energy put into the production is apparent. As that kind of passion is used to bring such a fascinating world to life, it's no wonder the series comes in at a well-deserved ninth place on the ranking for Anime of the Year.
